text: All buildings should have arrangements for detecting fire and raising the alarm.
text-fixed: All buildings should have arrangements for detecting fire and raising the alarm.

text: In most buildings, fires are detected by people, either by sight or smell, and therefore often nothing more is needed.
text-fixed: In most buildings, fires are detected by people, either by sight or smell, and therefore often nothing more is needed.

text: In some small buildings/premises, the means of raising the alarm may be simple (for example, a shouted warning).
text-fixed: The siting of the new building, or the second building if both are new, can then be checked to see that it also complies, using the

text: In assessing appropriate solutions, warnings need to be heard and understood throughout the premises.
text-fixed: In assessing appropriate solutions, warnings need to be heard and understood throughout the premises.

text: Other than for some small buildings/premises, an electrically operated fire alarm system should be provided.
text-fixed: Other than for some small buildings/premises, an electrically operated fire alarm system should be provided.

text: In some situations, the alarm should be operated by a fire detection system.
text-fixed: In some situations, the alarm should be operated by a fire detection system.

text: The detailed specification should be compatible with the fire strategy for the building.
text-fixed: The detailed specification should be compatible with the fire strategy for the building.

text: The term ‘fire alarm system’ describes the combination of components for giving an audible and/or other perceptible warning of fire.
text-fixed: The term ‘fire alarm system’ describes the combination of components for giving an audible and/or other perceptible warning of fire.

text: In this document, the term ‘fire detection system’ describes any type of automatic sensor network and associated control and indicating equipment.
text-fixed: In this document, the term ‘fire detection system’ describes any type of automatic sensor network and associated control and indicating equipment.

text: Sensors may be sensitive to smoke, heat, gaseous combustion products or radiation.
text-fixed: Sensors may be sensitive to smoke, heat, gaseous combustion products or radiation.

text: Automatic sprinkler systems can also be used to operate a fire alarm system.
text-fixed: Automatic sprinkler systems can also be used to operate a fire alarm system.

text: In ‘residential (institutional)’ and ‘residential (other)’ occupancies (purpose groups 2(a) and 2(b)), automatic fire detection and alarms should be provided.
text-fixed: In ‘residential (institutional)’ and ‘residential (other)’ occupancies (purpose groups 2(a) and 2(b)), automatic fire detection and alarms should be provided.

text: Automatic fire detection and alarm systems should be provided in non-residential occupancies where a fire could break out in an unoccupied part of the premises (e.g. a storage area or a part of the building that is not visited on a regular basis) and prejudice the means of escape from occupied part(s) of the premises.
text-fixed: Automatic fire detection and alarm systems should be provided in non-residential occupancies where a fire could break out in an unoccupied part of the premises (e.g. a storage area or a part of the building that is not visited on a regular basis) and prejudice the means of escape from occupied part(s) of the premises.

text: Automatic fire detection will also be necessary where fire protection systems, such as pressure differential systems or door releases, need to operate automatically.
text-fixed: Automatic fire detection will also be necessary where fire protection systems, such as pressure differential systems or door releases, need to operate automatically.

text: Every building design should be assessed individually.
text-fixed: Every building design should be assessed individually.

text: General guidance on the category of fire detection system that may need to be provided within a building can be found in Table A1 of BS 5839-1. 1.8 Where an electrically operated fire detection and alarm system is provided, it should comply with BS 5839-1.
text-fixed: General guidance on the category of fire detection system that may need to be provided within a building can be found in Table A1 of BS 5839-1. 1.8 Where an electrically operated fire detection and alarm system is provided, it should comply with BS 5839-1.

text: BS 5839-1 specifies three categories of system.
text-fixed: BS 5839-1 specifies three categories of system.

text: Category L – for the protection of life.
text-fixed: Category L – for the protection of life.

text: Category M – manual fire detection and alarm systems.
text-fixed: Category M – manual fire detection and alarm systems.

text: Category P – for property protection.
text-fixed: Category P – for property protection.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION Category L systems are divided into the following.
text-fixed: Category L systems are divided into the following.

text: systems installed throughout the protected building.
text-fixed: L1 - systems installed throughout the protected building.

text: systems installed only in defined parts of the protected building (a category L2 system will normally include the coverage required of a category L3 system).
text-fixed: L2 - systems installed only in defined parts of the protected building (a category L2 system will normally include the coverage required of a category L3 system).

text: systems designed to warn of fire at an early enough stage to enable all occupants, other than possibly those in the room where the fire started, to escape safely before the escape routes become impassable because of fire, smoke or toxic gases.
text-fixed: systems designed to warn of fire at an early enough stage to enable all occupants, other than possibly those in the room where the fire started, to escape safely before the escape routes become impassable because of fire, smoke or toxic gases.

text: systems installed within those parts of the escape routes that comprise circulation areas and circulation spaces, such as corridors and stairs.
text-fixed: systems installed within those parts of the escape routes that comprise circulation areas and circulation spaces, such as corridors and stairs.

text: systems in which the protected area(s) and/or the location of detectors are designed to satisfy a specific fire safety objective (other than that of a category L1, L2, L3 or L4 system).
text-fixed: systems in which the protected area(s) and/or the location of detectors are designed to satisfy a specific fire safety objective (other than that of a category L1, L2, L3 or L4 system).

text: Type P systems are divided into the following.
text-fixed: Type P systems are divided into the following.

text: systems installed throughout the protected building.
text-fixed: systems installed throughout the protected building.

text: systems installed only in defined parts of the protected building.
text-fixed: systems installed only in defined parts of the protected building.

text: Electrical alarm system call points should comply with either of the following.
text-fixed: Electrical alarm system call points should comply with either of the following.

text: Call points should be installed in accordance with BS 5839-1. Type B (indirect operation) call points of BS EN 54-11 should only be used with the approval of the building control body.
text-fixed: Call points should be installed in accordance with BS 5839-1. Type B (indirect operation) call points of BS EN 54-11 should only be used with the approval of the building control body.

text: A voice alarm system complying with BS 5839-8, and giving a fire warning different from other signals in general use, may be considered if either of the following applies.
text-fixed: A voice alarm system complying with BS 5839-8, and giving a fire warning different from other signals in general use, may be considered if either of the following applies.

text: People might not respond quickly to a fire warning.
text-fixed: People might not respond quickly to a fire warning.

text: People are unfamiliar with the fire warning arrangements.
text-fixed: People are unfamiliar with the fire warning arrangements.

text: In premises where lots of members of the public are present, an initial general alarm may be undesirable.
text-fixed: In premises where lots of members of the public are present, an initial general alarm may be undesirable.

text: Any fire alarm system that first alerts staff should comply with BS 5839-1.
text-fixed: Any fire alarm system that first alerts staff should comply with BS 5839-1.

text: Where the escape strategy is based on simultaneous evacuation, actuation of the fire alarm system should give warning from all fire alarm sounders.
text-fixed: Where the escape strategy is based on simultaneous evacuation, actuation of the fire alarm system should give warning from all fire alarm sounders.

text: Where phased evacuation is planned, a staged alarm system is appropriate.
text-fixed: Where phased evacuation is planned, a staged alarm system is appropriate.

text: BS 9999 provides guidance for fire detection and alarm systems in buildings containing atria.
text-fixed: BS 9999 provides guidance for fire detection and alarm systems in buildings containing atria.

text: Clause 18 of BS 5839-1 gives detailed guidance on the design and selection of fire alarm warnings for people with impaired hearing.
text-fixed: Clause 18 of BS 5839-1 gives detailed guidance on the design and selection of fire alarm warnings for people with impaired hearing.

text: In buildings or part of a building where people may be in relative isolation, a visual and audible fire alarm may be the most appropriate solution.
text-fixed: In buildings or part of a building where people may be in relative isolation, a visual and audible fire alarm may be the most appropriate solution.

text: In buildings where the population is managed, a vibrating personal paging system may be more appropriate.
text-fixed: In buildings where the population is managed, a vibrating personal paging system may be more appropriate.

text: Fire detection and alarm systems must be properly designed, installed and maintained.
text-fixed: Fire detection and alarm systems must be properly designed, installed and maintained.

text: A design, installation and commissioning certificate should be provided for fire detection and alarm systems.
text-fixed: A design, installation and commissioning certificate should be provided for fire detection and alarm systems.

text: Third party certification schemes for fire protection products and related services are an effective means of providing assurances of quality, reliability and safety.
text-fixed: Third party certification schemes for fire protection products and related services are an effective means of providing assurances of quality, reliability and safety.

text: Fire detection and alarm systems sometimes trigger other systems.
text-fixed: Fire detection and alarm systems sometimes trigger other systems.

text: The interface between systems must be reliable.
text-fixed: The interface between systems must be reliable.

text: Particular care should be taken if the interface is facilitated via another system.
text-fixed: Particular care should be taken if the interface is facilitated via another system.

text: Where any part of BS 7273 applies to the triggering of other systems, the recommendations of that part of BS 7273 should be followed.
text-fixed: Where any part of BS 7273 applies to the triggering of other systems, the recommendations of that part of BS 7273 should be followed.

text: Student accommodation 1.18 In student residences that are designed and occupied as a block of flats, separate automatic detection should be provided in each self-contained flat where all of the following apply.
text-fixed: Student accommodation 1.18 In student residences that are designed and occupied as a block of flats, separate automatic detection should be provided in each self-contained flat where all of the following apply.

text: A group of up to six students shares the flat.
text-fixed: A group of up to six students shares the flat.

text: Each flat has its own entrance door.
text-fixed: Each flat has its own entrance door.

text: The compartmentation principles for flats in Section 7 of Approved Document B Volume 1 have been followed.
text-fixed: The compartmentation principles for flats in Section 7 of Approved Document B Volume 1 have been followed.

text: Where a total evacuation strategy is adopted, the alarm system should follow the guidance elsewhere in this section.
text-fixed: Where a total evacuation strategy is adopted, the alarm system should follow the guidance elsewhere in this section.

text: Means of escape should be provided from any point on a storey to the storey exit, for all types of building.
text-fixed: Means of escape should be provided from any point on a storey to the storey exit, for all types of building.

text: The general principle is that any person confronted by a fire within a building can turn away from it and escape safely.
text-fixed: The general principle is that any person confronted by a fire within a building can turn away from it and escape safely.

text: For small shop, office, industrial, storage and other similar premises, the guidance on small premises (see section 4) may be followed instead of the provisions in this section, if they meet both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: For small shop, office, industrial, storage and other similar premises, the guidance on small premises (see section 4) may be followed instead of the provisions in this section, if they meet both of the following conditions.

text: No storey has an area more than 280m2.
text-fixed: No storey has an area more than 280m2.

text: There is a maximum of two storeys plus a basement storey.
text-fixed: There is a maximum of two storeys plus a basement storey.

text: The number of escape routes and exits that should be provided depends on both of the following.
text-fixed: The number of escape routes and exits that should be provided depends on both of the following.

text: The number of occupants in the room, tier or storey.
text-fixed: The number of occupants in the room, tier or storey.

text: The limits on travel distance to the nearest exit given in Table 2.1 (which apply only to the nearest exit; other exits may be further away).
text-fixed: The limits on travel distance to the nearest exit given in Table 2.1 (which apply only to the nearest exit; other exits may be further away).

text: In multi-storey buildings, if more than one stair is needed for vertical escape, every part of each storey should have access to more than one stair.
text-fixed: In multi-storey buildings, if more than one stair is needed for vertical escape, every part of each storey should have access to more than one stair.

text: An area may be in a dead end provided the alternative stair is accessible.
text-fixed: An area may be in a dead end provided the alternative stair is accessible.

text: In mixed use buildings, separate means of escape should be provided from any storeys or parts of storeys used for the ‘residential’ or ‘assembly and recreation’ purpose groups (purpose groups 1, 2 and 5).
text-fixed: In mixed use buildings, separate means of escape should be provided from any storeys or parts of storeys used for the ‘residential’ or ‘assembly and recreation’ purpose groups (purpose groups 1, 2 and 5).

text: A single escape route is acceptable for either of the following.
text-fixed: A single escape route is acceptable for either of the following.

text: Parts of a floor from which a storey exit can be reached within the limit for travel distance in one direction shown in Table 2.1 (see also paragraph 2.8), provided the following apply.
text-fixed: Parts of a floor from which a storey exit can be reached within the limit for travel distance in one direction shown in Table 2.1 (see also paragraph 2.8), provided the following apply.

text: For places of assembly and bars, no one room in this situation has more than 60 people.
text-fixed: For places of assembly and bars, no one room in this situation has more than 60 people.

text: For ‘residential (institutional)’ buildings (purpose group 2(a)), no one room in this situation has more than 30 people.
text-fixed: For ‘residential (institutional)’ buildings (purpose group 2(a)), no one room in this situation has more than 30 people.

text: Occupant number calculations are described in Appendix D.
text-fixed: Occupant number calculations are described in Appendix D.

text: A storey with no more than 60 people, where the limits on travel distance in one direction only are satisfied (see Table 2.1).
text-fixed: A storey with no more than 60 people, where the limits on travel distance in one direction only are satisfied (see Table 2.1).

text: In many cases, the beginning of a route will not have an alternative escape route (for example, a single exit from a room into a corridor where escape is possible in two directions).
text-fixed: In many cases, the beginning of a route will not have an alternative escape route (for example, a single exit from a room into a corridor where escape is possible in two directions).

text: This is acceptable if both of the following apply.
text-fixed: This is acceptable if both of the following apply.

text: The travel distance to the nearest storey exit is within the limits for routes where escape is possible in more than one direction (Table 2.1).
text-fixed: The travel distance to the nearest storey exit is within the limits for routes where escape is possible in more than one direction (Table 2.1).

text: The travel distance for the ‘one direction only’ section of the route does not exceed the limit for travel distance where there is no alternative escape route (Table 2.1).
text-fixed: The travel distance for the ‘one direction only’ section of the route does not exceed the limit for travel distance where there is no alternative escape route (Table 2.1).

text: Diagram 2.1 shows how to measure travel distances from a dead end in an open storey layout.
text-fixed: Diagram 2.1 shows how to measure travel distances from a dead end in an open storey layout.

text: should meet all of the following.
text-fixed: Travel distance in a dead-end condition should meet all of the following.

text: Angle ABD should be at least 45 degrees.
text-fixed: Angle ABD should be at least 45 degrees.

text: distance given for alternative escape routes.
text-fixed: Distance CBA or CBD (whichever is less) should be no more than the maximum travel distance given for alternative escape routes.

text: alternative escape routes.
text-fixed: Distance CB should be no more than the maximum travel distance where there are no alternative escape routes.

text: Assembly and recreation:
text-fixed: Assembly and recreation:

text: Place of special fire hazard(4) Plant room or roof-top plant:
text-fixed: Place of special fire hazard(4) Plant room or roof-top plant:

text-fixed: Maximum travel distance(1) where travel is possible in:

text: If the internal layout of partitions, fittings, etc. is not known, direct distances, rather than travel distances, should be assessed.
text-fixed: If the internal layout of partitions, fittings, etc. is not known, direct distances, rather than travel distances, should be assessed.

text: The direct distance should be assumed to be two-thirds of the actual travel distance.
text-fixed: The direct distance should be assumed to be two-thirds of the actual travel distance.

text: Maximum part of travel distance within the room.
text-fixed: Maximum part of travel distance within the room.

text: This limit applies within the bedroom and any associated dressing room, bathroom or sitting room, etc.
text-fixed: This limit applies within the bedroom and any associated dressing room, bathroom or sitting room, etc.

text: The distance is measured to the door to the protected corridor that serves the room or suite.
text-fixed: The distance is measured to the door to the protected corridor that serves the room or suite.

text: Sub-item (b) applies from that point along the bedroom corridor to a storey exit.
text-fixed: Sub-item (b) applies from that point along the bedroom corridor to a storey exit.

text: In industrial and storage buildings, the appropriate travel distance depends on the level of fire hazard associated with the processes and materials being used.
text-fixed: In industrial and storage buildings, the appropriate travel distance depends on the level of fire hazard associated with the processes and materials being used.

text: Higher hazard includes manufacturing, processing or storage of significant amounts of hazardous goods or materials, including any of the following.
text-fixed: Higher hazard includes manufacturing, processing or storage of significant amounts of hazardous goods or materials, including any of the following.

text: • Any compressed, liquefied or dissolved gas.
text-fixed: Any compressed, liquefied or dissolved gas.

text: • Any substance that becomes dangerous by interaction with either air or water.
text-fixed: Any substance that becomes dangerous by interaction with either air or water.

text: • Any liquid substance with a flash point below 65°C, including whisky or other alcoholic liquor.
text-fixed: Any liquid substance with a flash point below 65°C, including whisky or other alcoholic liquor.

text: • Any corrosive substance.
text-fixed: Any corrosive substance.

text: • Any oxidising agent.
text-fixed: Any oxidising agent.

text: • Any substance liable to spontaneous combustion.
text-fixed: Any substance liable to spontaneous combustion.

text: • Any substance that changes or decomposes readily, giving out heat when doing so.
text-fixed: Any substance that changes or decomposes readily, giving out heat when doing so.

text: • Any solid substance with a flash point less than 120°C.
text-fixed: Any solid substance with a flash point less than 120°C.

text: • Any substance that is likely to spread fire by flowing from one part of a building to another.
text-fixed: Any substance that is likely to spread fire by flowing from one part of a building to another.

text: Places of special fire hazard are listed in the definitions in Appendix A.
text-fixed: Places of special fire hazard are listed in the definitions in Appendix A.

text: Maximum part of travel distance within the room/area.
text-fixed: Maximum part of travel distance within the room/area.

text: Travel distance outside the room/area should comply with the limits for the purpose group of the building or part.
text-fixed: Travel distance outside the room/area should comply with the limits for the purpose group of the building or part.

text: Measures to restrict access to the building (or parts of it) should not adversely affect fire safety provisions.
text-fixed: Measures to restrict access to the building (or parts of it) should not adversely affect fire safety provisions.

text: It may be reasonable to close some escape routes outside normal business hours, but measures should remain to safely evacuate people left inside the building (see paragraph 5.6).
text-fixed: It may be reasonable to close some escape routes outside normal business hours, but measures should remain to safely evacuate people left inside the building (see paragraph 5.6).

text: The building design should be based on the number of occupants.
text-fixed: The building design should be based on the number of occupants.

text: If the number is not known, use the appropriate floor space factors (Appendix D).
text-fixed: If the number is not known, use the appropriate floor space factors (Appendix D).

text: Table 2.2 gives the minimum number of escape routes and exits from a room or storey for different numbers of occupants.
text-fixed: Table 2.2 gives the minimum number of escape routes and exits from a room or storey for different numbers of occupants.

text: This number is likely to be increased by the need to observe travel distances and other practical considerations.
text-fixed: This number is likely to be increased by the need to observe travel distances and other practical considerations.

text: The width of escape routes and exits is given in paragraph 2.18.
text-fixed: The width of escape routes and exits is given in paragraph 2.18.

text: Alternative escape routes should satisfy one of the following criteria.
text-fixed: Alternative escape routes should satisfy one of the following criteria.

text: They are in directions 45 degrees or more apart (Diagram 2.2).
text-fixed: They are in directions 45 degrees or more apart (Diagram 2.2).

text: They are in directions less than 45 degrees apart, but separated from each other by fire resisting construction.
text-fixed: They are in directions less than 45 degrees apart, but separated from each other by fire resisting construction.

text: is 45 degrees or more and therefore distance CA or CB (whichever is the less) should be no more than the maximum travel distance given for alternative escape routes.

text: ADB is less than 45 degrees (therefore see Diagram 2.1).
text-fixed: ADB is less than 45 degrees (therefore see Diagram 2.1).

text: There is also no alternative escape route from E.
text-fixed: There is also no alternative escape route from E.

text: An inner room is at risk if a fire starts in the access room (Diagram 2.3).
text-fixed: An inner room is at risk if a fire starts in the access room (Diagram 2.3).

text: Such an arrangement should only be accepted if all of the following conditions are satisfied.
text-fixed: Such an arrangement should only be accepted if all of the following conditions are satisfied.

text: B1Table 2.2 Minimum number of escape routes and exits from a room, tier or storeyONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION a. The occupant number of the inner room does not exceed:
text-fixed: The occupant number of the inner room does not exceed:

text: people for other purpose groups.
text-fixed: 60 people for other purpose groups.

text: The inner room is not a bedroom.
text-fixed: The inner room is not a bedroom.

text: The inner room is entered directly from the access room (but not via a corridor).
text-fixed: The inner room is entered directly from the access room (but not via a corridor).

text: The escape route from the inner room does not pass through more than one access room.
text-fixed: The escape route from the inner room does not pass through more than one access room.

text: The travel distance from any point in the inner room to the exits from the access room does not exceed the distances in Table 2.1.
text-fixed: The travel distance from any point in the inner room to the exits from the access room does not exceed the distances in Table 2.1.

text: The access room meets both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: The access room meets both of the following conditions.

text: It is not a place of special fire hazard.
text-fixed: It is not a place of special fire hazard.

text: It is in the control of the same occupier.
text-fixed: It is in the control of the same occupier.

text: One of the following arrangements is made.
text-fixed: One of the following arrangements is made.

text: The enclosures (walls or partitions) of the inner room stop a minimum of 500mm below the ceiling.
text-fixed: The enclosures (walls or partitions) of the inner room stop a minimum of 500mm below the ceiling.

text: The door or walls of the inner room contain a vision panel (minimum 0.1m2), so people can see if a fire starts in the access room.
text-fixed: The door or walls of the inner room contain a vision panel (minimum 0.1m2), so people can see if a fire starts in the access room.

text: The access room is fitted with an automatic fire detection and alarm system to warn occupants of the inner room if a fire starts in the access room.
text-fixed: The access room is fitted with an automatic fire detection and alarm system to warn occupants of the inner room if a fire starts in the access room.

text: Arrangement A Needs no special provision.
text-fixed: Arrangement A Needs no special provision.

text: Arrangement B Should observe the inner room provisions in paragraph 2.11.
text-fixed: Arrangement B Should observe the inner room provisions in paragraph 2.11.

text: Where a central core has more than one exit, storey exits should be remote from one another and no two exits should be approached from the same lift hall, common lobby or undivided corridor (Diagram 2.4).
text-fixed: Where a central core has more than one exit, storey exits should be remote from one another and no two exits should be approached from the same lift hall, common lobby or undivided corridor (Diagram 2.4).

text: Escape routes should not be within 4.5m of openings between floors, such as for an escalator, unless either of the following applies.
text-fixed: Escape routes should not be within 4.5m of openings between floors, such as for an escalator, unless either of the following applies.

text: The direction of travel is away from the opening.
text-fixed: The direction of travel is away from the opening.

text: An alternative escape route does not pass within 4.5m of the open connection (Diagram 2.5).
text-fixed: An alternative escape route does not pass within 4.5m of the open connection (Diagram 2.5).

text: The doors at both ends of the area marked ‘S’ should be self-closing ﬁre doorsets unless the area is sub-divided such that any ﬁre in that area will not be able to prejudice both sections of corridor at the same time.
text-fixed: The doors at both ends of the area marked ‘S’ should be self-closing fire doorsets unless the area is sub-divided such that any fire in that area will not be able to prejudice both sections of corridor at the same time.

text: If that area is a lift lobby, doors should be provided as shown in Figure 9 in BS 9999.
text-fixed: If that area is a lift lobby, doors should be provided as shown in Figure 9 in BS 9999.

text: Services, toilets, etc.
text-fixed: Services, toilets, etc.

text: From A and B at least one direction of travel is away from the opening.
text-fixed: From A and B at least one direction of travel is away from the opening.

text: From C, where the initial direction of travel is towards the opening, one of the escape routes is not less than 4.5m from the opening.
text-fixed: From C, where the initial direction of travel is towards the opening, one of the escape routes is not less than 4.5m from the opening.

text: Where a storey has more than one escape stair, it should be planned so that it is not necessary to pass through one stair to reach another.
text-fixed: Where a storey has more than one escape stair, it should be planned so that it is not necessary to pass through one stair to reach another.

text: However, it would be acceptable to pass through one stair’s protected lobby to reach another stair.
text-fixed: However, it would be acceptable to pass through one stair’s protected lobby to reach another stair.

text: Where they serve protected stairways that are part of primary circulation routes, self-closing fire doors should be fitted with an automatic release mechanism, to avoid them being rendered ineffective by misuse.
text-fixed: Where they serve protected stairways that are part of primary circulation routes, self-closing fire doors should be fitted with an automatic release mechanism, to avoid them being rendered ineffective by misuse.

text: Otherwise, the stair (and any associated exit passageway) should not form part of the primary circulation route between different parts of the building at the same level.
text-fixed: Otherwise, the stair (and any associated exit passageway) should not form part of the primary circulation route between different parts of the building at the same level.

text: If a storey contains areas for consuming food and/or drink, and where that is not the main use of the building, then both of the following apply.
text-fixed: If a storey contains areas for consuming food and/or drink, and where that is not the main use of the building, then both of the following apply.

text: A minimum of two escape routes should be provided from each area, except from inner rooms that meet the conditions in paragraph 2.11.
text-fixed: A minimum of two escape routes should be provided from each area, except from inner rooms that meet the conditions in paragraph 2.11.

text: Those escape routes should lead directly to a storey exit without entering a kitchen or similar area of high fire hazard.
text-fixed: Those escape routes should lead directly to a storey exit without entering a kitchen or similar area of high fire hazard.

text: Where a storey is divided into areas of occupancy under separate ownership or tenancy, then both of the following apply.
text-fixed: Where a storey is divided into areas of occupancy under separate ownership or tenancy, then both of the following apply.

text: The means of escape from each occupancy should not pass through any other occupancy.
text-fixed: The means of escape from each occupancy should not pass through any other occupancy.

text: If a common corridor or circulation space is on the escape route, one of the following should apply.
text-fixed: If a common corridor or circulation space is on the escape route, one of the following should apply.

text: It should be a protected corridor.
text-fixed: It should be a protected corridor.

text: A suitable automatic fire detection and alarm system should be installed throughout the storey.
text-fixed: A suitable automatic fire detection and alarm system should be installed throughout the storey.

text: The width of escape routes and exits should meet the provisions in Table 2.3, as well as the guidance in Approved Document M.
text-fixed: The width of escape routes and exits should meet the provisions in Table 2.3, as well as the guidance in Approved Document M.

text: If the maximum number of people likely to use the escape route and exit is not known, it should be calculated using the occupant number guidance in Appendix D.
text-fixed: If the maximum number of people likely to use the escape route and exit is not known, it should be calculated using the occupant number guidance in Appendix D.

text: Guidance on the spacing of fixed seating for auditoria is given in Annex D of BS 9999.
text-fixed: Guidance on the spacing of fixed seating for auditoria is given in Annex D of BS 9999.

text: See Appendix D for methods of measurement.
text-fixed: See Appendix D for methods of measurement.

text: Widths may need to be increased to meet guidance in Approved Document M.
text-fixed: Widths may need to be increased to meet guidance in Approved Document M.

text: Widths less than 1050mm should not be interpolated.
text-fixed: Widths less than 1050mm should not be interpolated.

text: 5mm/person does not apply to an opening serving fewer than 220 people.

text: Where multiple storey exits are available, fire might prevent one from being used.

text: Remaining exits need to be wide enough for all occupants, so when using Table 2.3, the largest exit should be discounted.

text: Stairs should be at least as wide as any storey exit leading onto them.

text: While some stairs are not subject to discounting (paragraphs 3.14 and 3.15), because the stairs will be available for other floors, the storey exits onto them are.

text: To calculate how many people two or more available exits (after discounting) can accommodate, add together the maximum numbers of people that each exit width can accommodate.
text-fixed: To calculate how many people two or more available exits (after discounting) can accommodate, add together the maximum numbers of people that each exit width can accommodate.

text: For example, three exits each 850mm wide accommodate 33110 = 330 people.
text-fixed: For example, three exits each 850mm wide accommodate 33110 = 330 people.

text: If a ground floor storey exit and a stair share a final exit (via a ground floor lobby), then the final exit should be wide enough to evacuate people at a maximum flow rate equal to or greater than from the storey exit and stair combined (Diagram 2.6).
text-fixed: If a ground floor storey exit and a stair share a final exit (via a ground floor lobby), then the final exit should be wide enough to evacuate people at a maximum flow rate equal to or greater than from the storey exit and stair combined (Diagram 2.6).

text: This can be calculated using the following formula:
text-fixed: This can be calculated using the following formula:

text: S is the stair width in metres.

text: If the number of people (N) entering the lobby from the ground storey is more than 60, then the distance from the foot of the stair or the storey exit to the final exit should be a minimum of 2m (see Diagram 2.6).
text-fixed: If the number of people (N) entering the lobby from the ground storey is more than 60, then the distance from the foot of the stair or the storey exit to the final exit should be a minimum of 2m (see Diagram 2.6).

text: If that minimum distance cannot be achieved, the width of the final exit (W) should be at least the width of the stair plus the width of the storey exit.

text: A ground floor storey exit serving 250 people shares a common final exit with a 1.2m wide stair.
text-fixed: A ground floor storey exit serving 250 people shares a common final exit with a 1.2m wide stair.

text: A corridor serving as part of the means of escape in any of the following circumstances should be a protected corridor.
text-fixed: A corridor serving as part of the means of escape in any of the following circumstances should be a protected corridor.

text: Every corridor that serves bedrooms.
text-fixed: Every corridor that serves bedrooms.

text: Every dead-end corridor (excluding recesses and extensions a maximum of 2m deep, as shown in Diagrams 2.7 and 2.8).
text-fixed: Every dead-end corridor (excluding recesses and extensions a maximum of 2m deep, as shown in Diagrams 2.7 and 2.8).

text: Any corridor shared by two or more occupancies (paragraph 2.17).
text-fixed: Any corridor shared by two or more occupancies (paragraph 2.17).

text: If a corridor is used for a means of escape but is not a protected corridor, even though the enclosing partitions may have no fire resistance, both of the following should be met to inhibit the spread of smoke.
text-fixed: If a corridor is used for a means of escape but is not a protected corridor, even though the enclosing partitions may have no fire resistance, both of the following should be met to inhibit the spread of smoke.

text: Partitions should continue to the soffit of the structural floor above, or to a suspended ceiling.
text-fixed: Partitions should continue to the soffit of the structural floor above, or to a suspended ceiling.

text: Openings into rooms from the corridor should be fitted with doors, which do not need to be fire doorsets.
text-fixed: Openings into rooms from the corridor should be fitted with doors, which do not need to be fire doorsets.

text: Open planning will not inhibit the spread of smoke, but occupants can become aware of a fire quickly.
text-fixed: Open planning will not inhibit the spread of smoke, but occupants can become aware of a fire quickly.

text: A corridor providing access to alternative escape routes should be divided by fire doorsets fitted with a self-closing device (and associated screens) where both of the following apply.
text-fixed: A corridor providing access to alternative escape routes should be divided by fire doorsets fitted with a self-closing device (and associated screens) where both of the following apply.

text: It is more than 12m long.
text-fixed: It is more than 12m long.

text: It connects two or more storey exits.
text-fixed: It connects two or more storey exits.

text: The fire doorsets (including any screens) should be approximately mid-way between the two storey exits.
text-fixed: The fire doorsets (including any screens) should be approximately mid-way between the two storey exits.

text: They should safeguard the route from smoke, while considering the layout of the corridor and any adjacent fire risks.
text-fixed: They should safeguard the route from smoke, while considering the layout of the corridor and any adjacent fire risks.

text: For buildings other than dwellings (purpose groups 2 to 7): if a cavity exists above the enclosures to a corridor as described above (because the enclosures are not carried to full storey height or the underside of the roof covering at the top storey), the potential for smoke to bypass the enclosure should be restricted by one of the following methods.
text-fixed: For buildings other than dwellings (purpose groups 2 to 7): if a cavity exists above the enclosures to a corridor as described above (because the enclosures are not carried to full storey height or the underside of the roof covering at the top storey), the potential for smoke to bypass the enclosure should be restricted by one of the following methods.

text: Method 1 – Fitting cavity barriers on the line of the enclosure(s) to and across the corridor (Diagram 2.9).
text-fixed: Method 1 – Fitting cavity barriers on the line of the enclosure(s) to and across the corridor (Diagram 2.9).

text: Method 2 – Dividing the storey using fire resisting construction that passes through the line of the division of the corridor (Diagram 2.9).
text-fixed: Method 2 – Dividing the storey using fire resisting construction that passes through the line of the division of the corridor (Diagram 2.9).

text: Any cavity above this division should be fitted with cavity barriers on the line of division of the storey and the corridor.
text-fixed: Any cavity above this division should be fitted with cavity barriers on the line of division of the storey and the corridor.

text: Method 3 – Enclosing the cavity on the lower side by a fire resisting ceiling that extends throughout the building, compartment or separated part.
text-fixed: Method 3 – Enclosing the cavity on the lower side by a fire resisting ceiling that extends throughout the building, compartment or separated part.

text: closing device (but need not necessarily be fire resisting).
text-fixed: Any door that could provide a path for smoke to bypass the division should be fitted with a self-closing device (but need not necessarily be fire resisting).

text: on line of corridor
text-fixed: Cavity barriers on line of corridor

text: ceiling cavity over the sub-division.
text-fixed: A cavity barrier may be used in any ceiling cavity over the sub-division.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION 2.28 Where dead ends of corridors exceeding 4.5m long provide access to a point from which alternative escape routes are available, they should be separated by self-closing fire doorsets (together with any associated screens) from any part of the corridor that either:
text-fixed: Where dead ends of corridors exceeding 4.5m long provide access to a point from which alternative escape routes are available, they should be separated by self-closing fire doorsets (together with any associated screens) from any part of the corridor that either:

text: Continues past one storey exit to another (Diagram 2.10b).
text-fixed: Continues past one storey exit to another (Diagram 2.10b).

text: Alternatively, the stairs and corridors may be protected by a pressurisation system complying with BS EN 12101-6.
text-fixed: Alternatively, the stairs and corridors may be protected by a pressurisation system complying with BS EN 12101-6.

text: Additional measures to safeguard means of escape from smoke are given in Section 10.
text-fixed: Additional measures to safeguard means of escape from smoke are given in Section 10.

text: Where an external escape route is beside an external wall of the building, the external wall should be of fire resisting construction in both of the following zones.
text-fixed: Where an external escape route is beside an external wall of the building, the external wall should be of fire resisting construction in both of the following zones.

text: Within 1800mm of the escape route.
text-fixed: Within 1800mm of the escape route.

text: Up to 1100mm above the surface of the escape route.
text-fixed: Up to 1100mm above the surface of the escape route.

text: This does not apply to external escape stairs (see paragraph 3.32).
text-fixed: This does not apply to external escape stairs (see paragraph 3.32).

text: Where a storey or part of a building has multiple escape routes available, one may be over a flat roof if it does not serve a ‘residential (institutional)’ (purpose group 2(a)) building, or part of a building intended for use by members of the public.
text-fixed: Where a storey or part of a building has multiple escape routes available, one may be over a flat roof if it does not serve a ‘residential (institutional)’ (purpose group 2(a)) building, or part of a building intended for use by members of the public.

text: Where an escape route over a flat roof is provided, the roof should comply with all of the following.
text-fixed: Where an escape route over a flat roof is provided, the roof should comply with all of the following.

text: It should be part of the same building from which escape is being made.
text-fixed: It should be part of the same building from which escape is being made.

text: The route across the roof should lead to a storey exit or external escape route.
text-fixed: The route across the roof should lead to a storey exit or external escape route.

text: The part of the roof forming the escape route and its supporting structure, together with any opening within 3m of the escape route, should be fire resisting (minimum REI 30).
text-fixed: The part of the roof forming the escape route and its supporting structure, together with any opening within 3m of the escape route, should be fire resisting (minimum REI 30).

text: The route should be clearly defined and guarded by walls and/or protective barriers to protect from falling.
text-fixed: The route should be clearly defined and guarded by walls and/or protective barriers to protect from falling.

text: The choice of fire safety strategy depends on the way a building is designed, furnished, staffed and managed, and on the level of dependency of the residents.
text-fixed: The choice of fire safety strategy depends on the way a building is designed, furnished, staffed and managed, and on the level of dependency of the residents.

text: In care homes for the elderly, some or all residents are likely to need help to evacuate.
text-fixed: In care homes for the elderly, some or all residents are likely to need help to evacuate.

text: Buildings should generally be designed for progressive horizontal evacuation (PHE) in accordance with paragraphs 2.35 to 2.46.
text-fixed: Buildings should generally be designed for progressive horizontal evacuation (PHE) in accordance with paragraphs 2.35 to 2.46.

text: For other care home types, the most appropriate of either a PHE or simultaneous evacuation strategy should be identified.
text-fixed: For other care home types, the most appropriate of either a PHE or simultaneous evacuation strategy should be identified.

text: The approach adopted in the design of a building must be recorded and communicated to the building management team, who can adopt procedures compatible with the building design.
text-fixed: The approach adopted in the design of a building must be recorded and communicated to the building management team, who can adopt procedures compatible with the building design.

text: The guidance below on PHE is for care homes where the provisions of the Firecode documents do not apply (see paragraph 0.10).
text-fixed: The guidance below on PHE is for care homes where the provisions of the Firecode documents do not apply (see paragraph 0.10).

text: PHE requires areas used for the care of residents to be divided into protected areas by compartment walls and compartment floors.
text-fixed: PHE requires areas used for the care of residents to be divided into protected areas by compartment walls and compartment floors.

text: Protected areas provide a place of relative safety, from which further evacuation can be made if necessary.
text-fixed: Protected areas provide a place of relative safety, from which further evacuation can be made if necessary.

text: Each storey used for the care of residents should be divided by compartment walls into at least three protected areas.
text-fixed: Each storey used for the care of residents should be divided by compartment walls into at least three protected areas.

text: All floors should be compartment floors.
text-fixed: All floors should be compartment floors.

text: Every protected area should have a minimum of two exits to adjoining protected areas.
text-fixed: Every protected area should have a minimum of two exits to adjoining protected areas.

text: Maximum travel distances within a protected area should be both of the following.
text-fixed: Maximum travel distances within a protected area should be both of the following.

text: To the exit to the adjoining protected area: as shown in Table 2.1.
text-fixed: To the exit to the adjoining protected area: as shown in Table 2.1.

text: From any point to a storey exit or a final exit: 64m.
text-fixed: From any point to a storey exit or a final exit: 64m.

text: A fire in one protected area should not prevent occupants of other areas from reaching a final exit (Diagram 2.11).
text-fixed: A fire in one protected area should not prevent occupants of other areas from reaching a final exit (Diagram 2.11).

text: Escape routes should not pass through ancillary accommodation listed in paragraph 2.44.
text-fixed: Escape routes should not pass through ancillary accommodation listed in paragraph 2.44.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION 2.39 The number of residents’ beds in protected areas should be based on an assessment of both of the following.
text-fixed: The number of residents’ beds in protected areas should be based on an assessment of both of the following.

text: The number of staff likely to be available.
text-fixed: The number of staff likely to be available.

text: The level of assistance that residents may require.
text-fixed: The level of assistance that residents may require.

text: The maximum number of residents’ beds in one protected area should not exceed 10, but may need to be lower depending on the assessment.
text-fixed: The maximum number of residents’ beds in one protected area should not exceed 10, but may need to be lower depending on the assessment.

text: A protected area used for horizontal evacuation from an adjoining protected area should have a floor area able to accommodate its own occupants plus those from the largest adjoining protected area.
text-fixed: A protected area used for horizontal evacuation from an adjoining protected area should have a floor area able to accommodate its own occupants plus those from the largest adjoining protected area.

text: in ﬁre resisting construction.
text-fixed: Bedrooms and all ancillary accommodation should be enclosed in fire resisting construction.

text: A fire detection and alarm system should be provided to L1 standard in accordance with BS 5839-1.
text-fixed: A fire detection and alarm system should be provided to L1 standard in accordance with BS 5839-1.

text: Each bedroom in a care home should be enclosed in fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30) with fire resisting doors (minimum E 30).
text-fixed: Each bedroom in a care home should be enclosed in fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30) with fire resisting doors (minimum E 30).

text: Every corridor serving bedrooms should be a protected corridor (see paragraph 2.24).
text-fixed: Every corridor serving bedrooms should be a protected corridor (see paragraph 2.24).

text: Bedrooms should not contain more than one single or double bed.
text-fixed: Bedrooms should not contain more than one single or double bed.

text: Ancillary accommodation such as all of the following should be enclosed by fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30).
text-fixed: Ancillary accommodation such as all of the following should be enclosed by fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30).

text: Staff changing and locker rooms.
text-fixed: Staff changing and locker rooms.

text: If doors fitted with a self-closing device could present an obstacle to residents, the following hardware in accordance with BS EN 1155 is appropriate.
text-fixed: If doors fitted with a self-closing device could present an obstacle to residents, the following hardware in accordance with BS EN 1155 is appropriate.

text: Bedrooms: free-swing door closers.
text-fixed: Bedrooms: free-swing door closers.

text: Circulation spaces: hold-open devices.
text-fixed: Circulation spaces: hold-open devices.

text: When a sprinkler system is provided in accordance with Appendix E, the following variations to the guidance given in paragraphs 2.35 to 2.45 are acceptable.
text-fixed: When a sprinkler system is provided in accordance with Appendix E, the following variations to the guidance given in paragraphs 2.35 to 2.45 are acceptable.

text: Fire doorsets to bedrooms do not need to be fitted with self-closing devices.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets to bedrooms do not need to be fitted with self-closing devices.

text: Protected areas may contain more than 10 beds.
text-fixed: Protected areas may contain more than 10 beds.

text: Bedrooms may contain more than one bed.
text-fixed: Bedrooms may contain more than one bed.

text: If any of the variations are made, the management procedures should take account of the larger number of residents that may need assistance, and the need to manually close bedroom doors during sleeping hours.
text-fixed: If any of the variations are made, the management procedures should take account of the larger number of residents that may need assistance, and the need to manually close bedroom doors during sleeping hours.

text: The limits on horizontal travel escape distances mean most people should be able to independently reach a protected escape route or final exit.
text-fixed: The limits on horizontal travel escape distances mean most people should be able to independently reach a protected escape route or final exit.

text: The following guidance also includes measures for people who are unable to use stairs without help.
text-fixed: The following guidance also includes measures for people who are unable to use stairs without help.

text: In larger buildings, some escape stairs may need to serve as firefighting stairs, and Section 17 will also apply.
text-fixed: In larger buildings, some escape stairs may need to serve as firefighting stairs, and Section 17 will also apply.

text: If a building contains storeys, or parts of storeys, in different purpose groups, it is necessary to consider providing either of the following.
text-fixed: If a building contains storeys, or parts of storeys, in different purpose groups, it is necessary to consider providing either of the following.

text: Separate escape routes from the areas of different use.

text: Other effective means to protect common escape routes.
text-fixed: Other effective means to protect common escape routes.

text: A single escape stair may serve a building (or part of a building) in the following situations.
text-fixed: A single escape stair may serve a building (or part of a building) in the following situations.

text: When independent escape routes from areas in different purpose groups are not necessary (see paragraph 3.2).

text: From a basement that is allowed to have a single escape route in accordance with paragraph 2.6b and Table 2.1.
text-fixed: From a basement that is allowed to have a single escape route in accordance with paragraph 2.6b and Table 2.1.

text: In small premises, provided it meets the conditions in paragraph 4.2.
text-fixed: In small premises, provided it meets the conditions in paragraph 4.2.

text: From a building that meets both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: From a building that meets both of the following conditions.

text: It has no storey with a floor level more than 11m above ground level.
text-fixed: It has no storey with a floor level more than 11m above ground level.

text: It is allowed to have only a single escape route in every storey in accordance with paragraph 2.6b and Table 2.1.
text-fixed: It is allowed to have only a single escape route in every storey in accordance with paragraph 2.6b and Table 2.1.

text: An office building with a maximum of five storeys above the ground storey where both of the following apply.
text-fixed: An office building with a maximum of five storeys above the ground storey where both of the following apply.

text: The travel distance from every point in each storey does not exceed the distances given in Table 2.1 for escape in one direction only.
text-fixed: The travel distance from every point in each storey does not exceed the distances given in Table 2.1 for escape in one direction only.

text: Every storey with a floor level more than 11m above ground level has an alternative means of escape.
text-fixed: Every storey with a floor level more than 11m above ground level has an alternative means of escape.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION f. A factory comprising no more than either of the following.
text-fixed: A factory comprising no more than either of the following.

text: For low risk buildings, two storeys above the ground storey.
text-fixed: For low risk buildings, two storeys above the ground storey.

text: For normal risk buildings, one storey above the ground storey, provided the travel distance from every point on each storey does not exceed the distances given in Table 2.1 for escape in one direction only.
text-fixed: For normal risk buildings, one storey above the ground storey, provided the travel distance from every point on each storey does not exceed the distances given in Table 2.1 for escape in one direction only.

text: Process plant buildings with a maximum of 10 people.
text-fixed: Process plant buildings with a maximum of 10 people.

text: Refuges form part of the management plan and offer relatively safe areas for people to wait for a short period only.
text-fixed: Refuges form part of the management plan and offer relatively safe areas for people to wait for a short period only.

text: Refuges should meet the following conditions.
text-fixed: Refuges should meet the following conditions.

text: Refuges should be provided on every storey (except ones consisting only of plant rooms) of each protected stairway providing an exit from that storey.
text-fixed: Refuges should be provided on every storey (except ones consisting only of plant rooms) of each protected stairway providing an exit from that storey.

text: Refuges do not need to be located within the stair enclosure, but should enable direct access to the stair.
text-fixed: Refuges do not need to be located within the stair enclosure, but should enable direct access to the stair.

text: The number of refuge spaces does not need to equal the number of wheelchair users who may be in the building.
text-fixed: The number of refuge spaces does not need to equal the number of wheelchair users who may be in the building.

text: A single refuge may be occupied by more than one person during the evacuation procedure.
text-fixed: A single refuge may be occupied by more than one person during the evacuation procedure.

text: The following are both examples of satisfactory refuges.
text-fixed: The following are both examples of satisfactory refuges.

text: An enclosure such as a compartment (Diagram 3.1), protected lobby, protected corridor or protected stairway (Diagram 3.2).
text-fixed: An enclosure such as a compartment (Diagram 3.1), protected lobby, protected corridor or protected stairway (Diagram 3.2).

text: An area in the open air, such as a flat roof, balcony, podium or similar place, that meets both of the following.
text-fixed: An area in the open air, such as a flat roof, balcony, podium or similar place, that meets both of the following.

text: It is protected (or remote) from any fire risk.
text-fixed: It is protected (or remote) from any fire risk.

text: It has its own means of escape.
text-fixed: It has its own means of escape.

text: Refuges should be a minimum of 900mm  1400mm in size and accessible by someone in a wheelchair.
text-fixed: Refuges should be a minimum of 900mm  1400mm in size and accessible by someone in a wheelchair.

text: Where sited in a protected stairway, protected lobby or protected corridor, they should not reduce the width of the escape route or obstruct the flow of people escaping.
text-fixed: Where sited in a protected stairway, protected lobby or protected corridor, they should not reduce the width of the escape route or obstruct the flow of people escaping.

text: Refuges should be provided with an emergency voice communication (EVC) system complying with BS 5839-9.
text-fixed: Refuges should be provided with an emergency voice communication (EVC) system complying with BS 5839-9.

text: It should consist of Type B outstations communicating with a master station in the building control room (if one exists) or next to the fire detection and alarm panel.
text-fixed: It should consist of Type B outstations communicating with a master station in the building control room (if one exists) or next to the fire detection and alarm panel.

text: In some buildings, wireless technology may be more appropriate.
text-fixed: In some buildings, wireless technology may be more appropriate.

text: Refuges and evacuation lifts should be clearly identified.
text-fixed: Refuges and evacuation lifts should be clearly identified.

text-fixed: In protected lobbies and protected stairways there should be a blue mandatory sign worded ‘Refuge – keep clear’ in addition to fire safety signs.

text: Paragraph 5.32 gives guidance on using lifts, including evacuation lifts, during a fire.
text-fixed: Paragraph 5.32 gives guidance on using lifts, including evacuation lifts, during a fire.

text: People occupying Compartment A would not reach an available refuge until they had entered Compartment B. Two ﬁre doorsets in the partition are necessary in case access to one of the doorsets is blocked by ﬁre.

Two fire doorsets in the partition are necessary in case access to one of the doorsets is blocked by fire.

text: Provision where access to the refuge is counter to the access ﬂow within the stairway.
text-fixed: Provision where access to the refuge is counter to the access ﬂow within the stairway.

text: The width of escape stairs should meet all of the following conditions.
text-fixed: The width of escape stairs should meet all of the following conditions.

text: It should be at least as wide as any exits giving access to the stairs.
text-fixed: It should be at least as wide as any exits giving access to the stairs.

text-fixed: Approved Document K requires stairs more than 2000mm wide in public buildings to have a central handrail.

text: If an exit route from a stair is also the escape route from the ground storey and/or basement storey, the width of the exit route may need to be increased (see paragraph 2.23).

text: Assessed as likely to use the stair in a fire emergency.

text: Section 6 of BS 9999 recommends that firefighting stairs should be at least 1100mm wide.

text-fixed: See Table 3.2 for the size of stairs for simultaneous evacuation, and Table 3.3 for phased evacuation.

text-fixed: If the maximum number of people needing to use escape stairs is unknown, calculate it using the floor space factors in Appendix D.

text: Escape stairs are protected by a smoke control system designed in accordance with BS EN 12101-6.

text: Phased evacuation cannot be used in every type of building, but can be advantageous for escape stairs in high buildings.
text-fixed: Phased evacuation cannot be used in every type of building, but can be advantageous for escape stairs in high buildings.

text: It requires supporting facilities, such as fire detection and alarm systems, to be provided and maintained.
text-fixed: It requires supporting facilities, such as fire detection and alarm systems, to be provided and maintained.

text: In a phased evacuation, the first people to be evacuated are those with reduced mobility and those on the storey most immediately affected by the fire.
text-fixed: In a phased evacuation, the first people to be evacuated are those with reduced mobility and those on the storey most immediately affected by the fire.

text: If needed, subsequent evacuation is done two floors at a time, reducing disruption in large buildings.
text-fixed: If needed, subsequent evacuation is done two floors at a time, reducing disruption in large buildings.

text: Phased evacuation enables stairs to be narrower than with simultaneous evacuation, and may be used for any building provided it is not identified in paragraph 3.16.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION 3.20 Phased evacuation in buildings with a storey over 30m in height introduces the potential for escaping people to impede firefighters entering and operating within the building.
text-fixed: Phased evacuation in buildings with a storey over 30m in height introduces the potential for escaping people to impede firefighters entering and operating within the building.

text: This can be addressed by consulting with the fire and rescue service about special management procedures.
text-fixed: This can be addressed by consulting with the fire and rescue service about special management procedures.

text: In very tall buildings, typically with a storey over 45m in height, physical measures may need to be incorporated, such as by discounting a stair.
text-fixed: In very tall buildings, typically with a storey over 45m in height, physical measures may need to be incorporated, such as by discounting a stair.

text: A building (or part of a building) designed for phased evacuation should satisfy all of the following criteria.
text-fixed: A building (or part of a building) designed for phased evacuation should satisfy all of the following criteria.

text: At each storey except a top storey, stairs should be approached through a protected lobby or protected corridor.

text: The building should be fitted with an appropriate fire warning system conforming to at least the L3 standard given in BS 5839-1.
text-fixed: The building should be fitted with an appropriate fire warning system conforming to at least the L3 standard given in BS 5839-1.

text: Every internal escape stair should be a protected stairway (within a fire resisting enclosure).

text-fixed: Fixed ladders 3.28 Fixed ladders should not be provided as a means of escape for members of the public.

text: They should only be provided where a conventional stair is impractical, such as for access to plant rooms which are not normally occupied.

text-fixed: Where a storey or part of the building has more than one escape route available, some of the escape routes may be via an external escape stair, provided the following conditions are met.

text: Every protected stairway should lead to a final exit, either directly or via an exit passageway.

text: A protected stairway may only include any of the following.
