text-fixed: Gas service and installation pipes and meters should not be within a protected stairway, unless installed in accordance with the Pipelines Safety Regulations 1996 and the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998.

text: An escape stair forming part of the only escape route from an upper storey should not continue down to serve a basement storey.
text-fixed: An escape stair forming part of the only escape route from an upper storey should not continue down to serve a basement storey.

text: The basement storey should be served by a separate escape stair.
text-fixed: The basement storey should be served by a separate escape stair.

text: Where multiple escape stairs serve the upper storeys, only one needs to end at ground level.
text-fixed: Where multiple escape stairs serve the upper storeys, only one needs to end at ground level.

text: Other stairs may connect with the basement storeys if there is a protected lobby or a protected corridor between the stairs and accommodation at each basement level.
text-fixed: Other stairs may connect with the basement storeys if there is a protected lobby or a protected corridor between the stairs and accommodation at each basement level.

text: A ‘small premises’ is generally limited both in its size and in its number of occupants.
text-fixed: A ‘small premises’ is generally limited both in its size and in its number of occupants.

text: When undivided, all of its parts are likely to be clearly visible to occupants.
text-fixed: When undivided, all of its parts are likely to be clearly visible to occupants.

text: Occupants of small premises will be able to reach an exit quickly in an emergency and therefore a reduction in the number of exits and stairs is acceptable.
text-fixed: Occupants of small premises will be able to reach an exit quickly in an emergency and therefore a reduction in the number of exits and stairs is acceptable.

text: This guidance is not applicable to small premises where highly flammable materials are sold, stored or used.
text-fixed: This guidance is not applicable to small premises where highly flammable materials are sold, stored or used.

text: Small premises should meet all of the following general conditions.
text-fixed: Small premises should meet all of the following general conditions.

text: It should be single occupancy.
text-fixed: It should be single occupancy.

text: It should not comprise more than a basement storey, ground storey and first storey.
text-fixed: It should not comprise more than a basement storey, ground storey and first storey.

text: No storey should have a floor area more than 280m2.
text-fixed: No storey should have a floor area more than 280m2.

text: Any kitchen or other open cooking arrangements should be at the extremity of any dead end remote from the exits.
text-fixed: Any kitchen or other open cooking arrangements should be at the extremity of any dead end remote from the exits.

text: For a bar or restaurant, the seating or standing accommodation (Table D1) should be planned for a maximum of 30 people per storey.
text-fixed: For a bar or restaurant, the seating or standing accommodation (Table D1) should be planned for a maximum of 30 people per storey.

text: The seating or standing accommodation for the ground storey may be planned for 100 people if it has a final exit independent of the stair.
text-fixed: The seating or standing accommodation for the ground storey may be planned for 100 people if it has a final exit independent of the stair.

text: The following paragraphs only apply in place of those provisions elsewhere in this Approved Document which relate to the following.
text-fixed: The following paragraphs only apply in place of those provisions elsewhere in this Approved Document which relate to the following.

text: The number and position of exits and protected stairways.
text-fixed: The number and position of exits and protected stairways.

text: Measuring distances of travel.
text-fixed: Measuring distances of travel.

text: Open escape stairs.
text-fixed: Open escape stairs.

text: For provisions other than those listed above, the guidance elsewhere in this Approved Document should be followed.
text-fixed: For provisions other than those listed above, the guidance elsewhere in this Approved Document should be followed.

text: Except in kitchens, ancillary offices and stores, floor areas should be undivided so exits are clearly visible from all parts.
text-fixed: Except in kitchens, ancillary offices and stores, floor areas should be undivided so exits are clearly visible from all parts.

text: Store rooms should be enclosed with fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30).
text-fixed: Store rooms should be enclosed with fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30).

text: Escape routes should be sited so that the travel distance from any point of a storey to the nearest storey exit does not exceed the distance given in Table 4.1 (see Diagrams 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3).
text-fixed: Escape routes should be sited so that the travel distance from any point of a storey to the nearest storey exit does not exceed the distance given in Table 4.1 (see Diagrams 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3).

text: The siting of two or more exits or stairs should give effective alternative directions of travel from any point in a storey.
text-fixed: The siting of two or more exits or stairs should give effective alternative directions of travel from any point in a storey.

text: If the internal layout of partitions, fittings, etc. is not known, direct distances, rather than travel distances, should be assessed.
text-fixed: If the internal layout of partitions, fittings, etc. is not known, direct distances, rather than travel distances, should be assessed.

text: The direct distance should be assumed to be two-thirds of the travel distance.
text-fixed: The direct distance should be assumed to be two-thirds of the travel distance.

text: The travel distance in small premises with an open stair is measured as follows.
text-fixed: The travel distance in small premises with an open stair is measured as follows.

text: In a basement: to the foot of the stair.
text-fixed: In a basement: to the foot of the stair.

text: On a first storey: to the head of the stair.
text-fixed: On a first storey: to the head of the stair.

text: Maximum floor area in any one storey 280m2.
text-fixed: Maximum floor area in any one storey 280m2.

text: Restricted accommodation if used as a restaurant or bar.
text-fixed: Restricted accommodation if used as a restaurant or bar.

text: Maximum floor area in any one storey 90m2.
text-fixed: Maximum floor area in any one storey 90m2.

text: The premises may not be used as a resturant or bar.
text-fixed: The premises may not be used as a resturant or bar.

text: Only acceptable in two storey premises (ﬁrst + ground storey or basement + ground storey).
text-fixed: Only acceptable in two storey premises (ﬁrst + ground storey or basement + ground storey).

text: Travel distances are set out in Table 4.1.
text-fixed: Travel distances are set out in Table 4.1.

text: Maximum floor area in any one storey 90m2.
text-fixed: Maximum floor area in any one storey 90m2.

text: Enclosed stair at ground storey level may be from either the basement or the ﬁrst storey.
text-fixed: Enclosed stair at ground storey level may be from either the basement or the ﬁrst storey.

text: The premises may not be used as a resturant or bar.
text-fixed: The premises may not be used as a resturant or bar.

text: Travel distances are set out in Table 4.1.
text-fixed: Travel distances are set out in Table 4.1.

text: A single escape stair may be used in small premises.
text-fixed: A single escape stair may be used in small premises.

text: An open stair may be used as a means of escape if all of the following apply.
text-fixed: An open stair may be used as a means of escape if all of the following apply.

text: The stair connects a maximum of two storeys.
text-fixed: The stair connects a maximum of two storeys.

text: The stair enters the ground storey a maximum of 3m from the final exit (see Diagrams 4.2 and 4.3).
text-fixed: The stair enters the ground storey a maximum of 3m from the final exit (see Diagrams 4.2 and 4.3).

text: The premises is not a bar or restaurant.
text-fixed: The premises is not a bar or restaurant.

text: Either of the following applies.
text-fixed: Either of the following applies.

text: The storey is also served by a protected stairway.
text-fixed: The storey is also served by a protected stairway.

text: The stair is a single stair and the floor area of any single storey is a maximum of 90m2.
text-fixed: The stair is a single stair and the floor area of any single storey is a maximum of 90m2.

text: Where the premises contains three storeys and a single open stair serves a top or bottom storey, the stair serving the other storey should be enclosed with fire resisting construction at the ground storey level and discharge to a final exit independent of the ground storey (see Diagram 4.3).
text-fixed: Where the premises contains three storeys and a single open stair serves a top or bottom storey, the stair serving the other storey should be enclosed with fire resisting construction at the ground storey level and discharge to a final exit independent of the ground storey (see Diagram 4.3).

text: This section applies to all buildings and deals with the design, construction and protection of escape routes and service installations.
text-fixed: This section applies to all buildings and deals with the design, construction and protection of escape routes and service installations.

text: Fire resistance test criteria are set out in Appendix B. Standards of performance are summarised in Tables B3 and B4.
text-fixed: Fire resistance test criteria are set out in Appendix B. Standards of performance are summarised in Tables B3 and B4.

text: Apart from specific situations described in Sections 1 and 2, and requirements B3 and B5, a minimum performance of REI 30 is sufficient to protect means of escape.
text-fixed: Apart from specific situations described in Sections 1 and 2, and requirements B3 and B5, a minimum performance of REI 30 is sufficient to protect means of escape.

text: Fire resistance test criteria are set out in Appendix C. Standards of performance are summarised in Table C1.
text-fixed: Fire resistance test criteria are set out in Appendix C. Standards of performance are summarised in Table C1.

text: If glazed elements in fire resisting enclosures and doors can only meet the required integrity performance, their use is limited.
text-fixed: If glazed elements in fire resisting enclosures and doors can only meet the required integrity performance, their use is limited.

text: These limitations depend on whether the enclosure forms part of a protected shaft (see Section 8) and the provisions set out in Appendix B, Table B5.
text-fixed: These limitations depend on whether the enclosure forms part of a protected shaft (see Section 8) and the provisions set out in Appendix B, Table B5.

text: If both integrity and insulation performance can be met, there is no restriction in this document on the use or amount of glass.
text-fixed: If both integrity and insulation performance can be met, there is no restriction in this document on the use or amount of glass.

text: Glazed elements should also comply with the following, where necessary.
text-fixed: Glazed elements should also comply with the following, where necessary.

text: If the enclosure forms part of a protected shaft: Section 8.
text-fixed: If the enclosure forms part of a protected shaft: Section 8.

text: Appendix B, Table B5.
text-fixed: Appendix B, Table B5.

text: Guidance on the safety of glazing: Approved Document K.
text-fixed: Guidance on the safety of glazing: Approved Document K.

text: Doors should be readily openable to avoid undue delay to people escaping.
text-fixed: Doors should be readily openable to avoid undue delay to people escaping.

text: Doors on escape routes (both within and from the building) should comply with paragraphs 5.7 to 5.15.
text-fixed: Doors on escape routes (both within and from the building) should comply with paragraphs 5.7 to 5.15.

text: Guidance on door closing and ‘hold open’ devices for fire doorsets is set out in Appendix C.
text-fixed: Guidance on door closing and ‘hold open’ devices for fire doorsets is set out in Appendix C.

text: In general, doors on escape routes (whether or not the doors are fire doorsets) should be either of the following.
text-fixed: In general, doors on escape routes (whether or not the doors are fire doorsets) should be either of the following.

text: Not fitted with a lock, latch or bolt fastenings.
text-fixed: Not fitted with a lock, latch or bolt fastenings.

text: Fitted only with simple fastenings that are all of the following.
text-fixed: Fitted only with simple fastenings that are all of the following.

text: Easy to operate; it should be apparent how to undo the fastening.
text-fixed: Easy to operate; it should be apparent how to undo the fastening.

text: Operable from the side approached by people escaping.
text-fixed: Operable from the side approached by people escaping.

text: Operable without a key.
text-fixed: Operable without a key.

text: Operable without requiring people to manipulate more than one mechanism.
text-fixed: Operable without requiring people to manipulate more than one mechanism.

text: Doors may be fitted with hardware to allow them to be locked when rooms are empty.
text-fixed: Doors may be fitted with hardware to allow them to be locked when rooms are empty.

text: In places such as hotel bedrooms, locks may be fitted that are key operated from the outside and manually opened from the inside.
text-fixed: In places such as hotel bedrooms, locks may be fitted that are key operated from the outside and manually opened from the inside.

text: If a secure door is operated by code or combination keypad, swipe or proximity card, biometric data, etc., a security mechanism override should be possible from the side approached by people escaping.
text-fixed: If a secure door is operated by code or combination keypad, swipe or proximity card, biometric data, etc., a security mechanism override should be possible from the side approached by people escaping.

text: Electrically powered locks should return to the unlocked position in all of the following situations.
text-fixed: Electrically powered locks should return to the unlocked position in all of the following situations.

text: If the fire detection and alarm system operates.
text-fixed: If the fire detection and alarm system operates.

text: If there is loss of power or system error.
text-fixed: If there is loss of power or system error.

text: If the security mechanism override is activated.
text-fixed: If the security mechanism override is activated.

text: Security mechanism overrides for electrically powered locks should be a Type A call point as described in BS 7273-4.
text-fixed: Security mechanism overrides for electrically powered locks should be a Type A call point as described in BS 7273-4.

text: The call point should be positioned on the side approached by people escaping.
text-fixed: The call point should be positioned on the side approached by people escaping.

text: If the door provides escape in either direction, a call point should be installed on both sides of the door.
text-fixed: If the door provides escape in either direction, a call point should be installed on both sides of the door.

text: In places of assembly and shop and commercial buildings (purpose groups 4 and 5), doors on escape routes from rooms with more than 60 people should be either of the following.
text-fixed: In places of assembly and shop and commercial buildings (purpose groups 4 and 5), doors on escape routes from rooms with more than 60 people should be either of the following.

text: Not fitted with locks, latches or bolts.
text-fixed: Not fitted with locks, latches or bolts.

text: Fitted with panic fastenings in accordance with BS EN 1125.
text-fixed: Fitted with panic fastenings in accordance with BS EN 1125.

text: In non-residential buildings (purpose groups 3 to 7), some final exit doors feature security locks that are used only when the building is empty.
text-fixed: In non-residential buildings (purpose groups 3 to 7), some final exit doors feature security locks that are used only when the building is empty.

text: Such locks may be appropriate, but management procedures must emphasise their safe use.
text-fixed: Such locks may be appropriate, but management procedures must emphasise their safe use.

text: Guidance on door closing and ‘hold open’ devices for fire doorsets is set out in Appendix C.
text-fixed: Guidance on door closing and ‘hold open’ devices for fire doorsets is set out in Appendix C.

text: The door of any doorway or exit should be hung to open in the direction of escape whenever reasonably practicable.
text-fixed: The door of any doorway or exit should be hung to open in the direction of escape whenever reasonably practicable.

text: It should always be hung to open in the direction of escape if either of the following conditions applies.
text-fixed: It should always be hung to open in the direction of escape if either of the following conditions applies.

text: More than 60 people might be expected to use it during a fire.
text-fixed: More than 60 people might be expected to use it during a fire.

text: There is a very high risk of fire with potential for rapid fire growth, such as with some industrial activities.
text-fixed: There is a very high risk of fire with potential for rapid fire growth, such as with some industrial activities.

text: All doors on escape routes should be hung to meet both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: All doors on escape routes should be hung to meet both of the following conditions.

text: Open by a minimum of 90 degrees.
text-fixed: Open by a minimum of 90 degrees.

text: Open with a swing that complies with both of the following.
text-fixed: Open with a swing that complies with both of the following.

text: Is clear of any change of floor level, other than a threshold or single step on the line of the doorway.
text-fixed: Is clear of any change of floor level, other than a threshold or single step on the line of the doorway.

text: Does not reduce the effective width of any escape route across a landing.
text-fixed: Does not reduce the effective width of any escape route across a landing.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION 5.13 Any door opening towards a corridor or a stair should be recessed to prevent its swing encroaching on the effective width.
text-fixed: Any door opening towards a corridor or a stair should be recessed to prevent its swing encroaching on the effective width.

text: Doors should contain vision panels in both of the following situations.
text-fixed: Doors should contain vision panels in both of the following situations.

text: Where doors on escape routes divide corridors.
text-fixed: Where doors on escape routes divide corridors.

text: Where doors are hung to swing both ways.
text-fixed: Where doors are hung to swing both ways.

text: Approved Document M contains guidance about vision panels in doors across accessible corridors and Approved Document K contains guidance about the safety of glazing.
text-fixed: Approved Document M contains guidance about vision panels in doors across accessible corridors and Approved Document K contains guidance about the safety of glazing.

text: Where revolving doors, automatic doors and turnstiles are placed across escape routes they should comply with one of the following.
text-fixed: Where revolving doors, automatic doors and turnstiles are placed across escape routes they should comply with one of the following.

text: They are automatic doors of the required width and comply with one of the following conditions.
text-fixed: They are automatic doors of the required width and comply with one of the following conditions.

text: Their failsafe system provides outward opening from any open position.
text-fixed: Their failsafe system provides outward opening from any open position.

text: They have a monitored failsafe system to open the doors if the mains electricity supply fails.
text-fixed: They have a monitored failsafe system to open the doors if the mains electricity supply fails.

text: They failsafe to the open position if the power fails.
text-fixed: They failsafe to the open position if the power fails.

text: #NAME?
text-fixed: Non-automatic swing doors of the required width are provided immediately adjacent to the revolving or automatic door or turnstile.

text: Escape routes should have a minimum clear headroom of 2m. The only projections allowed below this height are door frames.
text-fixed: Escape routes should have a minimum clear headroom of 2m. The only projections allowed below this height are door frames.

text: Escape route floor finishes should minimise their slipperiness when wet.
text-fixed: Escape route floor finishes should minimise their slipperiness when wet.

text: Finishes include the treads of steps and surfaces of ramps and landings.
text-fixed: Finishes include the treads of steps and surfaces of ramps and landings.

text: A ramp forming part of an escape route should meet the provisions in Approved Document M. Any sloping floor or tier should have a pitch of not more than 35 degrees to the horizontal.
text-fixed: A ramp forming part of an escape route should meet the provisions in Approved Document M. Any sloping floor or tier should have a pitch of not more than 35 degrees to the horizontal.

text: Guidance for where there is fixed seating is given in both of the following.
text-fixed: Guidance for where there is fixed seating is given in both of the following.

text: Approved Documents K and M give guidance on the design of ramps and associated landings, and on aisles and gangways where there is fixed seating.
text-fixed: Approved Documents K and M give guidance on the design of ramps and associated landings, and on aisles and gangways where there is fixed seating.

text: Section 2 of this document refers to Annex D of BS 9999, which gives guidance on the design of means of escape in places with fixed seating.
text-fixed: Section 2 of this document refers to Annex D of BS 9999, which gives guidance on the design of means of escape in places with fixed seating.

text: The width of a final exit should be at least the same as the minimum required width of the escape route it serves.
text-fixed: The width of a final exit should be at least the same as the minimum required width of the escape route it serves.

text: VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION 5.21 People should be able to rapidly leave the area around the building.
text-fixed: People should be able to rapidly leave the area around the building.

text: Direct access to a street, passageway, walkway or open space should be available.
text-fixed: Direct access to a street, passageway, walkway or open space should be available.

text: The route away from the building should comply with the following.
text-fixed: The route away from the building should comply with the following.

text: Be well defined.
text-fixed: Be well defined.

text: If necessary, have suitable guarding.
text-fixed: If necessary, have suitable guarding.

text: Final exits should not present a barrier for disabled people.
text-fixed: Final exits should not present a barrier for disabled people.

text: Where the route to a final exit does not include stairs, a level threshold and, where necessary, a ramp should be provided.
text-fixed: Where the route to a final exit does not include stairs, a level threshold and, where necessary, a ramp should be provided.

text: Final exit locations should be clearly visible and recognisable.
text-fixed: Final exit locations should be clearly visible and recognisable.

text: Final exits should avoid outlets of basement smoke vents and openings to transformer chambers, refuse chambers, boiler rooms and similar risks.
text-fixed: Final exits should avoid outlets of basement smoke vents and openings to transformer chambers, refuse chambers, boiler rooms and similar risks.

text: The exception is shops that meet all of the following:
text-fixed: The exception is shops that meet all of the following:

text: Including external escape routes.
text-fixed: Including external escape routes.

text: All escape routes should have adequate artificial lighting.
text-fixed: All escape routes should have adequate artificial lighting.

text: If the mains electricity power supply fails, escape lighting should illuminate the routes listed in Table 5.1.
text-fixed: If the mains electricity power supply fails, escape lighting should illuminate the routes listed in Table 5.1.

text: Escape stair lighting should be on a separate circuit from the electricity supply to any other part of the escape route.
text-fixed: Escape stair lighting should be on a separate circuit from the electricity supply to any other part of the escape route.

text: Escape lighting should conform to BS 5266-1.
text-fixed: Escape lighting should conform to BS 5266-1.

text: Every doorway or other exit providing access to a means of escape, other than exits in ordinary use (e.g. main entrances), should be distinctively and conspicuously marked by an exit sign in accordance with BS ISO 3864-1 and BS 5499-4.
text-fixed: Every doorway or other exit providing access to a means of escape, other than exits in ordinary use (e.g. main entrances), should be distinctively and conspicuously marked by an exit sign in accordance with BS ISO 3864-1 and BS 5499-4.

text: Advice on fire safety signs, including emergency escape signs, is given in the HSE publication Safety Signs and Signals: Guidance on Regulations.
text-fixed: Advice on fire safety signs, including emergency escape signs, is given in the HSE publication Safety Signs and Signals: Guidance on Regulations.

text: Some buildings may require additional signs to comply with other legislation.
text-fixed: Some buildings may require additional signs to comply with other legislation.

text: To limit potential damage to cables in protected circuits, all of the following should apply.
text-fixed: To limit potential damage to cables in protected circuits, all of the following should apply.

text: Cables should be sufficiently robust.
text-fixed: Cables should be sufficiently robust.

text: Cable routes should be carefully selected and/or physically protected in areas where cables may be exposed to damage.
text-fixed: Cable routes should be carefully selected and/or physically protected in areas where cables may be exposed to damage.

text: Methods of cable support should be class A1 rated and offer at least the same integrity as the cable.
text-fixed: Methods of cable support should be class A1 rated and offer at least the same integrity as the cable.

text: They should maintain circuit integrity and hold cables in place when exposed to fire.
text-fixed: They should maintain circuit integrity and hold cables in place when exposed to fire.

text: A protected circuit to operate equipment during a fire should achieve all of the following.
text-fixed: A protected circuit to operate equipment during a fire should achieve all of the following.

text: Cables should achieve PH 30 classification when tested in accordance with BS EN 50200 (incorporating Annex E) or an equivalent standard.
text-fixed: Cables should achieve PH 30 classification when tested in accordance with BS EN 50200 (incorporating Annex E) or an equivalent standard.

text: It should only pass through parts of the building in which the fire risk is negligible.
text-fixed: It should only pass through parts of the building in which the fire risk is negligible.

text: It should be separate from any circuit provided for another purpose.
text-fixed: It should be separate from any circuit provided for another purpose.

text: Guidance on cables for large and complex buildings is given in BS 5839-1, BS 5266-1 and BS 8519.
text-fixed: Guidance on cables for large and complex buildings is given in BS 5839-1, BS 5266-1 and BS 8519.

text: Generally, lifts should not be used when there is a fire in the building, unless their use forms part of a management plan for evacuating people and the following conditions are met.
text-fixed: Generally, lifts should not be used when there is a fire in the building, unless their use forms part of a management plan for evacuating people and the following conditions are met.

text: Lifts are appropriately sited and protected.
text-fixed: Lifts are appropriately sited and protected.

text: Lifts contain safety features to ensure they remain usable during a fire.
text-fixed: Lifts contain safety features to ensure they remain usable during a fire.

text: Guidance on the design and use of evacuation lifts is given in Annex G to BS 9999.
text-fixed: Guidance on the design and use of evacuation lifts is given in Annex G to BS 9999.

text: Where a firefighting lift is provided, it can be used to evacuate disabled people.
text-fixed: Where a firefighting lift is provided, it can be used to evacuate disabled people.

text: Management plans should describe how this would be managed, and what will happen when the fire and rescue service arrives.
text-fixed: Management plans should describe how this would be managed, and what will happen when the fire and rescue service arrives.

text: Lift wells should comply with one of the following conditions.
text-fixed: Lift wells should comply with one of the following conditions.

text: Be sited within the enclosures of a protected stairway.
text-fixed: Be sited within the enclosures of a protected stairway.

text: Be enclosed with fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30) when in a position that might prejudice the means of escape.
text-fixed: Be enclosed with fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30) when in a position that might prejudice the means of escape.

text: A lift well connecting different compartments should form a protected shaft (see Section 8).
text-fixed: A lift well connecting different compartments should form a protected shaft (see Section 8).

text: Lifts that rise within a large volume such as a mall or atrium and do not have a conventional well, such as wall-climber or feature lifts, may be at risk if they run through a smoke reservoir.
text-fixed: Lifts that rise within a large volume such as a mall or atrium and do not have a conventional well, such as wall-climber or feature lifts, may be at risk if they run through a smoke reservoir.

text: Care should be taken to maintain the integrity of the smoke reservoir and protect people in the lift.
text-fixed: Care should be taken to maintain the integrity of the smoke reservoir and protect people in the lift.

text: In buildings designed for phased evacuation or progressive horizontal evacuation, if the lift well is not within the enclosures of a protected stairway, its entrance should be separated at every storey by a protected lobby (minimum REI 30).
text-fixed: In buildings designed for phased evacuation or progressive horizontal evacuation, if the lift well is not within the enclosures of a protected stairway, its entrance should be separated at every storey by a protected lobby (minimum REI 30).

text: In basements and enclosed car parks, the lift should be within the enclosure of a protected stairway.
text-fixed: In basements and enclosed car parks, the lift should be within the enclosure of a protected stairway.

text: Otherwise, the lift should be approached only via a protected lobby or protected corridor (minimum REI 30).
text-fixed: Otherwise, the lift should be approached only via a protected lobby or protected corridor (minimum REI 30).

text: then the lift should be separated from the high fire risk area(s) by a protected lobby or protected corridor (minimum REI 30).
text-fixed: If a lift delivers into a protected corridor or protected lobby serving sleeping accommodation and also serves a storey containing a high fire risk (such as a kitchen, communal areas, stores, etc.) then the lift should be separated from the high fire risk area(s) by a protected lobby or protected corridor (minimum REI 30).

text: A lift shaft serving storeys above ground level should not serve any basement if either of the following applies.
text-fixed: A lift shaft serving storeys above ground level should not serve any basement if either of the following applies.

text: There is only one escape stair serving storeys above ground level and smoke from a basement fire would adversely affect escape routes in the upper storeys.
text-fixed: There is only one escape stair serving storeys above ground level and smoke from a basement fire would adversely affect escape routes in the upper storeys.

text: The lift shaft is within the enclosure to an escape stair that terminates at ground level.
text-fixed: The lift shaft is within the enclosure to an escape stair that terminates at ground level.

text: Lift machine rooms should be sited over the lift well where possible.
text-fixed: Lift machine rooms should be sited over the lift well where possible.

text: Where buildings or part of a building with only one stairway make this arrangement impractical, the lift machine room should be sited outside the protected stairway.
text-fixed: Where buildings or part of a building with only one stairway make this arrangement impractical, the lift machine room should be sited outside the protected stairway.

text: Refuse storage chambers, refuse chutes and refuse hoppers should be sited and constructed in accordance with BS 5906.
text-fixed: Refuse storage chambers, refuse chutes and refuse hoppers should be sited and constructed in accordance with BS 5906.

text: Refuse chutes and rooms for storing refuse should meet both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: Refuse chutes and rooms for storing refuse should meet both of the following conditions.

text: Be separated from other parts of the building by fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30 in buildings with a top storey up to 5m above ground level; otherwise REI 60).
text-fixed: Be separated from other parts of the building by fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30 in buildings with a top storey up to 5m above ground level; otherwise REI 60).

text: Not be situated within a protected stairway or protected lobby.
text-fixed: Not be situated within a protected stairway or protected lobby.

text: In ‘residential (other)’ (purpose group (2(b)) buildings, all floors should be compartment floors.

text: In buildings in a non-residential purpose group (purpose groups 3 to 7), the following should be compartment walls and compartment floors.
text-fixed: In buildings in a non-residential purpose group (purpose groups 3 to 7), the following should be compartment walls and compartment floors.

text: Every wall needed to divide the building to observe the compartment size limits in Table 8.1 (Diagram 8.1a).
text-fixed: Every wall needed to divide the building to observe the compartment size limits in Table 8.1 (Diagram 8.1a).

text: Every floor, if the building or separated part of the building (see paragraph 8.19) has a top storey that is more than 30m above ground level (Diagram 8.1b).
text-fixed: Every floor, if the building or separated part of the building (see paragraph 8.19) has a top storey that is more than 30m above ground level (Diagram 8.1b).

text: The floor of the ground storey, if the building has one or more basements (Diagram 8.1c), except in small premises (see paragraph 4.2).
text-fixed: The floor of the ground storey, if the building has one or more basements (Diagram 8.1c), except in small premises (see paragraph 4.2).

text: The floor of every basement storey (except the lowest floor), if the building or separated part has a basement more than 10m below ground level (Diagram 8.1d).
text-fixed: The floor of every basement storey (except the lowest floor), if the building or separated part has a basement more than 10m below ground level (Diagram 8.1d).

text: If the building comprises ‘shop and commercial’, ‘industrial’ or ‘storage’ premises (purpose groups 4, 6, 7): every wall or floor dividing a building into separate occupancies (spaces used by different organisations, whether they fall within the same purpose group or not).
text-fixed: If the building comprises ‘shop and commercial’, ‘industrial’ or ‘storage’ premises (purpose groups 4, 6, 7): every wall or floor dividing a building into separate occupancies (spaces used by different organisations, whether they fall within the same purpose group or not).

text: See also the provision in paragraph 5.46 for store rooms in shops to be separated from retail areas by fire resisting construction (minimum REI 30).

text: In two storey ‘shop and commercial’ or ‘industrial’ buildings (purpose groups 4 or 6), where the use of the upper storey is ancillary to the use of the ground storey, the ground storey may be treated as a single storey building for fire compartmentation purposes where all of the following apply.

text: The area of the upper storey does not exceed the lower of:
text-fixed: The area of the upper storey does not exceed the lower of:

text: The upper storey is compartmented from the lower one.
text-fixed: The upper storey is compartmented from the lower one.

text: The upper storey has a means of escape independent of the lower storey escape routes.
text-fixed: The upper storey has a means of escape independent of the lower storey escape routes.

text: Every place of special fire hazard (see Appendix E) should be enclosed with fire resisting construction.
text-fixed: Every place of special fire hazard (see Appendix E) should be enclosed with fire resisting construction.

text: Detailed advice on atria in buildings is given in Annexes B and C of BS 9999.
text-fixed: Detailed advice on atria in buildings is given in Annexes B and C of BS 9999.

text-fixed: ‘With sprinkler system’ means that the building is fitted throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Appendix E.

text: Compartment height is measured from finished floor level to the underside of the roof or ceiling.
text-fixed: Compartment height is measured from finished floor level to the underside of the roof or ceiling.

text: Buildings within the ‘office’, ‘shop and commercial’, ‘assembly and recreation’, ‘industrial’ and ‘storage and other non-residential’ (except car parks for light vehicles) purpose groups (purpose groups 3 to 7(a)) require sprinklers where there is a top storey above 30m. The sprinkler system should be provided in accordance with Appendix E.

The sprinkler system should be provided in accordance with Appendix E.

text: All compartment walls and compartment floors should achieve both of the following.
text-fixed: All compartment walls and compartment floors should achieve both of the following.

text: Form a complete barrier to fire between the compartments they separate.
text-fixed: Form a complete barrier to fire between the compartments they separate.

text: Have the appropriate fire resistance, as given in Appendix B, Tables B3 and B4.
text-fixed: Have the appropriate fire resistance, as given in Appendix B, Tables B3 and B4.

text: Timber beams, joists, purlins and rafters may be built into or carried through a masonry or concrete compartment wall if the openings for them are both of the following.
text-fixed: Timber beams, joists, purlins and rafters may be built into or carried through a masonry or concrete compartment wall if the openings for them are both of the following.

text: As small as practicable.
text-fixed: As small as practicable.

text: If trussed rafters bridge the wall, failure of the truss due to a fire in one compartment should not cause failure of the truss in another compartment.
text-fixed: If trussed rafters bridge the wall, failure of the truss due to a fire in one compartment should not cause failure of the truss in another compartment.

text: Where services could provide a source of ignition, the risk of fire developing and spreading into adjacent compartments should be controlled.
text-fixed: Where services could provide a source of ignition, the risk of fire developing and spreading into adjacent compartments should be controlled.

text: Adjoining buildings should only be separated by walls, not floors.
text-fixed: Adjoining buildings should only be separated by walls, not floors.

text: Compartment walls common to two or more buildings should comply with both of the following.
text-fixed: Compartment walls common to two or more buildings should comply with both of the following.

text: Run the full height of the building in a continuous vertical plane.
text-fixed: Run the full height of the building in a continuous vertical plane.

text: Be continued through any roof space to the underside of the roof.
text-fixed: Be continued through any roof space to the underside of the roof.

text: Compartment walls forming a separated part of a building should run the full height of the building in a continuous vertical plane.
text-fixed: Compartment walls forming a separated part of a building should run the full height of the building in a continuous vertical plane.

text: Separated parts can be assessed independently to determine the appropriate standard of fire resistance in each.
text-fixed: Separated parts can be assessed independently to determine the appropriate standard of fire resistance in each.

text: The two separated parts can have different standards of fire resistance.
text-fixed: The two separated parts can have different standards of fire resistance.

text: Compartment walls not described in paragraphs 8.18 and 8.19 should run the full height of the storey in which they are situated.
text-fixed: Compartment walls not described in paragraphs 8.18 and 8.19 should run the full height of the storey in which they are situated.

text: Compartment walls in a top storey beneath a roof should be continued through the roof space.
text-fixed: Compartment walls in a top storey beneath a roof should be continued through the roof space.

text: At the junction with another compartment wall or an external wall, the fire resistance of the compartmentation should be maintained.
text-fixed: At the junction with another compartment wall or an external wall, the fire resistance of the compartmentation should be maintained.

text: Fire-stopping that meets the provisions in paragraphs 10.24 to 10.29 should be provided.
text-fixed: Fire-stopping that meets the provisions in paragraphs 10.24 to 10.29 should be provided.

text: At the junction of a compartment floor and an external wall with no fire resistance, the external wall should be restrained at floor level.
text-fixed: At the junction of a compartment floor and an external wall with no fire resistance, the external wall should be restrained at floor level.

text: The restraint should reduce movement of the wall away from the floor if exposed to fire.
text-fixed: The restraint should reduce movement of the wall away from the floor if exposed to fire.

text: Compartment walls should be able to accommodate deflection of the floor, when exposed to fire, by either of the following means.
text-fixed: Compartment walls should be able to accommodate deflection of the floor, when exposed to fire, by either of the following means.

text: Between the wall and floor, provide a head detail that is capable of maintaining its integrity while deforming.
text-fixed: Between the wall and floor, provide a head detail that is capable of maintaining its integrity while deforming.

text: Design the wall so it maintains its integrity by resisting the additional vertical load from the floor above.
text-fixed: Design the wall so it maintains its integrity by resisting the additional vertical load from the floor above.

text: Where compartment walls are located within the middle half of a floor between vertical supports, the deflection may be assumed to be 40mm unless a smaller value can be justified by assessment.
text-fixed: Where compartment walls are located within the middle half of a floor between vertical supports, the deflection may be assumed to be 40mm unless a smaller value can be justified by assessment.

text: Outside this area, the limit can be reduced linearly to zero at the supports.
text-fixed: Outside this area, the limit can be reduced linearly to zero at the supports.

text: For steel beams that do not have the required fire resistance, reference should be made to SCI Publication P288.
text-fixed: For steel beams that do not have the required fire resistance, reference should be made to SCI Publication P288.

text: A compartment wall should achieve both of the following.
text-fixed: A compartment wall should achieve both of the following.

text: Meet the underside of the roof covering or deck, with fire-stopping to maintain the continuity of fire resistance.
text-fixed: Meet the underside of the roof covering or deck, with fire-stopping to maintain the continuity of fire resistance.

text: Be continued across any eaves.
text-fixed: Be continued across any eaves.

text: To reduce the risk of fire spreading over the roof from one compartment to another, a 1500mm wide zone of the roof, either side of the wall, should have a covering classified as BROOF(t4), on a substrate or deck of a material rated class A2-s3, d2 or better, as set out in Diagram 8.2a.
text-fixed: To reduce the risk of fire spreading over the roof from one compartment to another, a 1500mm wide zone of the roof, either side of the wall, should have a covering classified as BROOF(t4), on a substrate or deck of a material rated class A2-s3, d2 or better, as set out in Diagram 8.2a.

text: Thermoplastic rooflights that, because of paragraph 14.7, are regarded as having a BROOF(t4) classification are not suitable for use in that zone.
text-fixed: Thermoplastic rooflights that, because of paragraph 14.7, are regarded as having a BROOF(t4) classification are not suitable for use in that zone.

text: Materials achieving class B-s3, d2 or worse used as a substrate to the roof covering and any timber tiling battens, fully bedded in mortar or other suitable material for the width of the wall (Diagram 8.2b), may extend over the compartment wall in buildings that are both of the following.

text: A maximum of 15m high.
text-fixed: A maximum of 15m high.

text: In one of the following purpose groups.
text-fixed: In one of the following purpose groups.

text: All residential purpose groups (purpose groups 1 and 2) other than ‘residential (institutional)’ (purpose group 2(a)).
text-fixed: All residential purpose groups (purpose groups 1 and 2) other than ‘residential (institutional)’ (purpose group 2(a)).

text: ‘Office’ (purpose group 3).
text-fixed: ‘Office’ (purpose group 3).

text: ‘Assembly and recreation’ (purpose group 5).
text-fixed: ‘Assembly and recreation’ (purpose group 5).

text: Double-skinned insulated roof sheeting should incorporate a band of material rated class A2-s3, d2 or better, a minimum of 300mm in width, centred over the wall.
text-fixed: Double-skinned insulated roof sheeting should incorporate a band of material rated class A2-s3, d2 or better, a minimum of 300mm in width, centred over the wall.

text: As an alternative to the provisions of paragraph 8.26 or 8.27, the compartment wall may extend through the roof for a minimum of either of the following (see Diagram 8.2c).
text-fixed: As an alternative to the provisions of paragraph 8.26 or 8.27, the compartment wall may extend through the roof for a minimum of either of the following (see Diagram 8.2c).

text: Where the height difference between the two roofs is less than 375mm, 375mm above the top surface of the adjoining roof covering.
text-fixed: Where the height difference between the two roofs is less than 375mm, 375mm above the top surface of the adjoining roof covering.

text: 200mm above the top surface of the adjoining roof covering where either of the following applies.
text-fixed: 200mm above the top surface of the adjoining roof covering where either of the following applies.

text: The height difference between the two roofs is 375mm or more.
text-fixed: The height difference between the two roofs is 375mm or more.

text: The roof coverings either side of the wall are of a material classified as BROOF(t4).
text-fixed: The roof coverings either side of the wall are of a material classified as BROOF(t4).

text: Roof covering over this distance to be designated BROOF(t4) rated on deck of material of class A2-s3, d2 or better.
text-fixed: Roof covering over this distance to be designated BROOF(t4) rated on deck of material of class A2-s3, d2 or better.

text: Roof covering and deck could be composite structure, e.g. proﬁled steel cladding.
text-fixed: Roof covering and deck could be composite structure, e.g. proﬁled steel cladding.

text: Double-skinned insulated roof sheeting should incorporate a band of material rated class A2-s3, d2 or better, a minimum of 300mm in width, centred over the wall.
text-fixed: Double-skinned insulated roof sheeting should incorporate a band of material rated class A2-s3, d2 or better, a minimum of 300mm in width, centred over the wall.

text: If roof support members pass through the wall, ﬁre protection to these members for a distance of 1500mm on either side of the wall may be needed to delay distortion at the junction (see paragraph 8.16).
text-fixed: If roof support members pass through the wall, fire protection to these members for a distance of 1500mm on either side of the wall may be needed to delay distortion at the junction (see paragraph 8.16).

text: Fire-stopping to be carried up to underside of roof covering, e.g. roof tiles.
text-fixed: Fire-stopping to be carried up to underside of roof covering, e.g. roof tiles.

text: Roof covering to be designated BROOF(t4) rated for at least this distance.
text-fixed: Roof covering to be designated BROOF(t4) rated for at least this distance.

text: Boarding (used as a substrate) or timber tiling battens may be carried over the wall provided that they are fully bedded in mortar (or other no less suitable material) where over the wall.
text-fixed: Boarding (used as a substrate) or timber tiling battens may be carried over the wall provided that they are fully bedded in mortar (or other no less suitable material) where over the wall.

text: Thermoplastic insulation materials should not be carried over the wall.
text-fixed: Thermoplastic insulation materials should not be carried over the wall.

text: Double-skinned insulated roof sheeting with a thermoplastic core should incorporate a band of material of class A2-s3, d2 at least 300mm wide centred over the wall.
text-fixed: Double-skinned insulated roof sheeting with a thermoplastic core should incorporate a band of material of class A2-s3, d2 at least 300mm wide centred over the wall.

text: Sarking felt may also be carried over the wall.
text-fixed: Sarking felt may also be carried over the wall.

text: If roof support members pass through the wall, ﬁre protection to these members for a distance of 1500mm on either side of the wall may be needed to delay distortion at the junction (see paragraph 8.16).
text-fixed: If roof support members pass through the wall, fire protection to these members for a distance of 1500mm on either side of the wall may be needed to delay distortion at the junction (see paragraph 8.16).

text-fixed: Fire-stopping to be carried up to underside of roof covering, boarding or slab.

text: Roof covering to be designated BROOF(t4) rated for at least 1500mm either side of wall.
text-fixed: Roof covering to be designated BROOF(t4) rated for at least 1500mm either side of wall.

text: The compartment wall does not necessarily need to be constructed of masonry.
text-fixed: The compartment wall does not necessarily need to be constructed of masonry.

text-fixed: Any stair or other shaft passing directly from one compartment to another should be enclosed in a protected shaft.

text-fixed: Protected shafts should be used for the following only, but may also include sanitary accommodation and washrooms.

text: Stairs that are also firefighting stairs: Section 17.
text-fixed: Stairs that are also firefighting stairs: Section 17.

text-fixed: The construction enclosing a protected shaft (Diagram 8.3) should do all of the following.

text: Form a complete barrier to fire between the compartments connected by the shaft.
text-fixed: Form a complete barrier to fire between the compartments connected by the shaft.

text: Have the appropriate fire resistance given in Appendix B, Table B3, except for uninsulated glazed screens that meet the provisions of paragraph 8.34.
text-fixed: Have the appropriate fire resistance given in Appendix B, Table B3, except for uninsulated glazed screens that meet the provisions of paragraph 8.34.

text: Satisfy the provisions for ventilation and the treatment of openings in paragraphs 8.38 and 8.39.

text: of protected shafts.

text: The shaft structure (including any openings) should meet the relevant provisions for both of the following:
text-fixed: The shaft structure (including any openings) should meet the relevant provisions for both of the following:

text: The lobby or corridor is enclosed with fire resisting construction achieving a minimum rating of REI 30.

text: Cavities in the construction of a building provide a ready route for the spread of smoke and flame, which can present a greater danger as any spread is concealed.
text-fixed: Cavities in the construction of a building provide a ready route for the spread of smoke and flame, which can present a greater danger as any spread is concealed.

text: For the purpose of this document, a cavity is considered to be any concealed space.
text-fixed: For the purpose of this document, a cavity is considered to be any concealed space.

text: To reduce the potential for fire spread, cavity barriers should be provided for both of the following.
text-fixed: To reduce the potential for fire spread, cavity barriers should be provided for both of the following.

text: To divide cavities.
text-fixed: To divide cavities.

text: To close the edges of cavities.
text-fixed: To close the edges of cavities.

text: Cavity barriers should not be confused with fire-stopping details (Section 10).
text-fixed: Cavity barriers should not be confused with fire-stopping details (Section 10).

text: Cavity barriers should be provided at all of the following locations.
text-fixed: Cavity barriers should be provided at all of the following locations.

text: At the edges of cavities, including around openings (such as windows, doors and exit/entry points for services).
text-fixed: At the edges of cavities, including around openings (such as windows, doors and exit/entry points for services).

text: At the junction between an external cavity wall and every compartment floor and compartment wall.
text-fixed: At the junction between an external cavity wall and every compartment floor and compartment wall.

text: At the junction between an internal cavity wall and every compartment floor, compartment wall or other wall or door assembly forming a fire resisting barrier.
text-fixed: At the junction between an internal cavity wall and every compartment floor, compartment wall or other wall or door assembly forming a fire resisting barrier.

text: This does not apply where a wall meets the conditions of Diagram 9.2.
text-fixed: This does not apply where a wall meets the conditions of Diagram 9.2.

text: It is not appropriate to complete a line of compartment walls by fitting cavity barriers above them.
text-fixed: It is not appropriate to complete a line of compartment walls by fitting cavity barriers above them.

text: The compartment wall should extend to the underside of the floor or roof above.
text-fixed: The compartment wall should extend to the underside of the floor or roof above.

text: If the fire resisting construction of a protected escape route is either of the following.
text-fixed: If the fire resisting construction of a protected escape route is either of the following.

text: Not carried to full storey height.
text-fixed: Not carried to full storey height.

text: At the top storey, not carried to the underside of the roof covering.
text-fixed: At the top storey, not carried to the underside of the roof covering.

text: Then the cavity above or below the fire resisting construction should be either of the following.
text-fixed: Then the cavity above or below the fire resisting construction should be either of the following.

text: Fitted with cavity barriers on the line of the enclosure.
text-fixed: Fitted with cavity barriers on the line of the enclosure.

text: For cavities above the fire resisting construction, enclosed on the lower side by a fire resisting ceiling (minimum EI 30) that extends throughout the building, compartment or separated part (see Diagram 9.3).
text-fixed: For cavities above the fire resisting construction, enclosed on the lower side by a fire resisting ceiling (minimum EI 30) that extends throughout the building, compartment or separated part (see Diagram 9.3).

text: In divided corridors, cavity barriers may be needed to prevent alternative escape routes being affected by fire and/or smoke (see paragraph 2.27 and Diagram 2.9).
text-fixed: In divided corridors, cavity barriers may be needed to prevent alternative escape routes being affected by fire and/or smoke (see paragraph 2.27 and Diagram 2.9).

text: Where a cavity exists above or below a partition between bedrooms because the enclosure is not carried to full storey height or to the underside of the roof covering, the guidance in paragraph 9.5 should be followed.

text-fixed: Cavity barriers are not required between double-skinned corrugated or profiled insulated roof sheeting if the sheeting complies with all of the following.

text: The sheeting is rated class A2-s3, d2 or better.

text-fixed: The ceiling should meet all of the following conditions.

text: Provide a minimum ﬁre resistance of EI 30.

text: where such roofs pass over the top of a compartment wall.

text: Cavity barriers should be used to divide any cavity (including roof spaces).

text-fixed: Table 9.1 sets out maximum dimensions for undivided cavities.

text-fixed: A cavity in a wall that meets the conditions of Diagram 9.2.

text-fixed: A floor or roof cavity above a fire resisting ceiling (Diagram 9.3) that extends throughout the building or compartment to a maximum of 30m.

text-fixed: In a building not put to residential or institutional use, a cavity that does not contain materials achieving class B-s3, d2 or worse and is formed either:

text: by overcladding an existing masonry (or concrete) external wall or an existing concrete roof.
text-fixed: by overcladding an existing masonry (or concrete) external wall or an existing concrete roof.

text: A cavity that meets the conditions of paragraph 9.8.

text: A cavity below a floor next to the ground or next to oversite concrete, if either:

text: the cavity is not normally accessible by people, unless there are openings in the floor such that it is possible for materials to accumulate in the cavity (in which case cavity barriers should be provided and access should be provided to the cavity for cleaning).
text-fixed: the cavity is not normally accessible by people, unless there are openings in the floor such that it is possible for materials to accumulate in the cavity (in which case cavity barriers should be provided and access should be provided to the cavity for cleaning).

text: If a single room with a ceiling cavity or underfloor cavity exceeds the dimensions in Table 9.1, cavity barriers need only be provided on the line of the enclosing walls/partitions of that room, if both of the following apply.
text-fixed: If a single room with a ceiling cavity or underfloor cavity exceeds the dimensions in Table 9.1, cavity barriers need only be provided on the line of the enclosing walls/partitions of that room, if both of the following apply.

text: The cavity barriers are a maximum of 40m apart.
text-fixed: The cavity barriers are a maximum of 40m apart.

text: The surface of the material/product exposed in the cavity is class C-s3, d2 or better.
text-fixed: The surface of the material/product exposed in the cavity is class C-s3, d2 or better.

text: If the cavity is over an undivided area that exceeds 40m in any direction, there is no limit to its size if all of the following conditions are met.
text-fixed: If the cavity is over an undivided area that exceeds 40m in any direction, there is no limit to its size if all of the following conditions are met.

text: Together, the room and cavity form a compartment separated from the rest of the building.
text-fixed: Together, the room and cavity form a compartment separated from the rest of the building.

text: Both of the following apply.
text-fixed: Both of the following apply.

text: The building is fitted with an automatic fire detection and alarm system that conforms to BS 5839-1.
text-fixed: The building is fitted with an automatic fire detection and alarm system that conforms to BS 5839-1.

text: Detectors are only required in the cavity to satisfy BS 5839-1.
text-fixed: Detectors are only required in the cavity to satisfy BS 5839-1.

text: If the cavity is used as a plenum then the recommendations for recirculating air distribution systems in Section 32 of BS 9999 are followed.
text-fixed: If the cavity is used as a plenum then the recommendations for recirculating air distribution systems in Section 32 of BS 9999 are followed.

text: Both of the following apply.
text-fixed: Both of the following apply.

text: The exposed surface of the material/product used in the construction of the cavity is class B-s3, d2 or better.
text-fixed: The exposed surface of the material/product used in the construction of the cavity is class B-s3, d2 or better.

text: The supports and fixings in the cavity are class A1.
text-fixed: The supports and fixings in the cavity are class A1.

text: Any pipe insulation system should achieve class C-s3, d2 rating or better.
text-fixed: Any pipe insulation system should achieve class C-s3, d2 rating or better.

text-fixed: Any electrical wiring in the cavity is laid in metal trays or metal conduit.

text: Other than those in (d)–(f), any materials are class A2-s3, d2 rated or better.
text-fixed: Other than those in (d)–(f), any materials are class A2-s3, d2 rated or better.

text: minutes’ insulation (I 15).
text-fixed: 15 minutes’ insulation (I 15).

text: They may be formed by a construction provided for another purpose if it achieves the same performance.

text: Cavity barriers in a stud wall or partition, or provided around openings, may be formed of any of the following.
text-fixed: Cavity barriers in a stud wall or partition, or provided around openings, may be formed of any of the following.

text: Steel, a minimum of 0.5mm thick.

text: Timber, a minimum of 38mm thick.
text-fixed: Timber, a minimum of 38mm thick.

text: Polythene-sleeved mineral wool, or mineral wool slab, under compression when installed in the cavity.
text-fixed: Polythene-sleeved mineral wool, or mineral wool slab, under compression when installed in the cavity.

text: B3ONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION d. Calcium silicate, cement-based or gypsum-based boards, a minimum of 12mm thick.
text-fixed: Calcium silicate, cement-based or gypsum-based boards, a minimum of 12mm thick.

text: These do not necessarily achieve the performance specified in paragraph 9.13.
text-fixed: These do not necessarily achieve the performance specified in paragraph 9.13.

text: Cavity barriers provided around openings may be formed by the window or door frame if the frame is constructed of steel or timber of the minimum thickness in (a) or (b), as appropriate.
text-fixed: Cavity barriers provided around openings may be formed by the window or door frame if the frame is constructed of steel or timber of the minimum thickness in (a) or (b), as appropriate.

text: Cavity barriers should be tightly fitted to a rigid construction and mechanically fixed in position.
text-fixed: Cavity barriers should be tightly fitted to a rigid construction and mechanically fixed in position.

text: If this is not possible (e.g. where a cavity barrier joins to slates, tiles, corrugated sheeting or similar materials) the junction should be fire-stopped.
text-fixed: If this is not possible (e.g. where a cavity barrier joins to slates, tiles, corrugated sheeting or similar materials) the junction should be fire-stopped.

text: Cavity barriers should be fixed so their performance is unlikely to be made ineffective by any of the following.
text-fixed: Cavity barriers should be fixed so their performance is unlikely to be made ineffective by any of the following.

text: Movement of the building due to subsidence, shrinkage or temperature change, and movement of the external envelope due to wind.
text-fixed: Movement of the building due to subsidence, shrinkage or temperature change, and movement of the external envelope due to wind.

text: During a fire, collapse of services penetrating the cavity barriers, either by the failure of the supporting system or through degradation of the service itself (e.g. by melting or burning).
text-fixed: During a fire, collapse of services penetrating the cavity barriers, either by the failure of the supporting system or through degradation of the service itself (e.g. by melting or burning).

text: During a fire, failure of the cavity barrier fixings.
text-fixed: During a fire, failure of the cavity barrier fixings.

text: During a fire, failure of any material or construction to which cavity barriers abut.
text-fixed: During a fire, failure of any material or construction to which cavity barriers abut.

text: Openings should be limited to the following.
text-fixed: Openings should be limited to the following.

text: Fire doorsets with a minimum rating of E 30, fitted in accordance with Appendix C.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets with a minimum rating of E 30, fitted in accordance with Appendix C.

text: The passage of pipes that follow the provisions in Section 10.
text-fixed: The passage of pipes that follow the provisions in Section 10.

text: The passage of cables or conduits containing one or more cables.
text-fixed: The passage of cables or conduits containing one or more cables.

text: Openings fitted with a suitably mounted and appropriate fire damper.
text-fixed: Openings fitted with a suitably mounted and appropriate fire damper.

text: Ducts that are either of the following.
text-fixed: Ducts that are either of the following.

text: Fire resisting (minimum E 30).
text-fixed: Fire resisting (minimum E 30).

text: Fitted with a suitably mounted and appropriate fire damper where they pass through the cavity barrier.
text-fixed: Fitted with a suitably mounted and appropriate fire damper where they pass through the cavity barrier.

text: If a cavity barrier is provided above or below a partition between bedrooms in ‘residential (institutional)’ and ‘residential (other)’ (purpose groups 2(a) and 2(b)) buildings, and the partition is not a fire resisting partition, then paragraph 9.17 does not apply.
text-fixed: If a cavity barrier is provided above or below a partition between bedrooms in ‘residential (institutional)’ and ‘residential (other)’ (purpose groups 2(a) and 2(b)) buildings, and the partition is not a fire resisting partition, then paragraph 9.17 does not apply.

text: However, both of the following apply.
text-fixed: However, both of the following apply.

text: The number of openings in the barrier should be kept to a minimum.
text-fixed: The number of openings in the barrier should be kept to a minimum.

text: Any penetrations should be sealed to restrict the passage of smoke with an appropriate fire-stopping material.
text-fixed: Any penetrations should be sealed to restrict the passage of smoke with an appropriate fire-stopping material.

text: For further guidance on openings in cavity barriers see Section 10.
text-fixed: For further guidance on openings in cavity barriers see Section 10.

text: Every joint, imperfect fit and opening for services through a fire-separating element should be sealed with fire-stopping to ensure the fire resistance of the element is not impaired.
text-fixed: Every joint, imperfect fit and opening for services through a fire-separating element should be sealed with fire-stopping to ensure the fire resistance of the element is not impaired.

text: Fire-stopping delays the spread of fire and, generally, the spread of smoke as well.
text-fixed: Fire-stopping delays the spread of fire and, generally, the spread of smoke as well.

text: Pipes passing through a fire-separating element, unless in a protected shaft, should comply with one of the alternatives A, B or C below.
text-fixed: Pipes passing through a fire-separating element, unless in a protected shaft, should comply with one of the alternatives A, B or C below.

text: Provide a proprietary, tested sealing system that will maintain the fire resistance of the wall, floor or cavity barrier.
text-fixed: Provide a proprietary, tested sealing system that will maintain the fire resistance of the wall, floor or cavity barrier.

text: Where a proprietary sealing system is not used, fire-stop around the pipe, keeping the opening for the pipe as small as possible.
text-fixed: Where a proprietary sealing system is not used, fire-stop around the pipe, keeping the opening for the pipe as small as possible.

text: The nominal internal diameter of the pipe should not exceed the relevant dimension given in Table 10.1.
text-fixed: The nominal internal diameter of the pipe should not exceed the relevant dimension given in Table 10.1.

text: A pipe with a maximum nominal internal diameter of 160mm may be used with a sleeve made out of a high melting point metal, as shown in Diagram 10.1, if the pipe is made of one of the following.
text-fixed: A pipe with a maximum nominal internal diameter of 160mm may be used with a sleeve made out of a high melting point metal, as shown in Diagram 10.1, if the pipe is made of one of the following.

text: uPVC (pipes should also comply with either BS 4514 or BS 5255).
text-fixed: uPVC (pipes should also comply with either BS 4514 or BS 5255).

text: A high melting point metal means any metal (such as cast iron, copper or steel) which, if exposed to a temperature of 800°C, will not soften or fracture to the extent that flame or hot gas will pass through the wall of the pipe.
text-fixed: A high melting point metal means any metal (such as cast iron, copper or steel) which, if exposed to a temperature of 800°C, will not soften or fracture to the extent that flame or hot gas will pass through the wall of the pipe.

text: between pipe and ﬁre-separating element.
text-fixed: Make the opening in the fire-separating element as small as possible and provide fire-stopping between pipe and fire-separating element.

text: See Table 10.1 for materials speciﬁcation.
text-fixed: See Table 10.1 for materials speciﬁcation.

text: The sleeve should be class A1 rated.
text-fixed: The sleeve should be class A1 rated.

text: Any metal (such as cast iron, copper or steel) which, if exposed to a temperature of 800°C, will not soften or fracture to the extent that flame or hot gas will pass through the wall of the pipe.
text-fixed: Any metal (such as cast iron, copper or steel) which, if exposed to a temperature of 800°C, will not soften or fracture to the extent that flame or hot gas will pass through the wall of the pipe.

text: uPVC pipes that comply with either BS 4514 or BS 5255.
text-fixed: uPVC pipes that comply with either BS 4514 or BS 5255.

text: Ductwork should not help to transfer fire and smoke through the building.
text-fixed: Ductwork should not help to transfer fire and smoke through the building.

text: Terminals of exhaust points should be sited away from final exits, cladding or roofing materials achieving class B-s3, d2 or worse and openings into the building.
text-fixed: Terminals of exhaust points should be sited away from final exits, cladding or roofing materials achieving class B-s3, d2 or worse and openings into the building.

text: Ventilation ducts supplying or extracting air directly to or from a protected stairway should not also serve other areas.
text-fixed: Ventilation ducts supplying or extracting air directly to or from a protected stairway should not also serve other areas.

text: A separate ventilation system should be provided for each protected stairway.
text-fixed: A separate ventilation system should be provided for each protected stairway.

text: A fire and smoke damper should be provided where ductwork enters or leaves each section of the protected escape route it serves.
text-fixed: A fire and smoke damper should be provided where ductwork enters or leaves each section of the protected escape route it serves.

text: It should be operated by a smoke detector or suitable fire detection system.
text-fixed: It should be operated by a smoke detector or suitable fire detection system.

text: Fire and smoke dampers should close when smoke is detected.
text-fixed: Fire and smoke dampers should close when smoke is detected.

text: Alternatively, the methods set out in paragraphs 10.15 and 10.16 and Diagrams 10.2 and 10.3 may be followed.
text-fixed: Alternatively, the methods set out in paragraphs 10.15 and 10.16 and Diagrams 10.2 and 10.3 may be followed.
