text-fixed: Maximum nominal internal diameter of pipes passing through a fire-separating element
In a system that recirculates air, smoke detectors should be fitted in the extract ductwork before both of the following.

text: The point where recirculated air is separated from air to be discharged to the outside.
text-fixed: The point where recirculated air is separated from air to be discharged to the outside.

text: Any filters or other air cleaning equipment.
text-fixed: Any filters or other air cleaning equipment.

text: When smoke is detected, detectors should do one of the following.
text-fixed: When smoke is detected, detectors should do one of the following.

text: Cause the system to immediately shut down.
text-fixed: Cause the system to immediately shut down.

text: Switch the ventilation system from recirculating mode to extraction to divert smoke outside the building.
text-fixed: Switch the ventilation system from recirculating mode to extraction to divert smoke outside the building.

text: #NAME?
text-fixed: Non-domestic kitchens, car parks and plant rooms should have separate and independent extraction systems.

text: Extracted air should not be recirculated.
text-fixed: Extracted air should not be recirculated.

text: Under fire conditions, ventilation and air-conditioning systems should be compatible with smoke control systems and need to be considered in their respective design.
text-fixed: Under fire conditions, ventilation and air-conditioning systems should be compatible with smoke control systems and need to be considered in their respective design.

text: If air handling ducts pass through fire-separating elements, the fire performance of the elements should be maintained using one or more of the following four methods.
text-fixed: If air handling ducts pass through fire-separating elements, the fire performance of the elements should be maintained using one or more of the following four methods.

text: In most ductwork systems, a combination of the four methods is best.
text-fixed: In most ductwork systems, a combination of the four methods is best.

text: Method 1 – thermally activated fire dampers.
text-fixed: Method 1 – thermally activated fire dampers.

text: Method 2 – fire resisting enclosures.
text-fixed: Method 2 – fire resisting enclosures.

text: Method 3 – protection using fire resisting ductwork.
text-fixed: Method 3 – protection using fire resisting ductwork.

text: Method 4 – automatically activated fire and smoke dampers triggered by smoke detectors.
text-fixed: Method 4 – automatically activated fire and smoke dampers triggered by smoke detectors.

text: Further information on fire resisting ductwork is given in the ASFP Blue Book.
text-fixed: Further information on fire resisting ductwork is given in the ASFP Blue Book.

text: Kitchen extract 10.14 Methods 1 and 4 should not be used for extract ductwork serving kitchens.
text-fixed: Kitchen extract 10.14 Methods 1 and 4 should not be used for extract ductwork serving kitchens.

text: The likely build-up of grease within the duct can adversely affect dampers.
text-fixed: The likely build-up of grease within the duct can adversely affect dampers.

text: Method 1 should not be used for extract ductwork passing through the enclosures of protected escape routes (Diagrams 10.2 and 10.3), as large volumes of smoke can pass thermal devices without triggering them.
text-fixed: Method 1 should not be used for extract ductwork passing through the enclosures of protected escape routes (Diagrams 10.2 and 10.3), as large volumes of smoke can pass thermal devices without triggering them.

text: An ES classified fire and smoke damper which is activated by a suitable fire detection system (method 4) may also be used for protected escape routes.
text-fixed: An ES classified fire and smoke damper which is activated by a suitable fire detection system (method 4) may also be used for protected escape routes.

text: Ventilation ducts which serve other parts of the building should not supply or extract air directly to or from a protected escape route.
text-fixed: Ventilation ducts which serve other parts of the building should not supply or extract air directly to or from a protected escape route.

text: Ventilation ducts which serve other parts of the building should not supply or extract air directly to or from a protected escape route.
text-fixed: Ventilation ducts which serve other parts of the building should not supply or extract air directly to or from a protected escape route.

text: B3ONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION Installation and specification of fire dampers 10.17 Both fire dampers and fire and smoke dampers should be all of the following.
text-fixed: Both fire dampers and fire and smoke dampers should be all of the following.

text: Sited within the thickness of the fire-separating elements.
text-fixed: Sited within the thickness of the fire-separating elements.

text: Sited such that, in a fire, expansion of the ductwork would not push the fire damper through the structure.
text-fixed: Sited such that, in a fire, expansion of the ductwork would not push the fire damper through the structure.

text: Access to the fire damper and its actuating mechanism should be provided for inspection, testing and maintenance.
text-fixed: Access to the fire damper and its actuating mechanism should be provided for inspection, testing and maintenance.

text: Fire dampers should meet both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: Fire dampers should meet both of the following conditions.

text: Conform to BS EN 15650.
text-fixed: Conform to BS EN 15650.

text: Have a minimum E classification of 60 minutes or to match the integrity rating of the fire resisting elements, whichever is higher.
text-fixed: Have a minimum E classification of 60 minutes or to match the integrity rating of the fire resisting elements, whichever is higher.

text: Fire and smoke dampers should meet both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: Fire and smoke dampers should meet both of the following conditions.

text: Conform to BS EN 15650.
text-fixed: Conform to BS EN 15650.

text: Have a minimum ES classification of 60 minutes or to match the integrity rating of the fire resisting elements, whichever is higher.
text-fixed: Have a minimum ES classification of 60 minutes or to match the integrity rating of the fire resisting elements, whichever is higher.

text: Smoke detectors should be sited so as to prevent the spread of smoke as early as practicable by activating the fire and smoke dampers.
text-fixed: Smoke detectors should be sited so as to prevent the spread of smoke as early as practicable by activating the fire and smoke dampers.

text: Smoke detectors and automatic release mechanisms used to activate fire dampers and/or fire and smoke dampers should conform to BS EN 54-7 and BS 5839-3 respectively.
text-fixed: Smoke detectors and automatic release mechanisms used to activate fire dampers and/or fire and smoke dampers should conform to BS EN 54-7 and BS 5839-3 respectively.

text: Further information on fire dampers and/or fire and smoke dampers is given in the ASFP Grey Book.
text-fixed: Further information on fire dampers and/or fire and smoke dampers is given in the ASFP Grey Book.

text: Where the use of the building involves a sleeping risk, fire dampers or fire and smoke dampers should be actuated by both of the following.
text-fixed: Where the use of the building involves a sleeping risk, fire dampers or fire and smoke dampers should be actuated by both of the following.

text: Smoke detector-controlled automatic release mechanisms.
text-fixed: Smoke detector-controlled automatic release mechanisms.

text: Thermally actuated devices.
text-fixed: Thermally actuated devices.

text: However, in a situation where both of the following are true:
text-fixed: However, in a situation where both of the following are true:

text: then both of the following exceptions may be made.
text-fixed: then both of the following exceptions may be made.

text: If, on the detection of smoke, the fire alarm system signals the immediate evacuation of all the occupants of the building, then fire dampers and/or fire and smoke dampers do not need to be actuated by smoke detectors.

text: If the building is divided into fire compartments and the alarm system is arranged to signal the immediate evacuation of the occupants of the fire compartment in which the fire has been detected, then smoke detector-operated fire dampers or fire and smoke dampers need only be provided where ductwork enters or leaves the fire compartment.

text: Car parks call for different measures to restrict fire spread within buildings for the following reasons.
text-fixed: Car parks call for different measures to restrict fire spread within buildings for the following reasons.

text: The fire load is well defined.
text-fixed: The fire load is well defined.

text: The probability of fire spreading from one storey to another in a well ventilated car park is low.
text-fixed: The probability of fire spreading from one storey to another in a well ventilated car park is low.

text: Guidance is therefore given for three ventilation scenarios.
text-fixed: Guidance is therefore given for three ventilation scenarios.

text: For the purposes of assessing fire resistance, a building, compartment or separated part containing a car park may be regarded as open-sided when it complies with all of the following.
text-fixed: For the purposes of assessing fire resistance, a building, compartment or separated part containing a car park may be regarded as open-sided when it complies with all of the following.

text: There are no basement storeys.
text-fixed: There are no basement storeys.

text: Each storey is naturally ventilated by permanent openings at each car parking level.
text-fixed: Each storey is naturally ventilated by permanent openings at each car parking level.

text: The aggregate vent area is a minimum of 1/20 of that level’s floor area, at least half of which is provided equally by two opposite walls (1/80 on each side).
text-fixed: The aggregate vent area is a minimum of 1/20 of that level’s floor area, at least half of which is provided equally by two opposite walls (1/80 on each side).

text: The remaining free area can be distributed wherever possible.
text-fixed: The remaining free area can be distributed wherever possible.

text: Where one element of structure supports, carries or stabilises another, the fire resistance of the supporting element at least matches the minimum period of fire resistance for the other element.
text-fixed: Where one element of structure supports, carries or stabilises another, the fire resistance of the supporting element at least matches the minimum period of fire resistance for the other element.

text: In mixed use buildings, the fire resistance of any element that supports, carries or stabilises an element in the other part of the building should at least match the minimum period of fire resistance for the other element.
text-fixed: In mixed use buildings, the fire resistance of any element that supports, carries or stabilises an element in the other part of the building should at least match the minimum period of fire resistance for the other element.

text: All materials used in the construction should be class A1 rated, except for the following.

text: Any fire doorset.
text-fixed: Any fire doorset.

text: Any attendant’s kiosk not exceeding 15m2 in area.
text-fixed: Any attendant’s kiosk not exceeding 15m2 in area.

text: Any shop mobility facility.
text-fixed: Any shop mobility facility.

text: Ventilation should be either natural or mechanical.
text-fixed: Ventilation should be either natural or mechanical.

text: Each storey should be ventilated by permanent openings at each car parking level.

text-fixed: The openings can be at ceiling level.

text: The aggregate free vent area should be a minimum of 1/40 of that level’s floor area, at least half of which should be provided equally by two opposite walls (1/160 on each side).
text-fixed: The aggregate free vent area should be a minimum of 1/40 of that level’s floor area, at least half of which should be provided equally by two opposite walls (1/160 on each side).

text: The remaining free area can be distributed wherever possible.
text-fixed: The remaining free area can be distributed wherever possible.

text-fixed: If the minimum standard of natural ventilation is not possible, a system of mechanical ventilation should be provided that complies with all of the following.

text: The system should be both of the following.
text-fixed: The system should be both of the following.

text: Independent of any other ventilating system (other than any system that provides day to day ventilation to the car park).
text-fixed: Independent of any other ventilating system (other than any system that provides day to day ventilation to the car park).

text: Designed to operate at 10 air changes per hour during a fire.
text-fixed: Designed to operate at 10 air changes per hour during a fire.

text: The system should run in two parts, each of which is:
text-fixed: The system should run in two parts, each of which is:

text: provided with an independent power supply capable of operating if the main supply fails.
text-fixed: provided with an independent power supply capable of operating if the main supply fails.

text: 50% of the outlets should be at high level and 50% at low level.
text-fixed: 50% of the outlets should be at high level and 50% at low level.

text: The system should use E, I and S ductwork in accordance with BS EN 1366-8.
text-fixed: The system should use E, I and S ductwork in accordance with BS EN 1366-8.

text-fixed: For further information on equipment for removing hot smoke, refer to BS EN 12101-3.

text: An alternative method of providing smoke ventilation from enclosed car parks is given in BS 7346-7.
text-fixed: An alternative method of providing smoke ventilation from enclosed car parks is given in BS 7346-7.

text: “above ground level” in relation to a storey means above ground level when measured from the lowest ground level adjoining the outside of a building to the top of the floor surface of the storey.

text: The external envelope of a building should not contribute to undue fire spread from one part of a building to another part.
text-fixed: The external envelope of a building should not contribute to undue fire spread from one part of a building to another part.

text: This intention can be met by constructing external walls so that both of the following are satisfied.
text-fixed: This intention can be met by constructing external walls so that both of the following are satisfied.

text: The risk of ignition by an external source to the outside surface of the building and spread of fire over the outside surface is restricted.

text: The extent to which this is necessary depends on the height and use of the building.
text-fixed: The extent to which this is necessary depends on the height and use of the building.

text: The external envelope of a building should not provide a medium for undue fire spread to adjacent buildings or be readily ignited by fires in adjacent buildings.

text: Metal composite materials 12.12 Regulation 7(1A) prohibits the use of relevant metal composite materials in the external walls, and specified attachments, of all buildings of any height.
text-fixed: Metal composite materials 12.12 Regulation 7(1A) prohibits the use of relevant metal composite materials in the external walls, and specified attachments, of all buildings of any height.

text: Relevant metal composite materials are defined (in regulation 2(6)(c)) as any panel or sheet, having a thickness of no more than 10mm which is composed of a number of layers two or more of which are made of metal, alloy or metal compound and one or more of which is a substantial layer made of a material having a gross calorific value of more than 35MJ/kg when tested in accordance with BS EN ISO 1716.
text-fixed: Relevant metal composite materials are defined (in regulation 2(6)(c)) as any panel or sheet, having a thickness of no more than 10mm which is composed of a number of layers two or more of which are made of metal, alloy or metal compound and one or more of which is a substantial layer made of a material having a gross calorific value of more than 35MJ/kg when tested in accordance with BS EN ISO 1716.

text: A substantial layer is defined as a layer which is at least 1mm thick or has a mass per unit area of at least 1kg/m².
text-fixed: A substantial layer is defined as a layer which is at least 1mm thick or has a mass per unit area of at least 1kg/m².

text: Materials 12.14 Regulation 7(1)(a) requires that materials used in building work are appropriate for the circumstances in which they are used.
text-fixed: Materials 12.14 Regulation 7(1)(a) requires that materials used in building work are appropriate for the circumstances in which they are used.

text: Regulation 7(2) sets requirements in respect of external walls and specified attachments in relevant buildings.
text-fixed: Regulation 7(2) sets requirements in respect of external walls and specified attachments in relevant buildings.

text: Further guidance on regulation 7(1) can be found in HM Government’s Manual to the Building Regulations.
text-fixed: Further guidance on regulation 7(1) can be found in HM Government’s Manual to the Building Regulations.

text: Regulation 7(2) applies to any building with a storey at least 18m above ground level (as measured in accordance with Diagram D6 in Appendix D) and which contains one or more dwellings; an institution; or a room for residential purposes.
text-fixed: Regulation 7(2) applies to any building with a storey at least 18m above ground level (as measured in accordance with Diagram D6 in Appendix D) and which contains one or more dwellings; an institution; or a room for residential purposes.

text: It requires that all materials which become part of an external wall or specified attachment achieve class A2-s1, d0 or class A1 in accordance with BS EN 13501-1, other than those exempted by regulation 7(3).
text-fixed: It requires that all materials which become part of an external wall or specified attachment achieve class A2-s1, d0 or class A1 in accordance with BS EN 13501-1, other than those exempted by regulation 7(3).

text: The above includes student accommodation, care homes, sheltered housing, hospitals, dormitories in boarding schools, hotels, hostels and boarding houses.
text-fixed: The above includes student accommodation, care homes, sheltered housing, hospitals, dormitories in boarding schools, hotels, hostels and boarding houses.

text: See regulation 7(4) for the definition of relevant buildings.
text-fixed: See regulation 7(4) for the definition of relevant buildings.

text: Transposition to a national class (Table B1) does not apply to the classification in this paragraph.
text-fixed: Transposition to a national class (Table B1) does not apply to the classification in this paragraph.

text: External walls and specified attachments are defined in regulation 2(6) and these definitions include any parts of the external wall as well as balconies, solar panels and solar shading.
text-fixed: External walls and specified attachments are defined in regulation 2(6) and these definitions include any parts of the external wall as well as balconies, solar panels and solar shading.

text: Regulation 7(3) provides an exemption for certain components found in external walls and specified attachments.
text-fixed: Regulation 7(3) provides an exemption for certain components found in external walls and specified attachments.

text: Regulations 5(k) and 6(3) provide that, where the use of a building is changed such that the building becomes a building described in regulation 7(4), the construction of the external walls, and specified attachments, must be investigated and, where necessary, work must be carried out to ensure they only contain materials achieving class A2-s1, d0 or class A1, other than those exempted by regulation 7(3).
text-fixed: Regulations 5(k) and 6(3) provide that, where the use of a building is changed such that the building becomes a building described in regulation 7(4), the construction of the external walls, and specified attachments, must be investigated and, where necessary, work must be carried out to ensure they only contain materials achieving class A2-s1, d0 or class A1, other than those exempted by regulation 7(3).

text: Solar shading devices 12.19 Regulation 7(2) requires that the curtain and or slats of solar shading devices in a relevant building (as defined in regulation 7(4)) achieve class A1 or A2-s1, d0.
text-fixed: Solar shading devices 12.19 Regulation 7(2) requires that the curtain and or slats of solar shading devices in a relevant building (as defined in regulation 7(4)) achieve class A1 or A2-s1, d0.

text: The curtain of solar shading devices cannot be classified as a membrane in accordance with regulation 7(3).
text-fixed: The curtain of solar shading devices cannot be classified as a membrane in accordance with regulation 7(3).

text: Solar shading devices installed up to 4.5m above ground level are not required to meet the requirements of regulation 7(2).
text-fixed: Solar shading devices installed up to 4.5m above ground level are not required to meet the requirements of regulation 7(2).

text: The provisions of regulation 7 apply in addition to requirement B4.
text-fixed: The provisions of regulation 7 apply in addition to requirement B4.

text: Therefore, for buildings described in regulation 7(4), the potential impact of any products incorporated into or onto the external walls and specified attachments should be carefully considered with regard to their number, size, orientation and position.

text: Particular attention is drawn to the following points.
text-fixed: Particular attention is drawn to the following points.

text: Membranes used as part of the external wall construction above ground level should achieve a minimum of class B-s3, d0.
text-fixed: Membranes used as part of the external wall construction above ground level should achieve a minimum of class B-s3, d0.

text: Roofing membranes do not need to achieve a minimum of class A2-s1, d0 when used as part of a roof connecting to an external wall.

text: Internal linings should comply with the guidance provided in Section 4. c. Any part of a roof should achieve the minimum performance as detailed in Section 12.

text: As per regulation 7(3), window frames and glass (including laminated glass) are exempted from regulation 7(2).

text: Window spandrel panels and infill panels must comply with regulation 7(2).
text-fixed: Window spandrel panels and infill panels must comply with regulation 7(2).

text: Thermal breaks are small elements used as part of the external wall construction to restrict thermal bridging.
text-fixed: Thermal breaks are small elements used as part of the external wall construction to restrict thermal bridging.

text: There is no minimum performance for these materials.
text-fixed: There is no minimum performance for these materials.

text: However, they should not span two compartments and should be limited in size to the minimum required to restrict the thermal bridging (the principal insulation layer is not to be regarded as a thermal break).
text-fixed: However, they should not span two compartments and should be limited in size to the minimum required to restrict the thermal bridging (the principal insulation layer is not to be regarded as a thermal break).

text: Regulation 7(2) only applies to specified attachments.
text-fixed: Regulation 7(2) only applies to specified attachments.

text: Shop front signs and similar attachments are not covered by the requirements of regulation 7(2), although attention is drawn to paragraph 12.22g.
text-fixed: Shop front signs and similar attachments are not covered by the requirements of regulation 7(2), although attention is drawn to paragraph 12.22g.

text: While regulation 7(2) applies to materials which become part of an external wall or specified attachment, consideration should be given to other attachments to the wall which could impact on the risk of fire spread over the wall.

text: Any material achieving class A1fl or A2fl-s1 in accordance with BS EN 13501-1 is exempted when it meets both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: Any material achieving class A1fl or A2fl-s1 in accordance with BS EN 13501-1 is exempted when it meets both of the following conditions.

text: It forms the top horizontal floor layer of a balcony.

text-fixed: It is provided with an imperforate substrate under it which extends to the full size of the class A1fl or A2fl-s1 material.

text: The following assumptions enable a reasonable standard of resistance to the spread of fire to be specified.
text-fixed: The following assumptions enable a reasonable standard of resistance to the spread of fire to be specified.

text: A fire may involve a complete compartment, but will not spread to other compartments.
text-fixed: A fire may involve a complete compartment, but will not spread to other compartments.

text: The intensity of fire is related to the building use, but can be moderated by a sprinkler system.
text-fixed: The intensity of fire is related to the building use, but can be moderated by a sprinkler system.

text: Fires in ‘residential’ and ‘assembly and recreation’ buildings (purposes groups 1, 2 and 5) represent a greater risk to life.
text-fixed: Fires in ‘residential’ and ‘assembly and recreation’ buildings (purposes groups 1, 2 and 5) represent a greater risk to life.

text: A building on the far side of the relevant boundary meets both of the following conditions.
text-fixed: A building on the far side of the relevant boundary meets both of the following conditions.

text: Has a similar elevation to the one in question.
text-fixed: Has a similar elevation to the one in question.

text: Is at the same distance from the common boundary.
text-fixed: Is at the same distance from the common boundary.

text-fixed: The radiated heat passing through any part of the fire resisting external wall may be discounted.

text-fixed: Where regulation 7(2) applies, that regulation prevails over the provisions within this section.

text: Parts of an external wall with less fire resistance than the appropriate amount given in Appendix B, Table B4, are called unprotected areas.
text-fixed: Parts of an external wall with less fire resistance than the appropriate amount given in Appendix B, Table B4, are called unprotected areas.

text: Where a fire resisting external wall has an external surface material that is worse than class B-s3, d2 and is more than 1mm thick, that part of the wall should be classified as an unprotected area equating to half its area (Diagram 13.4).
text-fixed: Where a fire resisting external wall has an external surface material that is worse than class B-s3, d2 and is more than 1mm thick, that part of the wall should be classified as an unprotected area equating to half its area (Diagram 13.4).

text: Unprotected areas should meet the conditions in Diagram 13.5 and the rest of the wall should be fire resisting from both sides.
text-fixed: Unprotected areas should meet the conditions in Diagram 13.5 and the rest of the wall should be fire resisting from both sides.

text: External surface materials facing the boundary should be class B-s3, d2 or better.
text-fixed: External surface materials facing the boundary should be class B-s3, d2 or better.

text: Unprotected area should not exceed the result given by one of the methods in paragraph 13.17, and the rest of the wall (if any) should be fire resisting but only from the inside of the building.

text: In an otherwise protected wall, small unprotected areas may be ignored where they meet the conditions in Diagram 13.5.
text-fixed: In an otherwise protected wall, small unprotected areas may be ignored where they meet the conditions in Diagram 13.5.

text: For the purposes of assessing unprotected area, parts of walls of uncompartmented buildings that are more than 30m above mean ground level may be ignored.
text-fixed: For the purposes of assessing unprotected area, parts of walls of uncompartmented buildings that are more than 30m above mean ground level may be ignored.

text: Where both of the following apply, separation distances may be determined from the wall rather than from the edge of the canopy (Diagram 13.6).
text-fixed: Where both of the following apply, separation distances may be determined from the wall rather than from the edge of the canopy (Diagram 13.6).

text: The canopy is attached to the side of a building.
text-fixed: The canopy is attached to the side of a building.

text: The edges of the canopy are a minimum of 2m from the relevant boundary.
text-fixed: The edges of the canopy are a minimum of 2m from the relevant boundary.

text: Canopies that fall within class 6 or class 7 of Schedule 2 to the regulations (Exempt Buildings and Work) are exempt from the Building Regulations.
text-fixed: Canopies that fall within class 6 or class 7 of Schedule 2 to the regulations (Exempt Buildings and Work) are exempt from the Building Regulations.

text: Space separation may be disregarded if a canopy is all of the following.
text-fixed: Space separation may be disregarded if a canopy is all of the following.

text: Above a limited risk or controlled hazard, for example over petrol pumps.
text-fixed: Above a limited risk or controlled hazard, for example over petrol pumps.

text: A minimum of 1000mm from the relevant boundary.
text-fixed: A minimum of 1000mm from the relevant boundary.

text: Projections from the building line, such as a canopy or a loading platform, can be ignored when assessing separation distance.

text: This does not apply where the canopy is enclosed by side walls.
text-fixed: This does not apply where the canopy is enclosed by side walls.

text: Roofs with a pitch of more than 70 degrees to the horizontal should be assessed in accordance with this section.
text-fixed: Roofs with a pitch of more than 70 degrees to the horizontal should be assessed in accordance with this section.

text: Vertical parts of a pitched roof, such as dormer windows, should be included, only if the slope of the roof exceeds 70 degrees.
text-fixed: Vertical parts of a pitched roof, such as dormer windows, should be included, only if the slope of the roof exceeds 70 degrees.

text: It is a matter of judgement whether a continuous run of dormer windows that occupies most of a steeply pitched roof should be treated as a wall rather than a roof.
text-fixed: It is a matter of judgement whether a continuous run of dormer windows that occupies most of a steeply pitched roof should be treated as a wall rather than a roof.

text: Portal frames are often used in single storey industrial and commercial buildings where there may be no need for fire resistance of the structure (requirement B3).
text-fixed: Portal frames are often used in single storey industrial and commercial buildings where there may be no need for fire resistance of the structure (requirement B3).

text: However, where a portal framed building is near a relevant boundary, the external wall near the boundary may need fire resistance to restrict the spread of fire between buildings.
text-fixed: However, where a portal framed building is near a relevant boundary, the external wall near the boundary may need fire resistance to restrict the spread of fire between buildings.

text: It is generally accepted that a portal frame acts as a single structural element because of the moment-resisting connections used, especially at the column/rafter joints.
text-fixed: It is generally accepted that a portal frame acts as a single structural element because of the moment-resisting connections used, especially at the column/rafter joints.

text: Thus, in cases where the external wall of the building cannot be wholly unprotected, the rafter members of the frame, as well as the column members, may need to be fire protected.
text-fixed: Thus, in cases where the external wall of the building cannot be wholly unprotected, the rafter members of the frame, as well as the column members, may need to be fire protected.

text: The design method for this is set out in SCI Publication P313.
text-fixed: The design method for this is set out in SCI Publication P313.

text: The recommendations in the SCI publication for designing the foundation to resist overturning do not need to be followed if the building is fitted with a sprinkler system in accordance with Appendix E.

text: Normally, portal frames of reinforced concrete can support external walls requiring a similar degree of fire resistance without specific provision at the base to resist overturning.
