text: Only services associated with the firefighting shaft, such as ventilation systems and lighting for the firefighting shaft, should pass through or be contained within the firefighting shaft.
text-fixed: Only services associated with the firefighting shaft, such as ventilation systems and lighting for the firefighting shaft, should pass through or be contained within the firefighting shaft.

text: All firefighting shafts should have fire mains with outlet connections and valves at every storey.
text-fixed: All firefighting shafts should have fire mains with outlet connections and valves at every storey.

text: A firefighting lift installation includes all of the following.
text-fixed: A firefighting lift installation includes all of the following.

text: Lift machinery space.
text-fixed: Lift machinery space.

text: Lift control system.
text-fixed: Lift control system.

text: Lift communications system.
text-fixed: Lift communications system.

text: The lift shaft should be constructed in accordance with Section 6 of BS 9999.
text-fixed: The lift shaft should be constructed in accordance with Section 6 of BS 9999.

text: Firefighting lift installations should conform to BS EN 81-72 and BS EN 81-20.
text-fixed: Firefighting lift installations should conform to BS EN 81-72 and BS EN 81-20.

text: The fire and rescue service should be able to manually open and close rolling shutters without the use of a ladder.
text-fixed: The fire and rescue service should be able to manually open and close rolling shutters without the use of a ladder.

text: Heat and smoke from basement fires vented via stairs can inhibit access for firefighting personnel.
text-fixed: Heat and smoke from basement fires vented via stairs can inhibit access for firefighting personnel.

text: This may be reduced by providing smoke outlets, or smoke vents, which allow heat and smoke to escape from the basement levels to the open air.
text-fixed: This may be reduced by providing smoke outlets, or smoke vents, which allow heat and smoke to escape from the basement levels to the open air.

text: They can also be used by the fire and rescue service to let cooler air into the basements (Diagram 18.1).
text-fixed: They can also be used by the fire and rescue service to let cooler air into the basements (Diagram 18.1).

text: Each basement space should have one or more smoke outlets.
text-fixed: Each basement space should have one or more smoke outlets.

text: Where this is not practicable (for example, the plan area is deep and the amount of external wall is restricted by adjoining buildings), the perimeter basement spaces may be vented, with other spaces vented indirectly by opening connecting doors.
text-fixed: Where this is not practicable (for example, the plan area is deep and the amount of external wall is restricted by adjoining buildings), the perimeter basement spaces may be vented, with other spaces vented indirectly by opening connecting doors.

text: This does not apply for places of special fire hazard (see paragraph 18.7).
text-fixed: This does not apply for places of special fire hazard (see paragraph 18.7).

text: If a basement is compartmented, each compartment should have one or more smoke outlets, rather than indirect venting.
text-fixed: If a basement is compartmented, each compartment should have one or more smoke outlets, rather than indirect venting.

text: A basement storey or compartment containing rooms with doors or windows does not need smoke outlets.
text-fixed: A basement storey or compartment containing rooms with doors or windows does not need smoke outlets.

text: Smoke outlets connecting directly to the open air should be provided from every basement storey, except for any basement storey that has both of the following.
text-fixed: Smoke outlets connecting directly to the open air should be provided from every basement storey, except for any basement storey that has both of the following.

text: A maximum floor area of 200m2.
text-fixed: A maximum floor area of 200m2.

text: A floor a maximum of 3m below the adjacent ground level.
text-fixed: A floor a maximum of 3m below the adjacent ground level.

text: Strong rooms do not need to be provided with smoke outlets.
text-fixed: Strong rooms do not need to be provided with smoke outlets.

text: Smoke outlets should be both of the following.
text-fixed: Smoke outlets should be both of the following.

text: Sited at high level in either the ceiling or wall of the space they serve.
text-fixed: Sited at high level in either the ceiling or wall of the space they serve.

text: Evenly distributed around the perimeter, to discharge to the open air.
text-fixed: Evenly distributed around the perimeter, to discharge to the open air.

text: The combined clear cross-sectional area of all smoke outlets should be a minimum of 1/40 of the area of the floor of the storey they serve.
text-fixed: The combined clear cross-sectional area of all smoke outlets should be a minimum of 1/40 of the area of the floor of the storey they serve.

text: Separate outlets should be provided from places of special fire hazard.
text-fixed: Separate outlets should be provided from places of special fire hazard.

text: If the smoke outlet terminates at a point that is not readily accessible, it should be kept unobstructed and covered only with a class A1 grille or louvre.
text-fixed: If the smoke outlet terminates at a point that is not readily accessible, it should be kept unobstructed and covered only with a class A1 grille or louvre.

text: If the smoke outlet terminates in a readily accessible position, it may be covered by a panel, stallboard or pavement light that can be broken out or opened.
text-fixed: If the smoke outlet terminates in a readily accessible position, it may be covered by a panel, stallboard or pavement light that can be broken out or opened.

text: The position of covered smoke outlets should be suitably indicated.
text-fixed: The position of covered smoke outlets should be suitably indicated.

text: ONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSIONONLINE VERSION 18.10 Outlets should not be placed where they prevent the use of escape routes from the building.
text-fixed: Outlets should not be placed where they prevent the use of escape routes from the building.

text: If basement storeys are fitted with a sprinkler system in accordance with Appendix E, a mechanical smoke extraction system may be provided as an alternative to natural venting.
text-fixed: If basement storeys are fitted with a sprinkler system in accordance with Appendix E, a mechanical smoke extraction system may be provided as an alternative to natural venting.

text: Sprinklers do not need to be installed on the other storeys unless needed for other reasons.
text-fixed: Sprinklers do not need to be installed on the other storeys unless needed for other reasons.

text: Car parks are not normally expected to be fitted with sprinklers (see Section 11 for guidance on car parks).
text-fixed: Car parks are not normally expected to be fitted with sprinklers (see Section 11 for guidance on car parks).

text: The air extraction system should comply with all of the following.
text-fixed: The air extraction system should comply with all of the following.

text: It should give at least 10 air changes per hour.
text-fixed: It should give at least 10 air changes per hour.

text: It should be capable of handling gas temperatures of 300°C for not less than one hour.
text-fixed: It should be capable of handling gas temperatures of 300°C for not less than one hour.

text: It should do either of the following.
text-fixed: It should do either of the following.

text: Be activated automatically if the sprinkler system activates.
text-fixed: Be activated automatically if the sprinkler system activates.

text: Be activated by an automatic fire detection system that conforms to BS 5839-1 (minimum L3 standard).
text-fixed: Be activated by an automatic fire detection system that conforms to BS 5839-1 (minimum L3 standard).

text: Further information on equipment for removing hot smoke is given in BS EN 12101-3.
text-fixed: Further information on equipment for removing hot smoke is given in BS EN 12101-3.

text: Fire resisting construction of floor
text-fixed: Fire resisting construction of floor

text: with break-out or
text-fixed: Basement outlet with break-out or openable cover

text: Outlet ducts or shafts, including any bulkheads over them (see Diagram 18.1), should be enclosed in construction of class A1 rating and fire resistance at least equal to that of the element through which they pass.
text-fixed: Outlet ducts or shafts, including any bulkheads over them (see Diagram 18.1), should be enclosed in construction of class A1 rating and fire resistance at least equal to that of the element through which they pass.

text: Natural smoke outlet shafts should be separated from each other using construction of class A1 rating and fire resistance at least equal to that of the storeys they serve, where the shafts are either of the following.
text-fixed: Natural smoke outlet shafts should be separated from each other using construction of class A1 rating and fire resistance at least equal to that of the storeys they serve, where the shafts are either of the following.

text: From different compartments of the same basement storey.
text-fixed: From different compartments of the same basement storey.

text: From different basement storeys.
text-fixed: From different basement storeys.

text: The provisions for ventilation of basement car parks in Section 11 satisfy the requirements for venting smoke from any basement used as a car park.
text-fixed: The provisions for ventilation of basement car parks in Section 11 satisfy the requirements for venting smoke from any basement used as a car park.

text: This section deals with the following regulation of the Building Regulations 2010.
text-fixed: This section deals with the following regulation of the Building Regulations 2010.

text: consists of or includes the erection or extension of a relevant building; or
text-fixed: consists of or includes the erection or extension of a relevant building; or

text: is carried out in connection with a relevant change of use of a building,
text-fixed: is carried out in connection with a relevant change of use of a building,

text: and Part B of Schedule 1 imposes a requirement in relation to the work.
text-fixed: and Part B of Schedule 1 imposes a requirement in relation to the work.

text: The person carrying out the work shall give fire safety information to the responsible person not later than the date of completion of the work, or the date of occupation of the building or extension, whichever is the earlier.
text-fixed: The person carrying out the work shall give fire safety information to the responsible person not later than the date of completion of the work, or the date of occupation of the building or extension, whichever is the earlier.

text: In this regulation— (a) “fire safety information” means information relating to the design and construction of the building or extension, and the services, fittings and equipment provided in or in connection with the building or extension which will assist the responsible person to operate and maintain the building or extension with reasonable safety;
text-fixed: In this regulation— (a) “fire safety information” means information relating to the design and construction of the building or extension, and the services, fittings and equipment provided in or in connection with the building or extension which will assist the responsible person to operate and maintain the building or extension with reasonable safety;

text: a “relevant building” is a building to which the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 applies, or will apply after the completion of building work;
text-fixed: a “relevant building” is a building to which the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 applies, or will apply after the completion of building work;

text: a “relevant change of use” is a material change of use where, after the change of use takes place, the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 will apply, or continue to apply, to the building; and
text-fixed: a “relevant change of use” is a material change of use where, after the change of use takes place, the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 will apply, or continue to apply, to the building; and

text: “responsible person” has the meaning given by article 3 of the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005.
text-fixed: “responsible person” has the meaning given by article 3 of the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005.

text: The aim of this regulation is to ensure that the person responsible for the building has sufficient information relating to fire safety to enable them to manage the building effectively.
text-fixed: The aim of this regulation is to ensure that the person responsible for the building has sufficient information relating to fire safety to enable them to manage the building effectively.

text: The aim of regulation 38 will be achieved when the person responsible for the building has all the information to enable them to do all of the following.
text-fixed: The aim of regulation 38 will be achieved when the person responsible for the building has all the information to enable them to do all of the following.

text: Understand and implement the fire safety strategy of the building.
text-fixed: Understand and implement the fire safety strategy of the building.

text: Maintain any fire safety system provided in the building.
text-fixed: Maintain any fire safety system provided in the building.

text: Carry out an effective fire risk assessment of the building.
text-fixed: Carry out an effective fire risk assessment of the building.

text: For building work involving the erection or extension of a relevant building (i.e. a building to which the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 applies or will apply), or the relevant change of use of a building, fire safety information should be given to the responsible person at one of the following times.
text-fixed: For building work involving the erection or extension of a relevant building (i.e. a building to which the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 applies or will apply), or the relevant change of use of a building, fire safety information should be given to the responsible person at one of the following times.

text: When the project is complete.
text-fixed: When the project is complete.

text: When the building or extension is first occupied.
text-fixed: When the building or extension is first occupied.

text: This section is a guide to the information that should be provided.
text-fixed: This section is a guide to the information that should be provided.

text: Guidance is in terms of essential information and additional information for complex buildings; however, the level of detail required should be considered on a case-by-case basis.
text-fixed: Guidance is in terms of essential information and additional information for complex buildings; however, the level of detail required should be considered on a case-by-case basis.

text: Basic information on the location of fire protection measures may be sufficient.
text-fixed: Basic information on the location of fire protection measures may be sufficient.

text: An as-built plan of the building should be provided showing all of the following.
text-fixed: An as-built plan of the building should be provided showing all of the following.

text: Escape routes – this should include exit capacity (i.e. the maximum allowable number of people for each storey and for the building).
text-fixed: Escape routes – this should include exit capacity (i.e. the maximum allowable number of people for each storey and for the building).

text: Location of fire-separating elements (including cavity barriers in walk-in spaces).
text-fixed: Location of fire-separating elements (including cavity barriers in walk-in spaces).

text: Fire doorsets, fire doorsets fitted with a self-closing device and other doors equipped with relevant hardware.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets, fire doorsets fitted with a self-closing device and other doors equipped with relevant hardware.

text: Locations of fire and/or smoke detector heads, alarm call points, detection/alarm control boxes, alarm sounders, fire safety signage, emergency lighting, fire extinguishers, dry or wet fire mains and other firefighting equipment, and hydrants outside the building.
text-fixed: Locations of fire and/or smoke detector heads, alarm call points, detection/alarm control boxes, alarm sounders, fire safety signage, emergency lighting, fire extinguishers, dry or wet fire mains and other firefighting equipment, and hydrants outside the building.

text: Any sprinkler systems, including isolating valves and control equipment.
text-fixed: Any sprinkler systems, including isolating valves and control equipment.

text: Any smoke control systems, or ventilation systems with a smoke control function, including mode of operation and control systems.
text-fixed: Any smoke control systems, or ventilation systems with a smoke control function, including mode of operation and control systems.

text: Any high risk areas (e.g. heating machinery).
text-fixed: Any high risk areas (e.g. heating machinery).

text: Details should be provided of all of the following.
text-fixed: Details should be provided of all of the following.

text: Specifications of any fire safety equipment provided, including routine maintenance schedules.
text-fixed: Specifications of any fire safety equipment provided, including routine maintenance schedules.

text: Any assumptions regarding the management of the building in the design of the fire safety arrangements.
text-fixed: Any assumptions regarding the management of the building in the design of the fire safety arrangements.

text: Any provision enabling the evacuation of disabled people, which can be used when designing suitable personal emergency evacuation plans.
text-fixed: Any provision enabling the evacuation of disabled people, which can be used when designing suitable personal emergency evacuation plans.

text: A detailed record should be provided of both of the following.
text-fixed: A detailed record should be provided of both of the following.

text: The fire safety strategy.
text-fixed: The fire safety strategy.

text: Procedures for operating and maintaining any fire protection measures.
text-fixed: Procedures for operating and maintaining any fire protection measures.

text: This should include an outline cause and effect matrix/strategy for the building.
text-fixed: This should include an outline cause and effect matrix/strategy for the building.

text: Further guidance is available in clause 9 and Annex H of BS 9999.
text-fixed: Further guidance is available in clause 9 and Annex H of BS 9999.

text: The records should include details of all of the following.
text-fixed: The records should include details of all of the following.

text: The fire safety strategy, including all assumptions in the design of the fire safety systems (such as fire load).
text-fixed: The fire safety strategy, including all assumptions in the design of the fire safety systems (such as fire load).

text: Any risk assessments or risk analysis.
text-fixed: Any risk assessments or risk analysis.

text: All assumptions in the design of the fire safety arrangements for the management of the building.
text-fixed: All assumptions in the design of the fire safety arrangements for the management of the building.

text: All of the following.
text-fixed: All of the following.

text: Escape routes (including occupant load and capacity of escape routes).
text-fixed: Escape routes (including occupant load and capacity of escape routes).

text: Any provision to enable the evacuation of disabled people.
text-fixed: Any provision to enable the evacuation of disabled people.

text: Escape strategy (e.g. simultaneous or phased).
text-fixed: Escape strategy (e.g. simultaneous or phased).

text: All passive fire safety measures, including all of the following.
text-fixed: All passive fire safety measures, including all of the following.

text: Compartmentation (i.e. location of fire-separating elements).
text-fixed: Compartmentation (i.e. location of fire-separating elements).

text: Fire doorsets, including fire doorsets fitted with a self-closing device and other doors equipped with relevant hardware (e.g. electronic security locks).
text-fixed: Fire doorsets, including fire doorsets fitted with a self-closing device and other doors equipped with relevant hardware (e.g. electronic security locks).

text: All of the following.
text-fixed: All of the following.

text: Fire detector heads.
text-fixed: Fire detector heads.

text: Smoke detector heads.
text-fixed: Smoke detector heads.

text: Alarm call points.
text-fixed: Alarm call points.

text: Detection/alarm control boxes.
text-fixed: Detection/alarm control boxes.

text: Fire safety signage.
text-fixed: Fire safety signage.

text: Dry or wet fire mains and other firefighting equipment.
text-fixed: Dry or wet fire mains and other firefighting equipment.

text: Other interior facilities for the fire and rescue service.
text-fixed: Other interior facilities for the fire and rescue service.

text: Emergency control rooms.
text-fixed: Emergency control rooms.

text: Location of hydrants outside the building.
text-fixed: Location of hydrants outside the building.

text: Other exterior facilities for the fire and rescue service.
text-fixed: Other exterior facilities for the fire and rescue service.

text: All active fire safety measures, including both of the following.
text-fixed: All active fire safety measures, including both of the following.

text: Sprinkler system(s) design, including isolating valves and control equipment.
text-fixed: Sprinkler system(s) design, including isolating valves and control equipment.

text: Smoke control system(s) (or heating, ventilating and air conditioning system with a smoke control function) design, including mode of operation and control systems.
text-fixed: Smoke control system(s) (or heating, ventilating and air conditioning system with a smoke control function) design, including mode of operation and control systems.

text: Any high-risk areas (e.g. heating machinery) and particular hazards.
text-fixed: Any high-risk areas (e.g. heating machinery) and particular hazards.

text: Plans of the building as built, showing the locations of the above.
text-fixed: Plans of the building as built, showing the locations of the above.

text: Both of the following.
text-fixed: Both of the following.

text: Specifications of any fire safety equipment provided, including all of the following.
text-fixed: Specifications of any fire safety equipment provided, including all of the following.

text: • Routine inspection, testing and maintenance schedules.
text-fixed: Routine inspection, testing and maintenance schedules.

text: Records of any acceptance or commissioning tests.
text-fixed: Records of any acceptance or commissioning tests.

text: Any other details appropriate for the specific building.
text-fixed: Any other details appropriate for the specific building.

text: Except for the items marked * (which are from the Building Regulations 2010), these definitions apply only to Approved Document B.
text-fixed: Except for the items marked * (which are from the Building Regulations 2010), these definitions apply only to Approved Document B.

text: The terms defined below are key terms used in this document only.
text-fixed: The terms defined below are key terms used in this document only.

text: Refer to BS 4422 for further guidance on the definitions of common terms used in the fire safety industry which are not listed below.
text-fixed: Refer to BS 4422 for further guidance on the definitions of common terms used in the fire safety industry which are not listed below.

text: Access room A room that the only escape route from an inner room passes through.
text-fixed: Access room A room that the only escape route from an inner room passes through.

text: Alternative escape routes Escape routes that are sufficiently separated by direction and space or by fire resisting construction to ensure that one is still available if the other is affected by fire.
text-fixed: Alternative escape routes Escape routes that are sufficiently separated by direction and space or by fire resisting construction to ensure that one is still available if the other is affected by fire.

text: A second stair, balcony or flat roof which enables a person to reach a place free from danger from fire is considered an alternative escape route for the purposes of a dwellinghouse.
text-fixed: A second stair, balcony or flat roof which enables a person to reach a place free from danger from fire is considered an alternative escape route for the purposes of a dwellinghouse.

text: Alternative exit One of two or more exits, each of which is separate from the other.
text-fixed: Alternative exit One of two or more exits, each of which is separate from the other.

text: Appliance ventilation duct A duct to deliver combustion air to a gas appliance.
text-fixed: Appliance ventilation duct A duct to deliver combustion air to a gas appliance.

text: A continuous space that passes through one or more structural floors within a building, not necessarily vertically.
text-fixed: A continuous space that passes through one or more structural floors within a building, not necessarily vertically.

text: Enclosed lift wells, enclosed escalator wells, building services ducts and stairs are not classified as atria.
text-fixed: Enclosed lift wells, enclosed escalator wells, building services ducts and stairs are not classified as atria.

text: Automatic release mechanism A device that normally holds a door open, but closes it automatically if any one of the following occurs.
text-fixed: Automatic release mechanism A device that normally holds a door open, but closes it automatically if any one of the following occurs.

text: • Smoke is detected by an automatic device of a suitable nature and quality in a suitable location.
text-fixed: Smoke is detected by an automatic device of a suitable nature and quality in a suitable location.

text: • A hand-operated switch, fitted in a suitable position, is operated.
text-fixed: A hand-operated switch, fitted in a suitable position, is operated.

text: • The electricity supply to the device, apparatus or switch fails.
text-fixed: The electricity supply to the device, apparatus or switch fails.

text: • The fire alarm system, if any, is operated.
text-fixed: The fire alarm system, if any, is operated.

text: Basement storey A storey with a floor that, at some point, is more than 1200mm below the highest level of ground beside the outside walls.
text-fixed: Basement storey A storey with a floor that, at some point, is more than 1200mm below the highest level of ground beside the outside walls.

text: Boundary The boundary of the land that belongs to a building, or, where the land abuts a road, railway, canal or river, the centre line of that road, railway, canal or river.
text-fixed: Boundary The boundary of the land that belongs to a building, or, where the land abuts a road, railway, canal or river, the centre line of that road, railway, canal or river.

text: Building Any permanent or temporary building but not any other kind of structure or erection.
text-fixed: Building Any permanent or temporary building but not any other kind of structure or erection.

text: A reference to a building includes a reference to part of a building.
text-fixed: A reference to a building includes a reference to part of a building.

text: Building control body A term that includes both local authority building control and approved inspectors.
text-fixed: Building control body A term that includes both local authority building control and approved inspectors.

text: Cavity A space enclosed by elements of a building (including a suspended ceiling) or contained within an element, but that is not a room, cupboard, circulation space, protected shaft, or space within a flue, chute, duct, pipe or conduit.
text-fixed: Cavity A space enclosed by elements of a building (including a suspended ceiling) or contained within an element, but that is not a room, cupboard, circulation space, protected shaft, or space within a flue, chute, duct, pipe or conduit.

text: Cavity barrier A construction within a cavity, other than a smoke curtain, to perform either of the following functions.
text-fixed: Cavity barrier A construction within a cavity, other than a smoke curtain, to perform either of the following functions.

text: • Close a cavity to stop smoke or flame entering.
text-fixed: Close a cavity to stop smoke or flame entering.

text: • Restrict the movement of smoke or flame within a cavity.
text-fixed: Restrict the movement of smoke or flame within a cavity.

text: Ceiling Part of a building that encloses a room, protected shaft or circulation space and is exposed overhead.
text-fixed: Ceiling Part of a building that encloses a room, protected shaft or circulation space and is exposed overhead.

text: The soffit of a rooflight, but not the frame, is included as part of the surface of the ceiling.
text-fixed: The soffit of a rooflight, but not the frame, is included as part of the surface of the ceiling.

text: An upstand below a rooflight is considered as a wall.
text-fixed: An upstand below a rooflight is considered as a wall.

text: Circulation space A space (including a protected stairway) mainly used as a means of access between a room and an exit from the building or compartment.
text-fixed: Circulation space A space (including a protected stairway) mainly used as a means of access between a room and an exit from the building or compartment.

text: Common balcony A walkway, open to the air on one or more sides, that forms part of the escape route from more than one flat.
text-fixed: Common balcony A walkway, open to the air on one or more sides, that forms part of the escape route from more than one flat.

text: Common stair An escape stair that serves more than one flat.
text-fixed: Common stair An escape stair that serves more than one flat.

text: A building or part of a building, comprising one or more rooms, spaces or storeys, that is constructed to prevent the spread of fire to or from another part of the same building or an adjoining building.
text-fixed: A building or part of a building, comprising one or more rooms, spaces or storeys, that is constructed to prevent the spread of fire to or from another part of the same building or an adjoining building.

text: A roof space above the top storey of a compartment is included in that compartment.
text-fixed: A roof space above the top storey of a compartment is included in that compartment.

text: Compartment wall or floor A fire resisting wall or floor to separate one fire compartment from another.
text-fixed: Compartment wall or floor A fire resisting wall or floor to separate one fire compartment from another.

text: Provisions relating to construction are given in Section 8.
text-fixed: Provisions relating to construction are given in Section 8.

text: Corridor access A design of a building containing flats, in which each flat is approached via a common horizontal internal access or circulation space, which may include a common entrance hall.
text-fixed: Corridor access A design of a building containing flats, in which each flat is approached via a common horizontal internal access or circulation space, which may include a common entrance hall.

text: Curtain Part of a solar shading device which is set in motion by the operating system and fulfils the purpose of a blind, awning or shutter.
text-fixed: Curtain Part of a solar shading device which is set in motion by the operating system and fulfils the purpose of a blind, awning or shutter.

text: Dead end An area from which escape is possible in one direction only.
text-fixed: Dead end An area from which escape is possible in one direction only.

text: Direct distance The shortest distance from any point within the floor area to the nearest storey exit, measured within the external enclosures of the building, and ignoring walls, partitions and fittings other than the enclosing walls and partitions to protected stairways.
text-fixed: Direct distance The shortest distance from any point within the floor area to the nearest storey exit, measured within the external enclosures of the building, and ignoring walls, partitions and fittings other than the enclosing walls and partitions to protected stairways.

text: Dwelling Includes a dwellinghouse and a flat.
text-fixed: Dwelling Includes a dwellinghouse and a flat.

text: A dwelling is a unit where one or more people live (whether or not as a sole or main residence) in either of the following situations.
text-fixed: A dwelling is a unit where one or more people live (whether or not as a sole or main residence) in either of the following situations.

text: • A single person or people living together as a family.
text-fixed: A single person or people living together as a family.

text: • A maximum of six people living together as a single household, including where care is provided for residents.
text-fixed: A maximum of six people living together as a single household, including where care is provided for residents.

text: Dwellinghouse Does not include a flat or a building containing a flat.
text-fixed: Dwellinghouse Does not include a flat or a building containing a flat.

text: Element of structure Any of the following.
text-fixed: Element of structure Any of the following.

text: • A member that forms part of the structural frame of a building, or any other beam or column.
text-fixed: A member that forms part of the structural frame of a building, or any other beam or column.

text: • A loadbearing wall or loadbearing part of a wall.
text-fixed: A loadbearing wall or loadbearing part of a wall.

text: • A gallery (but not a loading gallery, fly gallery, stage grid, lighting bridge, or any gallery provided for similar purposes or for maintenance and repair).
text-fixed: A gallery (but not a loading gallery, fly gallery, stage grid, lighting bridge, or any gallery provided for similar purposes or for maintenance and repair).

text: • An external wall.
text-fixed: An external wall.

text: • A compartment wall (including a wall that is common to two or more buildings).
text-fixed: A compartment wall (including a wall that is common to two or more buildings).

text: However, see the guidance to requirement B3, paragraph 7.3, for a list of structures that are not considered to be elements of structure.
text-fixed: However, see the guidance to requirement B3, paragraph 7.3, for a list of structures that are not considered to be elements of structure.

text: Emergency lighting Lighting for use when the power supply to the normal lighting fails.
text-fixed: Emergency lighting Lighting for use when the power supply to the normal lighting fails.

text: Escape lighting The part of the emergency lighting that is provided to ensure that the escape route is illuminated at all material times.
text-fixed: Escape lighting The part of the emergency lighting that is provided to ensure that the escape route is illuminated at all material times.

text: Escape route The route along which people can escape from any point in a building to a final exit.
text-fixed: Escape route The route along which people can escape from any point in a building to a final exit.

text: Evacuation lift A lift that may be used to evacuate people in a fire.
text-fixed: Evacuation lift A lift that may be used to evacuate people in a fire.

text: Exit passageway A protected passageway that connects a protected stairway to a final exit.
text-fixed: Exit passageway A protected passageway that connects a protected stairway to a final exit.

text: Exit passageways should be protected to the same standard as the stairway they serve.
text-fixed: Exit passageways should be protected to the same standard as the stairway they serve.

text: External wall The external wall of a building includes all of the following.
text-fixed: External wall The external wall of a building includes all of the following.

text: • Anything located within any space forming part of the wall.
text-fixed: Anything located within any space forming part of the wall.

text: • Any decoration or other finish applied to any external (but not internal) surface forming part of the wall.
text-fixed: Any decoration or other finish applied to any external (but not internal) surface forming part of the wall.

text: • Any windows and doors in the wall.
text-fixed: Any windows and doors in the wall.

text: • Any part of a roof pitched at an angle of more than 70 degrees to the horizontal if that part of the roof adjoins a space within the building to which persons have access, but not access only for the purpose of carrying out repairs or maintenance.
text-fixed: Any part of a roof pitched at an angle of more than 70 degrees to the horizontal if that part of the roof adjoins a space within the building to which persons have access, but not access only for the purpose of carrying out repairs or maintenance.

text: Final exit The end of an escape route from a building that gives direct access to a street, passageway, walkway or open space, and is sited to ensure that people rapidly disperse away from the building so that they are no longer in danger from fire and/or smoke.
text-fixed: Final exit The end of an escape route from a building that gives direct access to a street, passageway, walkway or open space, and is sited to ensure that people rapidly disperse away from the building so that they are no longer in danger from fire and/or smoke.

text: Windows are not acceptable as final exits.
text-fixed: Windows are not acceptable as final exits.

text: Fire alarm system Combination of components for giving an audible and/or other perceptible warning of fire.
text-fixed: Fire alarm system Combination of components for giving an audible and/or other perceptible warning of fire.

text: Fire damper A mechanical or intumescent device within a duct or ventilation opening that operates automatically and is designed to resist the spread of fire.
text-fixed: Fire damper A mechanical or intumescent device within a duct or ventilation opening that operates automatically and is designed to resist the spread of fire.

text: Fire and smoke damper A fire damper which, in addition to the performance of the fire damper, resists the spread of smoke.
text-fixed: Fire and smoke damper A fire damper which, in addition to the performance of the fire damper, resists the spread of smoke.

text: Fire doorset A door or shutter which, together with its frame and furniture as installed in a building, is intended (when closed) to resist the spread of fire and/or gaseous products of combustion and meets specified performance criteria to those ends.
text-fixed: Fire doorset A door or shutter which, together with its frame and furniture as installed in a building, is intended (when closed) to resist the spread of fire and/or gaseous products of combustion and meets specified performance criteria to those ends.

text: A fire doorset may have one or more leaves.
text-fixed: A fire doorset may have one or more leaves.

text: The term includes a cover or other form of protection to an opening in a fire resisting wall or floor, or in a structure that surrounds a protected shaft.
text-fixed: The term includes a cover or other form of protection to an opening in a fire resisting wall or floor, or in a structure that surrounds a protected shaft.

text: A fire doorset is a complete door assembly, assembled on site or delivered as a completed assembly, consisting of the door frame, leaf or leaves, essential hardware, edge seals and glazing, and any integral side panels or fanlight panels in an associated door screen.
text-fixed: A fire doorset is a complete door assembly, assembled on site or delivered as a completed assembly, consisting of the door frame, leaf or leaves, essential hardware, edge seals and glazing, and any integral side panels or fanlight panels in an associated door screen.

text: Firefighting lift A lift with additional protection and with controls that enable it to be used by the fire and rescue service when fighting a fire.
text-fixed: Firefighting lift A lift with additional protection and with controls that enable it to be used by the fire and rescue service when fighting a fire.

text: Firefighting lobby A protected lobby that provides access from a firefighting stair to the accommodation area and to any associated firefighting lift.
text-fixed: Firefighting lobby A protected lobby that provides access from a firefighting stair to the accommodation area and to any associated firefighting lift.

text: Firefighting shaft A protected enclosure that contains a firefighting stair, firefighting lobbies and, if provided, a firefighting lift together with its machine room.
text-fixed: Firefighting shaft A protected enclosure that contains a firefighting stair, firefighting lobbies and, if provided, a firefighting lift together with its machine room.

text: Firefighting stair A protected stairway that connects to the accommodation area through only a firefighting lobby.
text-fixed: Firefighting stair A protected stairway that connects to the accommodation area through only a firefighting lobby.

text: The ability of a component or a building to satisfy, for a stated period of time, some or all of the appropriate criteria given in the relevant standard.
text-fixed: The ability of a component or a building to satisfy, for a stated period of time, some or all of the appropriate criteria given in the relevant standard.

text: Fire-separating element A compartment wall, compartment floor, cavity barrier and construction that encloses a protected escape route and/or a place of special fire hazard.
text-fixed: Fire-separating element A compartment wall, compartment floor, cavity barrier and construction that encloses a protected escape route and/or a place of special fire hazard.

text: A seal provided to close an imperfection of fit or design tolerance between elements or components, to restrict the spread of fire and smoke.
text-fixed: A seal provided to close an imperfection of fit or design tolerance between elements or components, to restrict the spread of fire and smoke.

text: Flat A flat is a separate and self-contained premises constructed or adapted for use for residential purposes and forming part of a building from some other part of which it is divided horizontally.
text-fixed: Flat A flat is a separate and self-contained premises constructed or adapted for use for residential purposes and forming part of a building from some other part of which it is divided horizontally.

text: Gallery A floor or balcony that does not extend across the full extent of a building’s footprint and is open to the floor below.
text-fixed: Gallery A floor or balcony that does not extend across the full extent of a building’s footprint and is open to the floor below.

text: Habitable room A room used, or intended to be used, for people to live in (including, for the purposes of Approved Document B Volumes 1 and 2, a kitchen, but not a bathroom).
text-fixed: Habitable room A room used, or intended to be used, for people to live in (including, for the purposes of Approved Document B Volumes 1 and 2, a kitchen, but not a bathroom).

text: Height (of a building or storey for the purposes of Approved Document B Volumes 1 and 2) • Height of a building is measured as shown in Appendix D, Diagram D4.
text-fixed: Height (of a building or storey for the purposes of Approved Document B Volumes 1 and 2)  Height of a building is measured as shown in Appendix D, Diagram D4.

text: • Height of the floor of the top storey above ground level is measured as shown in Appendix D, Diagram D6.
text-fixed: Height of the floor of the top storey above ground level is measured as shown in Appendix D, Diagram D6.

text: Inner room Room from which escape is possible only by passing through another room (the access room).
text-fixed: Inner room Room from which escape is possible only by passing through another room (the access room).

text: A floor that is supported by a structural floor, but with an intervening cavity to house services.
text-fixed: A floor that is supported by a structural floor, but with an intervening cavity to house services.

text: Live/work unit A flat that is a workplace for people who live there, its occupants, and for people who do not live on the premises.
text-fixed: Live/work unit A flat that is a workplace for people who live there, its occupants, and for people who do not live on the premises.

text: Means of escape Structural means that provide one or more safe routes for people to go, during a fire, from any point in the building to a place of safety.
text-fixed: Means of escape Structural means that provide one or more safe routes for people to go, during a fire, from any point in the building to a place of safety.

text: Measurement • Width of a doorway, cubic capacity, area, height of a building and number of storeys are measured as shown in Appendix D, Diagrams D1 to D6.
text-fixed: Measurement  Width of a doorway, cubic capacity, area, height of a building and number of storeys are measured as shown in Appendix D, Diagrams D1 to D6.

text: • Occupant number, travel distance, escape route and stairs are measured as described in Appendix D, paragraphs D1 to D4.
text-fixed: Occupant number, travel distance, escape route and stairs are measured as described in Appendix D, paragraphs D1 to D4.

text: Notional boundary A boundary presumed to exist between two buildings on the same site.
text-fixed: Notional boundary A boundary presumed to exist between two buildings on the same site.

text: For the purposes of this document there is a distinction between open spatial planning and an atrium space.
text-fixed: For the purposes of this document there is a distinction between open spatial planning and an atrium space.

text: The maximum aggregate plan perimeter, found by vertical projection onto a horizontal plane.
text-fixed: The maximum aggregate plan perimeter, found by vertical projection onto a horizontal plane.

text: Pipe Includes pipe fittings and accessories.
text-fixed: Pipe Includes pipe fittings and accessories.

text: The definition of ‘pipe’ excludes a flue pipe and a pipe used for ventilating purposes, other than a ventilating pipe for an above-ground drainage system.
text-fixed: The definition of ‘pipe’ excludes a flue pipe and a pipe used for ventilating purposes, other than a ventilating pipe for an above-ground drainage system.

text: Place of special fire hazard A room such as any of the following.
text-fixed: Place of special fire hazard A room such as any of the following.

text: • Oil-filled transformer room.
text-fixed: Oil-filled transformer room.

text: • Switch gear room.
text-fixed: Switch gear room.

text: • Storage space for fuel or other highly flammable substance(s).
text-fixed: Storage space for fuel or other highly flammable substance(s).

text: • Room that houses a fixed internal combustion engine.
text-fixed: Room that houses a fixed internal combustion engine.

text: Protected circuit An electrical circuit that is protected against fire.
text-fixed: Protected circuit An electrical circuit that is protected against fire.

text: Protected corridor/lobby A corridor or lobby that is adequately protected from fire in adjoining areas by fire resisting construction.
text-fixed: Protected corridor/lobby A corridor or lobby that is adequately protected from fire in adjoining areas by fire resisting construction.

text: Protected entrance hall/landing A circulation area, consisting of a hall or space in a flat, that is enclosed with fire resisting construction other than an external wall of a building.
text-fixed: Protected entrance hall/landing A circulation area, consisting of a hall or space in a flat, that is enclosed with fire resisting construction other than an external wall of a building.

text: Protected shaft A shaft that enables people, air or objects to pass from one compartment to another, and which is enclosed with fire resisting construction.
text-fixed: Protected shaft A shaft that enables people, air or objects to pass from one compartment to another, and which is enclosed with fire resisting construction.

text: Protected stairway A stair that leads to a final exit to a place of safety and that is adequately enclosed with fire resisting construction.
text-fixed: Protected stairway A stair that leads to a final exit to a place of safety and that is adequately enclosed with fire resisting construction.

text: Included in the definition is any exit passageway between the foot of the stair and the final exit.
text-fixed: Included in the definition is any exit passageway between the foot of the stair and the final exit.

text: Purpose group A classification of a building according to the purpose to which it is intended to be put.
text-fixed: Purpose group A classification of a building according to the purpose to which it is intended to be put.

text: or coincides with, and that is parallel or at an angle of a maximum of 80 degrees to that side of the building.
text-fixed: or coincides with, and that is parallel or at an angle of a maximum of 80 degrees to that side of the building.

text: Rooflight A dome light, lantern light, skylight, ridge light, glazed barrel vault or other element to admit daylight through a roof.
text-fixed: Rooflight A dome light, lantern light, skylight, ridge light, glazed barrel vault or other element to admit daylight through a roof.

text: Room An enclosed space within a building that is not used solely as a circulation space.
text-fixed: Room An enclosed space within a building that is not used solely as a circulation space.

text: The term includes not only conventional rooms, but also cupboards that are not fittings and large spaces such as warehouses and auditoria.
text-fixed: The term includes not only conventional rooms, but also cupboards that are not fittings and large spaces such as warehouses and auditoria.

text: The term does not include cavities such as ducts, ceiling cavities and roof spaces.
text-fixed: The term does not include cavities such as ducts, ceiling cavities and roof spaces.

text: School A place of education for children between 2 and 19 years old.
text-fixed: School A place of education for children between 2 and 19 years old.

text: The term includes nursery schools, primary schools and secondary schools as defined in the Education Act 1996.
text-fixed: The term includes nursery schools, primary schools and secondary schools as defined in the Education Act 1996.

text: Self-closing device A device that closes a door, when open at any angle, against a door frame.
text-fixed: Self-closing device A device that closes a door, when open at any angle, against a door frame.

text: If the door is in a cavity barrier, rising butt hinges (which are different from the self-closing device mentioned above) are acceptable.
text-fixed: If the door is in a cavity barrier, rising butt hinges (which are different from the self-closing device mentioned above) are acceptable.

text: Separated part (of a building) Part of a building that is separated from another part of the same building by a compartment wall.
text-fixed: Separated part (of a building) Part of a building that is separated from another part of the same building by a compartment wall.

text: The wall runs the full height of the part and is in one vertical plane.
text-fixed: The wall runs the full height of the part and is in one vertical plane.

text: Sheltered housing Includes two or more dwellings in the same building or on adjacent sites, designed and constructed as residential accommodation for vulnerable or elderly people who receive, or will receive, a support service.
text-fixed: Sheltered housing Includes two or more dwellings in the same building or on adjacent sites, designed and constructed as residential accommodation for vulnerable or elderly people who receive, or will receive, a support service.

text: Single storey building A building that consists of a ground storey only.
text-fixed: Single storey building A building that consists of a ground storey only.

text: Basements are not counted as storeys in a building (see Appendix D).
text-fixed: Basements are not counted as storeys in a building (see Appendix D).

text: A separated part that consists of a ground storey only, with a roof to which access is only provided for repair or maintenance, may be treated as a single storey building.
text-fixed: A separated part that consists of a ground storey only, with a roof to which access is only provided for repair or maintenance, may be treated as a single storey building.

text: The land occupied by the building, up to the boundaries with land in other ownership.
text-fixed: The land occupied by the building, up to the boundaries with land in other ownership.

text: Solar shading device A device attached to the external surface of an external wall for reducing heat gain within a building by shading or deflecting sunlight.
text-fixed: Solar shading device A device attached to the external surface of an external wall for reducing heat gain within a building by shading or deflecting sunlight.

text: Specified attachment Includes any of the following.
text-fixed: Specified attachment Includes any of the following.

text: • A balcony attached to an external wall.
text-fixed: A balcony attached to an external wall.

text: • A device for reducing heat gain within a building by deflecting sunlight which is attached to an external wall.
text-fixed: A device for reducing heat gain within a building by deflecting sunlight which is attached to an external wall.

text: • A solar panel attached to an external wall.
text-fixed: A solar panel attached to an external wall.

text: Storey Includes any of the following.
text-fixed: Storey Includes any of the following.

text: • Any gallery in an assembly building (purpose group 5).
text-fixed: Any gallery in an assembly building (purpose group 5).

text: • Any gallery in any other type of building if its area is more than half that of the space into which it projects.
text-fixed: Any gallery in any other type of building if its area is more than half that of the space into which it projects.

text: • A roof, unless it is accessible only for maintenance and repair.
text-fixed: A roof, unless it is accessible only for maintenance and repair.

text: The building is regarded as a multi-storey building if both of the following apply.
text-fixed: The building is regarded as a multi-storey building if both of the following apply.

text: • There is more than one gallery.
text-fixed: There is more than one gallery.

text: • The total aggregate area of all the galleries in one space is more than half the floor area of that space.
text-fixed: The total aggregate area of all the galleries in one space is more than half the floor area of that space.

text: Storey exit A final exit, or a doorway that gives direct access into a protected stairway, firefighting lobby or external escape route.
text-fixed: Storey exit A final exit, or a doorway that gives direct access into a protected stairway, firefighting lobby or external escape route.

text: If an institutional building is planned to enable progressive horizontal evacuation, a door in a compartment wall is considered a storey exit for the purposes of requirement B1.
text-fixed: If an institutional building is planned to enable progressive horizontal evacuation, a door in a compartment wall is considered a storey exit for the purposes of requirement B1.

text: A ceiling suspended below a floor that adds to the fire resistance of the floor.
text-fixed: A ceiling suspended below a floor that adds to the fire resistance of the floor.

text: Thermoplastic material Any synthetic polymeric material that has a softening point below 200°C if tested to BS EN ISO 306 Method A120.
text-fixed: Thermoplastic material Any synthetic polymeric material that has a softening point below 200°C if tested to BS EN ISO 306 Method A120.

text: Specimens for this test may be fabricated from the original polymer where the thickness of material of the end product is less than 2.5mm.
text-fixed: Specimens for this test may be fabricated from the original polymer where the thickness of material of the end product is less than 2.5mm.

text: The distance that a person would travel from any point within the floor area to the nearest storey exit, determined by the layout of walls, partitions and fittings.
text-fixed: The distance that a person would travel from any point within the floor area to the nearest storey exit, determined by the layout of walls, partitions and fittings.

text: All of the following are classed as unprotected areas.
text-fixed: All of the following are classed as unprotected areas.

text: • Any part of the external wall that has less than the relevant fire resistance set out in Section 13.
text-fixed: Any part of the external wall that has less than the relevant fire resistance set out in Section 13.

text: • Any part of the external wall constructed of material more than 1mm thick if that material does not have a class B-s3, d2 rating or better, which is attached or applied, whether for cladding or any other purpose.
text-fixed: Any part of the external wall constructed of material more than 1mm thick if that material does not have a class B-s3, d2 rating or better, which is attached or applied, whether for cladding or any other purpose.

text: • Windows, doors or other openings.
text-fixed: Windows, doors or other openings.

text: This does not include windows that are designed and glazed to give the necessary level of fire resistance and that are not openable.
text-fixed: This does not include windows that are designed and glazed to give the necessary level of fire resistance and that are not openable.

text: Recessed car parking areas as shown in Diagram A1 should not be regarded as unprotected areas.
text-fixed: Recessed car parking areas as shown in Diagram A1 should not be regarded as unprotected areas.

text: both of the following:
text-fixed: The parking area should be both of the following:

text: speciﬁed in Table B4 in Appendix B.
text-fixed: Separated from the remainder of the building by a compartment wall(s) and floor(s) having not less than the period of fire resistance specified in Table B4 in Appendix B.

text: Much of the guidance in this document is given in terms of performance classifications in relation to British or European Standards.
text-fixed: Much of the guidance in this document is given in terms of performance classifications in relation to British or European Standards.

text: In such cases, it will be necessary to demonstrate that a system or product can meet the relevant performance classification.
text-fixed: In such cases, it will be necessary to demonstrate that a system or product can meet the relevant performance classification.

text: This will be achieved if the system or product complies with one of the following.
text-fixed: This will be achieved if the system or product complies with one of the following.

text: They should be in accordance with a specification or design that has been shown by a specific test to be capable of meeting that performance classification.
text-fixed: They should be in accordance with a specification or design that has been shown by a specific test to be capable of meeting that performance classification.

text: They should have been designed by using relevant design standards in order to meet that performance classification.
text-fixed: They should have been designed by using relevant design standards in order to meet that performance classification.

text: They should have been assessed by applying relevant test evidence, in lieu of carrying out a specific test, as being capable of meeting that performance classification.
text-fixed: They should have been assessed by applying relevant test evidence, in lieu of carrying out a specific test, as being capable of meeting that performance classification.

text: Some products are subject to Classification Without Further Testing (CWFT).
text-fixed: Some products are subject to Classification Without Further Testing (CWFT).

text: For the purposes of this approved document, such products can be considered to have been shown to be capable of meeting a performance specification as per paragraph B1a.
text-fixed: For the purposes of this approved document, such products can be considered to have been shown to be capable of meeting a performance specification as per paragraph B1a.

text: Any test evidence used to demonstrate the fire performance classification of a product or system should be carefully checked to ensure that it is applicable to the intended use.
text-fixed: Any test evidence used to demonstrate the fire performance classification of a product or system should be carefully checked to ensure that it is applicable to the intended use.

text: Small differences in detail, such as fixing method, joints, dimensions, the introduction of insulation materials and air gaps (ventilated or not), can significantly affect the performance.
text-fixed: Small differences in detail, such as fixing method, joints, dimensions, the introduction of insulation materials and air gaps (ventilated or not), can significantly affect the performance.

text: Assessments should not be regarded as a way to avoid a test where one is necessary.
text-fixed: Assessments should not be regarded as a way to avoid a test where one is necessary.

text: Assessments should only be carried out where sufficient relevant test evidence is available.
text-fixed: Assessments should only be carried out where sufficient relevant test evidence is available.

text: Relevant test evidence is unlikely to be provided by test standards which have different classification criteria.
text-fixed: Relevant test evidence is unlikely to be provided by test standards which have different classification criteria.

text: Where it is proposed to assess the classification of a product or system in lieu of carrying out a specific test (as in paragraph B1c), this should be done in accordance with the relevant standard for extended application for the test in question and should include details of the test evidence that has been used to support the assessment.
text-fixed: Where it is proposed to assess the classification of a product or system in lieu of carrying out a specific test (as in paragraph B1c), this should be done in accordance with the relevant standard for extended application for the test in question and should include details of the test evidence that has been used to support the assessment.

text: For performance classifications where there is no specific standard for extended application, assessment reports should be produced in accordance with the principles of BS EN 15725 and should include details of the test evidence that has been used to support the assessment.
text-fixed: For performance classifications where there is no specific standard for extended application, assessment reports should be produced in accordance with the principles of BS EN 15725 and should include details of the test evidence that has been used to support the assessment.

text: Further information on best practice is provided in the Passive Fire Protection Forum’s Guide to Undertaking Technical Assessments of the Fire Performance of Construction Products Based on Fire Test Evidence.
text-fixed: Further information on best practice is provided in the Passive Fire Protection Forum’s Guide to Undertaking Technical Assessments of the Fire Performance of Construction Products Based on Fire Test Evidence.

text: Regulation 7(2) limits components used in or on the external walls of certain buildings to materials achieving class A2-s1, d0 or class A1 (see Section 12).
text-fixed: Regulation 7(2) limits components used in or on the external walls of certain buildings to materials achieving class A2-s1, d0 or class A1 (see Section 12).

text: Assessments cannot be used to demonstrate compliance with this requirement.
text-fixed: Assessments cannot be used to demonstrate compliance with this requirement.

text: Tests and assessments should be carried out by organisations with the necessary expertise.
text-fixed: Tests and assessments should be carried out by organisations with the necessary expertise.

text: Products Regulation or laboratories accredited by the United Kingdom Accreditation Service (UKAS) for the relevant test standard can be assumed to have the necessary expertise.
text-fixed: Products Regulation or laboratories accredited by the United Kingdom Accreditation Service (UKAS) for the relevant test standard can be assumed to have the necessary expertise.

text: Standard fire tests do not directly measure fire hazard.
text-fixed: Standard fire tests do not directly measure fire hazard.

text: They measure or assess the response of a material or system to exposure to one or more aspects of fire conditions.
text-fixed: They measure or assess the response of a material or system to exposure to one or more aspects of fire conditions.

text: Performance in fire tests is only one of a number of factors that should be taken into account.
text-fixed: Performance in fire tests is only one of a number of factors that should be taken into account.

text: Reaction to fire relates to the degree to which a product will contribute, by its own decomposition, to a fire under specified conditions.
text-fixed: Reaction to fire relates to the degree to which a product will contribute, by its own decomposition, to a fire under specified conditions.

text: Products, other than floorings, are classified as A1, A2, B, C, D, E or F (with class A1 being the highest performance and F being the lowest) in accordance with BS EN 13501-1.
text-fixed: Products, other than floorings, are classified as A1, A2, B, C, D, E or F (with class A1 being the highest performance and F being the lowest) in accordance with BS EN 13501-1.

text: Class F is assigned when a product fails to attain class E. Untested products cannot be classified in accordance with BS EN 13501-1.
text-fixed: Class F is assigned when a product fails to attain class E. Untested products cannot be classified in accordance with BS EN 13501-1.

text: Materials covered by the Classification Without Further Testing (CWFT) process can be found by accessing the European Commission’s website https://eur-lex.europa.eu/.
text-fixed: Materials covered by the Classification Without Further Testing (CWFT) process can be found by accessing the European Commission’s website https://eur-lex.europa.eu/.

text: The classes of reaction to fire performance of A2, B, C, D and E are accompanied by additional classifications related to the production of smoke (s1, s2, s3), with s1 indicating the lowest production, and/or flaming droplets/particles (d0, d1, d2), with d0 indicating the lowest production.
text-fixed: The classes of reaction to fire performance of A2, B, C, D and E are accompanied by additional classifications related to the production of smoke (s1, s2, s3), with s1 indicating the lowest production, and/or flaming droplets/particles (d0, d1, d2), with d0 indicating the lowest production.

text: When a classification includes s3, d2 this means that there is no limit set for smoke production and/or flaming droplets/particles.
text-fixed: When a classification includes s3, d2 this means that there is no limit set for smoke production and/or flaming droplets/particles.

text: To reduce the testing burden on manufacturers, BS EN 13238 defines a number of standard substrates that produce test results representative of different end use applications.
text-fixed: To reduce the testing burden on manufacturers, BS EN 13238 defines a number of standard substrates that produce test results representative of different end use applications.

text: The classification for reaction to fire achieved during testing is only valid when the product is used within this field of application, i.e. when the product is fixed to a substrate of that class in its end use.
text-fixed: The classification for reaction to fire achieved during testing is only valid when the product is used within this field of application, i.e. when the product is fixed to a substrate of that class in its end use.

text: The standard substrate selected for testing should take account of the intended end use applications (field of application) of the product and represent end use substrates that have a density of a minimum of 75% of the standard substrate’s nominal density.
text-fixed: The standard substrate selected for testing should take account of the intended end use applications (field of application) of the product and represent end use substrates that have a density of a minimum of 75% of the standard substrate’s nominal density.

text: Standard substrates include gypsum plasterboard (BS EN 520) with a density of 700+/-100kg/m3, calcium silicate board (BS EN 14306) 870+/-50kg/m3 and fibre-cement board 1800+/-200kg/m3.
text-fixed: Standard substrates include gypsum plasterboard (BS EN 520) with a density of 700+/-100kg/m3, calcium silicate board (BS EN 14306) 870+/-50kg/m3 and fibre-cement board 1800+/-200kg/m3.

text: Standard calcium silicate board is not representative of gypsum plasterboard end use (due to the paper layer), but would be representative of most gypsum plasters (with densities of more than 650kg/m3).
text-fixed: Standard calcium silicate board is not representative of gypsum plasterboard end use (due to the paper layer), but would be representative of most gypsum plasters (with densities of more than 650kg/m3).

text: Classifications based on tests using a plasterboard substrate would also be acceptable for products bonded to a gypsum plaster end use substrate.
text-fixed: Classifications based on tests using a plasterboard substrate would also be acceptable for products bonded to a gypsum plaster end use substrate.

text: This document uses the European classification system for reaction to fire set out in BS EN 13501-1; however, there may be some products lawfully on the market using the classification system set out in previous editions.
text-fixed: This document uses the European classification system for reaction to fire set out in BS EN 13501-1; however, there may be some products lawfully on the market using the classification system set out in previous editions.

text: Where this is the case, Table B1 can be used for the purposes of this document.
text-fixed: Where this is the case, Table B1 can be used for the purposes of this document.

text: Material that, when tested to BS 476-11, does not either:
text-fixed: Material that, when tested to BS 476-11, does not either:

text: Material that meets either of the following.

text: Thermoplastic material is any synthetic polymeric material that has a softening point below 200°C if tested to BS EN ISO 306 Method A120.
text-fixed: Thermoplastic material is any synthetic polymeric material that has a softening point below 200°C if tested to BS EN ISO 306 Method A120.

text: Products formed from these materials cannot always be classified in the normal way.

text: A thermoplastic material alone when used as a lining to a wall or ceiling cannot be assumed to protect a substrate.
text-fixed: A thermoplastic material alone when used as a lining to a wall or ceiling cannot be assumed to protect a substrate.

text: The surface rating of both thermoplastic material and substrate must therefore meet the required classification.
text-fixed: The surface rating of both thermoplastic material and substrate must therefore meet the required classification.

text: If, however, the thermoplastic material is fully bonded to a non-thermoplastic substrate, then only the surface rating of the composite needs to meet the required classification.
text-fixed: If, however, the thermoplastic material is fully bonded to a non-thermoplastic substrate, then only the surface rating of the composite needs to meet the required classification.

text: Performance of the resistance of roofs to external fire exposure is measured in terms of penetration through the roof construction and the spread of flame over its surface.
text-fixed: Performance of the resistance of roofs to external fire exposure is measured in terms of penetration through the roof construction and the spread of flame over its surface.

text: Roof constructions are classified within the European system as BROOF(t4), CROOF(t4), DROOF(t4), EROOF(t4) or FROOF(t4) in accordance with BS EN 13501-5. BROOF(t4) indicates the highest performance and FROOF(t4) the lowest.

text: Common to all of the provisions of Part B of the Building Regulations is the property of fire resistance.
text-fixed: Common to all of the provisions of Part B of the Building Regulations is the property of fire resistance.

text: Fire resistance is a measure of one or more of the following.
text-fixed: Fire resistance is a measure of one or more of the following.

text: Resistance to collapse (loadbearing capacity), which applies to loadbearing elements only, denoted R in the European classification of the resistance to fire performance.
text-fixed: Resistance to collapse (loadbearing capacity), which applies to loadbearing elements only, denoted R in the European classification of the resistance to fire performance.

text: Resistance to fire penetration (integrity), denoted E in the European classification of the resistance to fire performance.
text-fixed: Resistance to fire penetration (integrity), denoted E in the European classification of the resistance to fire performance.

text: Resistance to the transfer of excessive heat (insulation), denoted I in the European classification of the resistance to fire performance.
text-fixed: Resistance to the transfer of excessive heat (insulation), denoted I in the European classification of the resistance to fire performance.

text: The standards of fire resistance necessary for a particular building are based on assumptions about the severity of fires and the consequences should an element fail.
text-fixed: The standards of fire resistance necessary for a particular building are based on assumptions about the severity of fires and the consequences should an element fail.

text: Fire severity is estimated in very broad terms from the use of the building (its purpose group), on the assumption that the building contents (which constitute the fire load) are similar for buildings with the same use.
text-fixed: Fire severity is estimated in very broad terms from the use of the building (its purpose group), on the assumption that the building contents (which constitute the fire load) are similar for buildings with the same use.

text: Because the use of buildings may change, a precise estimate of fire severity based on the fire load due to a particular use may be misleading.
text-fixed: Because the use of buildings may change, a precise estimate of fire severity based on the fire load due to a particular use may be misleading.

text: Therefore if a fire engineering approach of this kind is adopted, the likelihood that the fire load may change in the future needs to be considered.
text-fixed: Therefore if a fire engineering approach of this kind is adopted, the likelihood that the fire load may change in the future needs to be considered.

text: Performance in terms of the fire resistance to be achieved by elements of structure, doors and other forms of construction is classified in accordance with one of the following.
