text: All fire doorsets should have the performance shown in Table C1, based on one of the following.
text-fixed: All fire doorsets should have the performance shown in Table C1, based on one of the following.

text: Fire resistance in terms of integrity, for a period of minutes, when tested to BS 476-22, e.g. FD 30.
text-fixed: Fire resistance in terms of integrity, for a period of minutes, when tested to BS 476-22, e.g. FD 30.

text: A suffix (S) is added for doorsets where restricted smoke leakage at ambient temperatures is needed.
text-fixed: A suffix (S) is added for doorsets where restricted smoke leakage at ambient temperatures is needed.

text: As determined with reference to Commission Decision 2000/367/EC regarding the classification of the resistance to fire performance of construction products, construction works and parts thereof.
text-fixed: As determined with reference to Commission Decision 2000/367/EC regarding the classification of the resistance to fire performance of construction products, construction works and parts thereof.

text: All fire doorsets should be classified in accordance with BS EN 13501-2, tested to the relevant European method from the following.
text-fixed: All fire doorsets should be classified in accordance with BS EN 13501-2, tested to the relevant European method from the following.

text: As determined with reference to European Parliament and Council Directive 95/16/EC (which applies to lifts that permanently serve buildings and constructions and specified safety components) on the approximation of laws of Member States relating to lifts (‘Lifts Directive’) implementing the Lifts Regulations 1997 (SI 1997/831) and calling upon the harmonised standard BS EN 81-58.
text-fixed: As determined with reference to European Parliament and Council Directive 95/16/EC (which applies to lifts that permanently serve buildings and constructions and specified safety components) on the approximation of laws of Member States relating to lifts (‘Lifts Directive’) implementing the Lifts Regulations 1997 (SI 1997/831) and calling upon the harmonised standard BS EN 81-58.

text: The performance requirement is in terms of integrity (E) for a period of minutes.
text-fixed: The performance requirement is in terms of integrity (E) for a period of minutes.

text: An additional classification of Sa is used for all doors where restricted smoke leakage at ambient temperatures is needed.
text-fixed: An additional classification of Sa is used for all doors where restricted smoke leakage at ambient temperatures is needed.

text: The requirement is for test exposure from each side of the doorset separately.
text-fixed: The requirement is for test exposure from each side of the doorset separately.

text: The exception is lift doors, which are tested from the landing side only.
text-fixed: The exception is lift doors, which are tested from the landing side only.

text: Any test evidence used to verify the fire resistance rating of a doorset or shutter should be checked to ensure both of the following.
text-fixed: Any test evidence used to verify the fire resistance rating of a doorset or shutter should be checked to ensure both of the following.

text: It adequately demonstrates compliance.
text-fixed: It adequately demonstrates compliance.

text: It is applicable to the complete installed assembly.
text-fixed: It is applicable to the complete installed assembly.

text: Small differences in detail may significantly affect the rating.
text-fixed: Small differences in detail may significantly affect the rating.

text: Until relevant harmonised product standards are published, for the purposes of meeting the Building Regulations, products tested in accordance with BS EN 1634-1 (with or without pre-fire test mechanical conditioning) that achieve the minimum performance in Table C1 will be deemed to satisfy the provisions.
text-fixed: Until relevant harmonised product standards are published, for the purposes of meeting the Building Regulations, products tested in accordance with BS EN 1634-1 (with or without pre-fire test mechanical conditioning) that achieve the minimum performance in Table C1 will be deemed to satisfy the provisions.

text: All fire doorsets, including to flat entrances and between a dwellinghouse and an integral garage, should be fitted with a self-closing device, except for all of the following.
text-fixed: All fire doorsets, including to flat entrances and between a dwellinghouse and an integral garage, should be fitted with a self-closing device, except for all of the following.

text: Fire doorsets to cupboards.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets to cupboards.

text: Fire doorsets to service ducts normally locked shut.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets to service ducts normally locked shut.

text: Fire doorsets within flats and dwellinghouses.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets within flats and dwellinghouses.

text: If a self-closing device would be considered to interfere with the normal approved use of the building, self-closing fire doors may be held open by one of the following.
text-fixed: If a self-closing device would be considered to interfere with the normal approved use of the building, self-closing fire doors may be held open by one of the following.

text: A fusible link, but not if the doorset is in an opening provided as a means of escape unless it complies with paragraph C7.
text-fixed: A fusible link, but not if the doorset is in an opening provided as a means of escape unless it complies with paragraph C7.

text: An automatic release mechanism activated by an automatic fire detection and alarm system.
text-fixed: An automatic release mechanism activated by an automatic fire detection and alarm system.

text: A door closer delay device.
text-fixed: A door closer delay device.

text: Two fire doorsets may be fitted in the same opening if each door is capable of closing the opening, so the total fire resistance is the sum of their individual resistances.
text-fixed: Two fire doorsets may be fitted in the same opening if each door is capable of closing the opening, so the total fire resistance is the sum of their individual resistances.

text: If the opening is provided as a means of escape, both fire doorsets should be self-closing.
text-fixed: If the opening is provided as a means of escape, both fire doorsets should be self-closing.

text: If one fire doorset is capable of being easily opened by hand and has a minimum of 30 minutes’ fire resistance, the other fire doorset should comply with both of the following.
text-fixed: If one fire doorset is capable of being easily opened by hand and has a minimum of 30 minutes’ fire resistance, the other fire doorset should comply with both of the following.

text: Be fitted with an automatic self-closing device.
text-fixed: Be fitted with an automatic self-closing device.

text: Be held open by a fusible link.
text-fixed: Be held open by a fusible link.

text: Fire doorsets often do not provide any significant insulation.
text-fixed: Fire doorsets often do not provide any significant insulation.

text: Unless providing both integrity and insulation in accordance with Appendix B, Table B3, a maximum of 25% of the length of a compartment wall should consist of door openings.
text-fixed: Unless providing both integrity and insulation in accordance with Appendix B, Table B3, a maximum of 25% of the length of a compartment wall should consist of door openings.

text: Where it is practicable to maintain a clear space on both sides of the doorway, the above percentage may be greater.
text-fixed: Where it is practicable to maintain a clear space on both sides of the doorway, the above percentage may be greater.

text: Rolling shutters should be capable of manual opening and closing for firefighting purposes (see Section 17).
text-fixed: Rolling shutters should be capable of manual opening and closing for firefighting purposes (see Section 17).

text: Rolling shutters across a means of escape should only be released by a heat sensor, such as a fusible link or electric heat detector, in the immediate vicinity of the door.
text-fixed: Rolling shutters across a means of escape should only be released by a heat sensor, such as a fusible link or electric heat detector, in the immediate vicinity of the door.

text: Unless a shutter is also intended to partially descend as part of a boundary to a smoke reservoir, shutters across a means of escape should not be closed by smoke detectors or a fire alarm system.
text-fixed: Unless a shutter is also intended to partially descend as part of a boundary to a smoke reservoir, shutters across a means of escape should not be closed by smoke detectors or a fire alarm system.

text: Unless shown to be satisfactory when tested as part of a fire doorset assembly, the essential components of any hinge on which a fire door is hung should be made entirely from materials that have a minimum melting point of 800°C.
text-fixed: Unless shown to be satisfactory when tested as part of a fire doorset assembly, the essential components of any hinge on which a fire door is hung should be made entirely from materials that have a minimum melting point of 800°C.

text: Except for doorsets listed in paragraph C12, all fire doorsets should be marked with one of the following fire safety signs, complying with BS 5499-5, as appropriate.
text-fixed: Except for doorsets listed in paragraph C12, all fire doorsets should be marked with one of the following fire safety signs, complying with BS 5499-5, as appropriate.

text: To be kept closed when not in use – mark ‘Fire door keep shut’.
text-fixed: To be kept closed when not in use – mark ‘Fire door keep shut’.

text: To be kept locked when not in use – mark ‘Fire door keep locked shut’.
text-fixed: To be kept locked when not in use – mark ‘Fire door keep locked shut’.

text: Held open by an automatic release mechanism or free swing device – mark ‘Automatic fire door keep clear’.
text-fixed: Held open by an automatic release mechanism or free swing device – mark ‘Automatic fire door keep clear’.

text: All fire doorsets should be marked on both sides, except fire doorsets to cupboards and service ducts, which should be marked on the outside.
text-fixed: All fire doorsets should be marked on both sides, except fire doorsets to cupboards and service ducts, which should be marked on the outside.

text-fixed: The following fire doorsets are not required to comply with paragraph C11.

text-fixed: Lift entrance/landing doors.

text-fixed: Recommendations for the specification, design, construction, installation and maintenance of fire doorsets constructed with non-metallic door leaves are given in BS 8214.

text: Guidance on timber fire resisting doorsets, in relation to the new European test standard, may be found in Timber Fire Resisting Doorsets: Maintaining Performance Under the New European Test Standard published by the Timber Research and Development Association (TRADA).

text: As an alternative to using the values in the table, the floor space factor may be determined by reference to actual data taken from similar premises.
text-fixed: As an alternative to using the values in the table, the floor space factor may be determined by reference to actual data taken from similar premises.

text: Where appropriate, the data should reflect the average occupant density at a peak trading time of year.
text-fixed: Where appropriate, the data should reflect the average occupant density at a peak trading time of year.

text: Where accommodation is not directly covered by the descriptions given, a reasonable value based on a similar use may be selected.
text-fixed: Where accommodation is not directly covered by the descriptions given, a reasonable value based on a similar use may be selected.

text: Where any part of the building is to be used for more than one type of accommodation, the most onerous factor(s) should be applied.
text-fixed: Where any part of the building is to be used for more than one type of accommodation, the most onerous factor(s) should be applied.

text: Where the building contains different types of accommodation, the occupancy of each different area should be calculated using the relevant space factor.

text: For detailed guidance on appropriate floor space factors for concourses in sports grounds refer to Concourses published by the Football Licensing Authority.
text-fixed: For detailed guidance on appropriate floor space factors for concourses in sports grounds refer to Concourses published by the Football Licensing Authority.

text: Alternatively the occupant number may be taken as the number of fixed seats provided, if the occupants will normally be seated.

text: Shops excluding those under item 10, but including: supermarkets and department stores (main sales areas), shops for personal services, such as hairdressing, and shops for the delivery or collection of goods for cleaning, repair or other treatment or for members of the public themselves carrying out such cleaning, repair or other treatment.
text-fixed: Shops excluding those under item 10, but including: supermarkets and department stores (main sales areas), shops for personal services, such as hairdressing, and shops for the delivery or collection of goods for cleaning, repair or other treatment or for members of the public themselves carrying out such cleaning, repair or other treatment.

text: Shops (excluding those in covered shopping complexes but including department stores) trading predominantly in furniture, floor coverings, cycles, prams, large domestic appliances or other bulky goods, or trading on a wholesale self-selection basis (cash and carry).
text-fixed: Shops (excluding those in covered shopping complexes but including department stores) trading predominantly in furniture, floor coverings, cycles, prams, large domestic appliances or other bulky goods, or trading on a wholesale self-selection basis (cash and carry).

text: Travel distance is measured as the shortest route.
text-fixed: Travel distance is measured as the shortest route.

text: Both of the following should be observed.
text-fixed: Both of the following should be observed.

text: If there is fixed seating or other fixed obstructions, the shortest route is along the centre line of the seatways and gangways.
text-fixed: If there is fixed seating or other fixed obstructions, the shortest route is along the centre line of the seatways and gangways.

text: If the route includes a stair, the shortest route is along the pitch line on the centre line of travel.
text-fixed: If the route includes a stair, the shortest route is along the pitch line on the centre line of travel.

text: Width is measured according to the following.
text-fixed: Width is measured according to the following.

text: For a door (or doorway), the clear width when the door is open (Diagram D1).
text-fixed: For a door (or doorway), the clear width when the door is open (Diagram D1).

text: For an escape route, either of the following.
text-fixed: For an escape route, either of the following.

text: When the route is defined by walls: the width at 1500mm above finished floor level.
text-fixed: When the route is defined by walls: the width at 1500mm above finished floor level.

text: Elsewhere: the minimum width of passage available between any fixed obstructions.
text-fixed: Elsewhere: the minimum width of passage available between any fixed obstructions.

text: For a stair, the clear width between the walls or balustrades.
text-fixed: For a stair, the clear width between the walls or balustrades.

text: On escape routes and stairs, handrails and strings intruding into the width by a maximum of 100mm on each side may be ignored.
text-fixed: On escape routes and stairs, handrails and strings intruding into the width by a maximum of 100mm on each side may be ignored.

text: Rails used for guiding a stair-lift may be ignored, but it should be possible to park the lift’s chair or carriage in a position that does not obstruct the stair or landing.
text-fixed: Rails used for guiding a stair-lift may be ignored, but it should be possible to park the lift’s chair or carriage in a position that does not obstruct the stair or landing.

text-fixed: If a hipped roof, measure to outermost point of roof at base area

text: If a lean-to roof,
text-fixed: If a lean-to roof, measure from the face of wall to the outermost point of roof

text-fixed: Room, garage, conservatory or outbuilding,

text-fixed: Storey, part or compartment,

text: is included as a storey, but not if it is a loading gallery,
text-fixed: In assembly buildings (purpose group 5), a gallery is included as a storey, but not if it is a loading gallery, fly gallery, stage grid, lighting bridge, or any gallery provided for similar purposes, or for maintenance and repair.

text: Sprinkler systems E1 Sprinkler systems installed in buildings can reduce the risk to life and significantly reduce the degree of damage caused by fire within a building.
text-fixed: Sprinkler systems E1 Sprinkler systems installed in buildings can reduce the risk to life and significantly reduce the degree of damage caused by fire within a building.

text: Further recommendations for the provision of sprinklers are provided in the following sections:
text-fixed: Further recommendations for the provision of sprinklers are provided in the following sections:

text: Design of sprinkler systems E3 Where required, sprinkler systems should be provided throughout the building or separated part, unless acting as a compensatory feature to address a specific risk.
text-fixed: Design of sprinkler systems E3 Where required, sprinkler systems should be provided throughout the building or separated part, unless acting as a compensatory feature to address a specific risk.

text: They should be designed and installed in accordance with the following.
text-fixed: They should be designed and installed in accordance with the following.

text: For residential buildings, the requirements of BS 9251.
text-fixed: For residential buildings, the requirements of BS 9251.

text: For non-residential buildings, or residential buildings outside the scope of BS 9251, the requirements of BS EN 12845, including the relevant hazard classification together with additional measures to improve system reliability and availability as described in Annex F of the standard.
text-fixed: For non-residential buildings, or residential buildings outside the scope of BS 9251, the requirements of BS EN 12845, including the relevant hazard classification together with additional measures to improve system reliability and availability as described in Annex F of the standard.

text: Any sprinkler system installed to satisfy the requirements of Part B of the Building Regulations should be provided with additional measures to improve system reliability and availability and is therefore to be regarded as a life safety system.
text-fixed: Any sprinkler system installed to satisfy the requirements of Part B of the Building Regulations should be provided with additional measures to improve system reliability and availability and is therefore to be regarded as a life safety system.

text: However, there may be some circumstances in which additional measures to improve system reliability and availability specified in Annex F of BS EN 12845 are inappropriate or unnecessary.
text-fixed: However, there may be some circumstances in which additional measures to improve system reliability and availability specified in Annex F of BS EN 12845 are inappropriate or unnecessary.

text: If the provisions in a building vary from those in this document, sprinkler protection can also sometimes be used as a compensatory feature.
text-fixed: If the provisions in a building vary from those in this document, sprinkler protection can also sometimes be used as a compensatory feature.

text: BS 9251 makes additional recommendations when sprinklers are proposed as compensatory features.
text-fixed: BS 9251 makes additional recommendations when sprinklers are proposed as compensatory features.

text: For non-residential sprinkler systems designed and installed to BS EN 12845, water supplies should consist of either of the following.
text-fixed: For non-residential sprinkler systems designed and installed to BS EN 12845, water supplies should consist of either of the following.

text: Two single water supplies complying with clause 9.6.1, independent of each other.
text-fixed: Two single water supplies complying with clause 9.6.1, independent of each other.

text: Two stored water supplies meeting all of the following conditions.
text-fixed: Two stored water supplies meeting all of the following conditions.

text: Gravity or suction tanks should satisfy all the requirements of clause 9.6.2(b), other than capacity.
text-fixed: Gravity or suction tanks should satisfy all the requirements of clause 9.6.2(b), other than capacity.

text: Any pump arrangements should comply with clause 10.2.
text-fixed: Any pump arrangements should comply with clause 10.2.

text: In addition to meeting the requirements for inflow, either of the following should apply.
text-fixed: In addition to meeting the requirements for inflow, either of the following should apply.

text: • The capacity of each tank should be at least half the specified minimum water volume of a single full capacity tank, appropriate to the hazard.
text-fixed: The capacity of each tank should be at least half the specified minimum water volume of a single full capacity tank, appropriate to the hazard.

text: • One tank should be at least equivalent to half the specified water volume of a single full capacity tank, and the other shall not be less than the minimum volume of a reduced capacity tank (see clause 9.3.4) appropriate to the hazard.
text-fixed: One tank should be at least equivalent to half the specified water volume of a single full capacity tank, and the other shall not be less than the minimum volume of a reduced capacity tank (see clause 9.3.4) appropriate to the hazard.

text: The total capacity of the water supply in (iii), including any inflow for a reduced capacity tank, should be at least that of a single full holding capacity tank that complies with Table 9, Table 10 or clause 9.3.2.3, as appropriate to the hazard and pipework design.
text-fixed: The total capacity of the water supply in (iii), including any inflow for a reduced capacity tank, should be at least that of a single full holding capacity tank that complies with Table 9, Table 10 or clause 9.3.2.3, as appropriate to the hazard and pipework design.

text: For the systems described in paragraph E5, both of the following apply if pumps are used to draw water from two tanks.

text: Each pump should be able to draw water from either tank.
text-fixed: Each pump should be able to draw water from either tank.

text: Any one pump, or either tank, should be able to be isolated.
text-fixed: Any one pump, or either tank, should be able to be isolated.

text: The sprinkler water supplies should not be used as connections for other services or other fixed firefighting systems.
